Transfer from BA review on 3-7-13-
 Served on tap in a pint glass

 Appearance – The beer is served a medium amber color with a one-half finger white head. The head fades fast to leave a persistent foam on the top of the brew with very light lacing on the sides of the glass.

 Smell –The aroma is very light overall and only consists of a very small amount of roasted malt and caramel.

 Taste – The taste begins with a good caramel malt backbone that creates a rather sweeter and breadier flavor. This taste lasts throughout the taste with very little change. Toward the middle of the taste a notes of toffee and a more buttery flavor comes to the tongue. These mix with a very light herbal and grassy hop flavor at the end of the taste which end up leaving a smooth and sweet flavor to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel – The body of the beer for an only 4.3 % abv beer is much creamier then would be anticipated while the carbonation level is rather average. The thicker body is nice for accentuating the toffee and buttery flavors of the brew while the average carbonation level keeps it refreshing and easy drinking. Nicely done for the flavors and style.

 Overall – While the flavor profile is not too complex, but instead rather simple, it is quite nice and with the lower alcohol level makes this brew an easy one to drink.
Clear dark amber with small off white head. Aroma is subdued due to very cold serving temps. Taste is nutty, caramel , toffee . No finish.

Bottle from missoula, York. Beautiful toasty amber colour and a healthy head. Aroma is orange and a bit of lychee, malts and hops. Taste is mild and crisp. A little too mich carb for me but Very drinkable none the less.

Aroma is clove, light sweet malts and slight sulphur hints. Taste is a light sweet maltiness with some graininess and light caramel notes. There is a subtle bitterness that is quite well balanced and finishes very smoothly. Appearance is a copper /gold with a medium pearl head that retains fairly well.
Bottle. Pours clear amber with nice white head. Nose is citrus and grain. Taste is dry bitterness. Okay bitter.
(bottle) bright clear amber colour with a small white head; aroma of stewed fruit; faint and watery flavour - dishwater after washing beer bottles? very forgettable
Pours light chestnut, brief white head. Faint malt aroma. Very light, approaching watery. Flavor is sweetish, light malt. A bit of fizz. Overall a good session beer. Pleasant but very light.
Somewhat disappointing bitter. Rather watery and low on flavors. Is this the same Honker’s as before the InBev acquisition?
12 FL OZ ($4.00) had this at a local bar. not bad good but far from special. In my opinion when there are lots of better choices to be made.

On tap in Ajax. clear red amber like colour. light citrus aroma with a real zesty note that I find surprising but there is some malt cereal like notes in there as well. Medium bodied, lightly hopped and again sort of zesty on the palate. Easily forgetful.
Bottle bier huis ossett. Amber thin head. Aroma is caramel biscuit malts. Taste is same slight fruit and spice light bitter finish. Medium body ok stuff

On tap at Biermarkt. Clear copper pour with small off white head leaving sheets of lace. Sweet caramel and roasted nut nose. Medium sweet start with a balanced bitter middle. Light to medium mouth with soft carbonation. Just OK
Pours amber color with a thick white head. Not overly bitter but definitely has a slight taste.

Aroma: Malt: Medium biscuit, syrup. Medium Hops: Medium-high, fruity, 
Appearance: Body, hazy copper. Head, medium, creamy, good retention.
Flavour: Malt: Medium-light, biscuit, syrup. Hops: Medium-light, fruity. Bitterness: Medium., but not overpowering or harsh. Lingering bitterness, not harsh.
Mouthfeel: Light body, medium-high carbonation, creamy
Overall: Good, but I would lower the carbonation quite a bit.

355 ml bottle, poured. Thanks Andre!
8B. Special/Best/Premium Bitter

Light amber pour with small white head. Aroma of hops, spice, and slightly fruity. Taste of malts, caramel, slight citrus, slight peppery spice and a faint bitter hop finish. Light bodied, medium carbonation, slightly dry finish.
Bottle at La Guardia Airport, New York September 2013. Decent beer with amber colour and big fluffy head. Nutty biscuit flavour and quite malty.
One of my favorite bitters nice color... Not overly hoppy. And not too carbonated. A real traditional English bitter.
Pours Amber with a thick white head. Has an earthy aroma with a moderate hoppy flavor.

Coming from the Hinterlands of Ontario’s LCBO domain I’ve only seen the Vintage versions of GL beer, which are exceptional. This is the first regular beer, if seasonal, I’ve had. So...Pint poured in a random Philly airport restaurant. Pours dark amber with finer of fluffy beige head. Smells of hops and caramel malt. Taste caramel malts, bitter malts, some ash on the finish with some lingering bitterness. Generally good beer. In a airport no less. 5 years ago it would all be Bud, MGD and Labatt Blue as the import. we’ve come a long way baby. Don’t worry about this one Tiki.

Tap at Darcy McGee’s Orleans. Pours burnt orange limited head with some lacing. Nose is sweet. Flavours or light caramel, maybe some honey, some Cheerios. Taste light/med sweet, light bitter. Medium body somewhat sticky mouthfeel. Nice beer.

bottle, pours light amber, slightly hazy, with off-white head. Sweet malty aroma of caramel and cookies, with hoppy citrus and resin note. Taste is malty, caramel, with light bitterness. Medium body, soft carbonation, bit tart aftertaste.

On tap at a restaurant in Des Moines, IA. Pours orange with a small white head. Aroma is caramel and hops. Taste is lightly sweet, moderate hops with a mild bitterness, caramel. Medium mouthfeel. A pleasant drink.

On draft. Not much aroma. Pours orange. Taste is bitter with a nice hoppiness. Good summer time beer in my opinion. I could drink a few at a time. Not sure why it is rating so low on here.

-- rated with beerbasher/winphone
Clear golden amber with fluffy white head. Aromas of hops and malty undertones. Taste slightly too sweet for me. Some bitterness.Creamy texture and soft carbonation.

Draft @ Golden Crust, Red Lion, PA. Pours amber/brown, head was thin but lacing was there. Aroma of bread, nuts and herbs. Taste is mildly bitter, lots of malty sweetness. Body was light, medium carbonation, mouth feel was a little thin. Finishes earthy bitter (herbs, flowers) and toasty malt sweetness. A good example of a English style bitter.

With my parents on the way to the Lakehouse. Aroma is idk I am drinking from the bottle. Taste is nice smooth bitterness on the earthy side but fresh and light. I like it. I order this stuff when I am out and there is not too much on tap.
It's like a simple slightly oaky nutty lager. There is nothing offensive about it, but it's pretty tame overall. The oak aftertaste stays in your mouth for a long time.
On tap at The Landing in Boston, somewhat bready, fairly mild, hoppy ending.
Pretty bitter and very palettey, no bad aftertaste though, which means if you can deal with bitter it won’t last afterwards.

Pint on tap at Beer Revolution in Edmonton pours a clear pale amber color with a finger of white head that leaves some nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is caramel with some light fruits and floral notes. Taste is a fruity and malty sweetness with a grassy and herbal bitterness. Light bodied with good carbonation leaving the palate satisfied. A well done English style bitter which is easy to drink and quite tasty.

On tap at Beer Rev. I am at home now lying in bed doing a review from 45 min old memory.... May god have mercy on my soul. Taste good, smells good, looks like a relish beer, what else can be said? Tons-o-flavour for such a low alc. No real faults, maybe just maybe hints of soap. Now as I lie in bed to lazy to have brushed my teeth I can taste metal and caramel in the lingering after taste. I could drink the ship out of this beer!
Bottle from Booths, Media City. Hazy deeper amber in colour with a thin head. Light withe a smooth drinking texture. Has an orange fruit nose which is less stated in its taste but remains pleasant.
Not too bad for an ale. A little hoppy but not near as intense as others. I wouldn’t turn one down but if it’s more than a couple I would probably take a pass...
Bottle pour. Amber color with a decent head. Fruity and hoppy flavor. Taste is the same. Well balanced with a nice bitter finish.
12 oz bottle pours an amber color with a small white head. Aromas of fruit, malt sweetness. Light bodied, very nice bitter

From bottle to glass
Aroma: smells of delicious caramel maltyness, slight hint of chocolate

Appearance: a clear light copper body with a just off-white well-sized head

Taste: light on the bitter, medium on the sweet

Palate: feels very light-bodied and thin with soft carbonation. The finish however is pretty long for a beer of this type. Leaves quite the impression.

I really enjoyed this easy-drinking ale. Very smooth caramel malts with the slightest bitterness. I would definitely enjoy this again.

Bottle at home. 
Watery nose, cucumber, grapefruit. 
Hazy orange amber, fine white head. 
Medium body, some sweetness, fruity, grapefruit, sharp bubbles, watery aftertaste. 


:)
Bolton Brew.

Bottle from Bob’s.



Amber-brown pour with a reasonable-sized off-white head. The nose is surprisingly fruity, some yeast as well. Relatively thin as one might expect at 4.3%, flavors brown bread with metal and some cider. 



Not bad, not spectacular, props for low 4% abv.

On top of a nice orange amber body sits a good two finger tall eggshell colored foam head. The head hangs on well and makes cool lace patterns on the glass. The aroma has a nice sweet maltiness with caramel and a good balance of citrus hops. Up first there is a simple bready maltiness with some mild caramel like sweetness and light toasted grain with faint hints of fruitiness. This is balanced by pleasant citrus and leafy hop bitterness. The medium body has a smooth feel and drinks easily.
Bottle at ribs n bibs lincoln. Amber with a good white head. Aroma and taste of sweetness with hops and marmalade.

(On tap) Pours a clear copper with one finger of fluffy head diminishing gradually to a thin cap, heavy lacing. Nose is predominantly biscuity english malt, faint pine and citrus hops. Taste follows suit, with a mellow caramel sweetness followed by a mild bitter finish. Mouth feel is medium-bodied, with low carbonation and and off-dry bitter finish.

Not my favourite style, I admit. But as it goes, not bad. The malt isn’t overwhelming, and is decently balanced against the mild bittering. It’ll do, I guess, but I won’t have a second.

On tap poured into a glass that looks something like a crossbred hefeweizen glass and an imperial pint. The aromas are mellow with notes of bread crust and toast, some light caramel, and a slight mildew and a touch of citrus. It pours a clear, sparkling, copper brown and is topped by a soft, snowy white head. The head contains even, small bubbles and laces in thick, creamy layers. It’s well balanced between medium light sweet and bitter tastes. The thin texture has lots of soft carbonation with a medium light, malty body. The finish is primarily caramel with some support from a roasted grain, and a citrus peel accent. It’s somewhat on the dry side with a bit of a resin feel to it. The aftertaste is a light, clean pine note.
Pours a clear golden color with white head. Pine and some citrus hops on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with maltiness.

Look: pours a gold straw color. Thick white head.
Smell: hoops in the beginning. Pine flavors almost zero fruit smell.
Taste: taste pint, slightly bitter on the back end. Also good amount of malt.
Feel: good carbonation. Easy on the palate. Not heavy at all. Leaves no film on the mouth.
Overall: not a bad summer beer. Not as citrus as I like but still a good flavor. Well balanced.
First drank: 5/25/14 at CCD
On tap at Redwood Cafe. Pours a pale amber color with a bit of head. A little harsh. Sweet and swill beer malt taste.

Bière achetée dans un Deli près de Times Square. Couleur cuivrée, avec une belle mousse. Nez de malt avec des noisettes grillées. En bouche, la Honker’s ale est maltée, avec des notes caramélisées d’une rousse standard. Rien de bien spécial à signaler, mais c’est tranquillo et rafraichissant. Bière d’entrée de gamme qui plaira à tous. Le houblon est léger, donc il ne repoussera personne, et le malt est assez intéressant et équilibré pour intéressé les non initiés. Cheers!

Bottle purchased at Bacchus, Olney. Golden and hazy, mid to heavy carbonation with small white head & reasonable lacing. Fruity and floral aroma, full of hops. Caramel, toast and honey can also be detected on the nose. Overall sweet taste and a short finish: simple and unexciting but far from disappointing. A nice American twist on the UK bitter style.
Pours a dark yellow with a thin white head. It has a sweet, toasty corn flake aroma with a hint of hops. The taste is of piney hops and a light, smooth, slightly sweet cereal finish. Not bad!

Pouted from 12oz bottle. Not what i would expect from Goose Island. Pale in color with a lack of depth or character. Slight malt opening with a hint of hops on the back end. Just not enough flavor here to warrant praise. 

--you've been Dubbed.
Clear copper pour with off white head. Aroma is sweet, biscuity malts. Flavour has caramel, bready malts, light toast, some sweetness. Finish is a touch of piney hops. Okay, but session worthy.

The aroma has caramel flavors and some esters with low hop aroma. The appearance is copper with a small white head and not much retention. It is a clear beer. The flavor is toast and caramel and very balanced with a somewhat dry finish. Some bitterness shows through at the end. The mouth feel is medium to medium light with moderate carbonation. Overall it is easy drinking and balanced beer with moderate carbonation. I would like to see a minor increase in hop for a slightly more hop forward bitterness.
Ambrée/rousse. Légèrement amère. Un peu de caramel. Banane. Biscuit sec. Malté. Rafraichissante et sèche. Simple mais bien.

On tap at D’Arcy McGee’s (Ottawa, ON). Limpid copper body with a thin off-white creamy head. Decent malty/hoppy aroma with some grainy and brown sugar hints. Its well balanced taste is slightly dominated by hoppy flavors. It also carries grainy, herbal, and subtle citrusy notes. Ends with a good bitter finish. Good "routine bitter".

For those who like their bitter, bitter, this is a bit light. Nice light copper color with faint bready malt and light earthy hop aroma. Overall, I call it a "bitter-lite" in style, but certainly drinkable and sessionable.
Ins glas ergießt sich ein bernsteinfarbenes Bier mit schöner beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch fruchtig malzig, Karamell, dunkle Beeren. Geschmack hopfig fruchtig, nussig, Karamell.

On tap at Buffalo Wildwings in Fort Collins. Appearance: finger of white head, light amber color, clear, good lacing. Aroma: floral, citrus, caramel, resin. Palate: light body, average carbonation, sticky, bitter finish. Taste: medium sweet with a delayed medium bitter kicking in on the end. Overall, good balance, and very nice aromas and taste.

Bouteille de 355 ml (12 oz fl.) achetée lors d’un voyage à Chicago. Dégustée le 11 novembre 2010. Bière rousse voilée. Mousse peu, col mince beige, éphémère. Très peu effervescente, bulles fines. Odeur de froment, de berries et de pain grillé. Très douce, assez sucrée, peu amère. Très bonne mais un peu mince, manque un peu de caractère.
Very drinkable ale with a nice ruby color, thin off-white head, a somewhat disagreeable aroma at first but the taste is fine.
Aroma of hops and malt, caramel colour small head. A malty taste slightly sour with a watery mildly bitter finish.
Des biscuits sablés un tantinet caramélisés, corps croustillant, saveurs éphémères et amertume modeste.
Draft. Pours a dark reddish color with small white head. Taste and aroma of toffee with some slight fruitiness. As it warns some toasty and almost roasty flavors come thru. Pretty easy to drink.
Bottle. Pours copper red with good carbonation and medium head. Aroma is a malty bread smell. Medium body, lightly fizzy. Finish is very bitter. Not my style.

Bottle pour. Clean amber in glass. Small head. Mild nose of roasted malts, trace amounts of fruit and continental hops. Taste is mellow. Good balance between the bitter and bready sweetness. Drinkable.
Tastes like Samuel Adams, but with a sweet ending. All in all, still too hoppy for me.

Bottle. Pours clear golden brown. Light head with little lacing. Nice aroma with a hint of fruits. Medium body with a sharp bitter taste that is somewhat lasting.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft to pint glass
Papaya, orange, cookie, pepper, and berries. Clear reddish amber with a thin white head. Taste is quite malty, some skinkiness, and astringent bitterness, along with light caramel and light tropical fruits. I don’t know, the skunkiness overpowers too much of this beer.

tap/can. Poured deep amber with a thin but creamy off-white head. Bready malt aroma with an orange citrusy hops.  Medium body with some creaminess that ends on a tart dry note. Caramel malt, burnt sugar and wood with a fresh leafy hop flavour, some sweet citrus throughout.

12 ounce bottle into pint glass, bottled on 12/3/2013. Pours lightly hazy/cloudy copper amber color with a 2 finger fairly dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Light spotty foamy lacing clings on the glass, with some light streaming carbonation. Aromas of caramel, toast, biscuit, orange zest, herbal, grass, pepper, light pear/apple, and herbal/yeast earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance of malt, hop, and yeast ester notes; with good strength. Taste of caramel, toast, biscuit, orange zest, herbal, grass, pepper, light pear/apple, and toast/yeast earthiness. Good amount of earthy herbal/pepper bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, toast, biscuit, orange zest, herbal, grass, pepper, and toast/yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice balance of malt, hop, and light-moderate yeast flavors; with good robustness and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbontion and light-medium bodied; with a smooth, crisp, and slightly bready mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish as expected of 4.2%. Overall this is a very nice English bitter style. All around good robustness and balance of malt, hop, and light-moderate yeast ester flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink. A very enjoyable offering.

pours clear bright golden orange with a small nice creamy off-white head, some retention and lacing. nutty and spicy caramel malts, pepper crackers, lemon tea, clean english yeast - although slighty dusty and metallic, grass, pepper, soft earthy notes, hint of honey sweetness. moderate carbonation, light body - not quite watery, relatively dry and bittering grassy-spicy-peppery finish. nicely done.
Bottle pour. Copper in color. Aroma of bitter hops and caramel. Low on flavor, but a drinkable beer overall. A little bready. Not bad.

Bottle 33 cl.

Pours light amber with small nicely lacing head. Quite hoppy, and light to medium malty aroma. Rather mild, well balanced and round bitter taste.
12oz bottle to tulip glass. Pours a very clear copper with a quick disappearing head. Taste is a bit weak for an ale but does go down ok

Deep amber color. Not to much aroma. Fast white dissapearing head. Definitely an English tasty beer. Bitter taste at the end. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A caramel, malty British ale-esque treat with a modest amount of hops to balance. Doesn't set the world on fire but a fine representation of the style.

Rated by BrewTom
Small taste of my Dad’s mug at some chop house in Muscatine. A beer I’ve had several times before, still drinking pretty good after many years.
Amber with contasting white head. Some lacing. Aroma and taste of pale toffee, English hops and orange marmelade. Thin mouthfeel

Flaske fra HelgøMeny i Hundvågkrossen, på Holmens aktivitetsdag mars-14: pent hvitt skum med kniplinger og nydelig ravfarge. Men her stopper også gleden. Synes denne har en lett og intetsigende smak, tynn og vandig munnfølelse kombinert med en kort ettersmak. Skuffende fra Goose Island.
Klar mørk gyllen farve med lys beige skum. Lukt av malt, karamell og humle. smak av malt og karamell. Supermarked.

Bottle at a hotel room, London. Dark golden with off white head. Aroma is biscuit, perfume, nuts, floral, and some yeast. Taste is similar, biscuit, toffee, toast, nuts, earth and spice. Very well balanced and pleasant to drink
Bottle @ Home: Pours amber (unclear) with a powerful beige foam. Aroma malty with slight hints of herbal hops. Light mouth feel and a dry aftertaste
Poured from the tap. Clear light amber brown with off-white head. Malty aroma. Malty taste, cereal, with some mild nutty notes. Medium body. Full taste to start, but dissipates into mild finish.

Bottle: Solid amber color with burnt orange highlights; super-hazy, nearly opaque & topped with a creamy, eggshell head on top that leaves some generous lacing behind. Aroma is super malty; soft caramel, toasted nuts, lightly boozy toffee, earthy & leafy hop aromas, candied barley, & very subtle brown sugar. Taste is a little watered down & very light. Mild nuttiness, much less sweet than the aroma would indicate. Light toffee & caramel over earth, dirt, grass, toast, & a timid nuttiness. Mild, woodsy musk flavor with caramel covered toast & toasted nuts in the aftertaste... Small hint of yeast & wet wood. Lots of stuff packed into this 4.3% ABV beer, but the synchronization could be a little better.
Pours a clear copper with thin white head the quickly dissolves. Light hop and malt aroma. Nice amount of hop bitterness with a smooth mouth feel. Refreshing light finish. An excellent session beer.
Quite unusual sweetish taste. Moorish, and distinctive sweet aroma I hadn’t smelled before.

DATE TASTED: February 13, 2014... GLASSWARE: Kisatsky’s Tavern pint...OCCASION: snow day half done--part two of the storm, beginning now ... APPEARANCE: classic amber body with steady effervescence; beautiful snow white head that creates wonderful, patterned lacing... AROMA: butterscotch, hazelnut, and light yet fragrant hops are counterbalanced by the expected English bitter malts...PALATE: active, medium bodied yet easy-drinking, as the label advertises...TASTE: bitter indeed--slightly abrasive bite tempered by unmistakable ESB maltiness--drinkable and enjoyable, but not overtly winning... OVERALL: a strong representation of the style, with the proper strength, mouthfeel and flavor to elicit a sessionable night; a second quality offering from Goose Island, after the 312 Wheat...

Bottle from chester beer and wine, chester. Orange amber beer with large head. Quite a bit of carbonation. Aroma of yeast, mandarins, malts and caramel. The taste follows the aroma with the addition of grapefruit. Decent.
Bottle at a conference. Clear appearance. Aroma of cinnamon and nutmeg. Med carb and bod. Light taste thats balanced.
Bottle gift from SJ. Nice easy drinking brew with notes of caramel malt, and hop. The body was a bit too think for my tastes, but it was still good.

Appearance was clear deep gold with diminishing creamy off white 1 finger head, spotty lacing. Aromas are simple biscuit toasty malts with light floral hop nose, maybe fruity yeasts instead. Taste are mild biscuit toast toffee malts with soft earthy spicy hops. Palate was soft smooth CO2 with light-medium body, then lasting balanced slightly drying finish. An good bitter for the style.
Dark pour with beige head. Caramel, malt, hop, dark fruits. Pretty complex, toasted malt backbone. Fruit and oak, followed by the bite. Medium-thin body.
Drinkable. Very malty, very refreshing. Pretty standard English ale. Sessionable and pretty good.

355ml bottle from The Local Pub, Athens Greece. Poured a copper orange with a big white head. Aromas of caramel and toasted notes. Taste at the same levels with some nice hop bitterness. Long-lasting aftertaste. Light body and low to medium carbonation.
Draft - Toasted malts and a bit of caramel. Clear copper with a rich white head. Toasted malts and caramel with a mild hop bitterness. Light and simple, typical English style bitter.

Chocolate, coffee malt smooth Finnish. This beer is worthy of everyone on this site to try. You will not be disappointed!



---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled, 355ml from Beers of Europe, Norfolk. Orange gold with fizzed white head. This is way too carbonated for me and certainly to match ’pub’ beers, wet cardboard on the aroma and initial flavour. There is a fruity sweetness within the malt, sweet orange notes then a reasonable earthy leafy hop, but the initial flavour put me off I’m sorry to say. Not for me.
Pours a nice copper color with a thin white head. Aroma is caramel and light earthy hops. Flavor is similar. Has medium carbonation and a light body feel. Not too impressive.

Head pies like a hefeweizen, but surprisingly has more lacing. Clear and dark brown. Tastes citrus and caramel. Hops is not overwhelming but seems stronger that IBU 30. A great beer to have with dinner
Pours a clear light amber, with minimal white head. Very little aroma, although pleasant notes of blended malt and hops. Well balanced and drinkable. Still better than macro-brews...

Bottle.

A- Malts, citrus.

A- Brown orange color, clear liquid, minimal head.

T- Bitter, citrus zest, slightly sweet.

P- Medium body, average texture, medium carbonation, crisp dry finish.

O- Bitter but not overly so. This beer fits it’s style well. There isn’t a lot of complexity to it, but it has been done well enough that it doesn’t matter.

Bottle. Pours a burnt orange/amber, quite cloudy with a thick, foamy head. Aromas of sweetness, vinousy, doughy, malts. Taste is rich, quite hoppy, smooth mouthfeel, hints of citrussy zest, bitter orange and marmalade, orange peel, a refreshing finish. Pretty good overall.
Lys gylden med flust av skum. Aroma av malt og humle. Smaken er hovedsakelig malt, men en fin bitterhet som lurer i bakgrunnen. Tynn/medium konsistens.

2 glass bottled 12 ouncers poured into an english pint glass and placed the remainder of the 2nd bottle away, to be kept cool.
Purchased a 12 pak for hardly what a 6 pak of, say, keystone, would cost.
Asked the proprietor why so cheap? "The beer’s discontinued in Colorado".
I bought a case. 
.....Just came back from buying another case; the 312 was already sold out.

12oz bottle served in a Sam Adams perfect pint
bottled on March 20th 2013

A - Pours a copper/amber color, clear and shiny, 1 finger of off-white head

S - Sweet grain, caramel, some berry fruit, nut bread.

T - Toasted caramel malt, grainy wheat, has some lemon acidity upfront, grassy hops, bitterness grows and really dries off toward the end. Finishes dry and crisp.

M - Carbonation is spritzy but turns creamy.

A tasty bitter that I could drink all day long. Slighty sweet upfront transition to a dry crisp, and refreshing finish.

Serving type: bottle

05-14-2013

Clear orange with a thick head. Bread and spruce aroma. Moderately bitter flavor, and very smooth finish. This is a very drinkable ale. It is very well balanced, and doesn’t call attention to itself. I like it.
Tasted from a 12oz. bottle. It poured a clear amber with a frothy white head. Has a mild malt aroma. A smooth, easy drinking ale with malty hop taste.

Nice drinkable beer. Golden amber in color but is a bit dry and flat. Would drink again. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

pours a amber color with a thick head with lots of lacing. the aroma is malts and also some cereal in it as well. the taste was very impressive, tasted like sweet malts and some breadiness as well. some hop character as well.

Bottle @ home, picked up at RJs Fort Collins. Pours a dark orange appearance with a cream colored head. Bready, chewy/doughy, light caramel, herbal aroma. Pretty good body. Light tangerine, dough, caramel, toast, earthy flavor. A bit twangy. Not something I’d buy again but it’s not bad.
Had this a hundred times but forgot to rate it I guess. Red pour from draft at blackfinn. Malty and earth dirt taste. Bitter and tasty. Good beer and order it whenever I can

Draft at Boca Ale House served in a pint glass. Deep golden clear pour with a velvety head (it may have been a nitro pour.) The head was a great white pillow. Aroma was fairly weak but it had a nice cereal and malt on the nose. The taste was similar with no real flavors standing out but the malt presence was very nice. Little caramel. Extremely smooth, low-medium carb. Very easy to drink session beer.

Honker’s Ale is one of those beers that you can drink at pretty much any given time. It doesn’t have any characteristics that particularly stand out. It’s just a damn good beer that’s very easy to drink. While it won’t even be seen as anything special, it’s an ale that works for every occasion.

Bottle bought from Beermoth, Manchester. Pours a nice clear golden amber with a bubbly but quickly dissipating head. Sweet vanilla honey aroma with what I can only describe as a sweet shop smell to boot. Very low carbonation, with taste of biscuit and fruits. Not what I was expecting after having tried the IPA from this brewer, but a pleasant enough surprise.

355ml btl. abv4.3 b@eurospar.
Off white yellowish head. Somewhat hazy deep golden or amber body.
Flowerish scents, apples, flowers, herbs, summer breeze.
Taste with low bitterness, sweet dark malts, citric notes, 
Well balanced to palate. Finishes with caramel, malts, sweet bun dough.

Thanks to dhren1979 for this snack. Cheers doug!

A: Pours a hazy brownish copper ale with a single finger of peanut head that dissipates to a medium sheet of the same. Stubborn lacing. 

S: nutty, noble hops, earthy. Slight metallic and cardboard scents. Decent florals in there as well.

T: Good healthy malt backbone, pale in nature. The hops are quite pleasant on this one. Good earthyness with the slightest hint of citrus and woodsy character. Quite on par with English Bitters I’ve had. Well done.

M: Medium body with high carbonation. A hair too high on the carb IMO. The finish is mouthwatering.

O: Well done beer. Appreciate the low ABV for an american ale. Totally drinkable and I would pick up on a regular basis if it was in my area. Good stuff.

Serving type: bottle

04-16-2011
355ml bottle from Good Spirits Company, Glasgow - clear amber brown, thin off-white head, nice fruity malty aroma, no lacing, malty, hint of vanilla, carbonation on the high side, vanilla finish

330ml bottle shared with mr_h. Reddish orange brown, reasonable head. Spicy vanilla malt aroma sweet creamy vanilla biscuit flavour Not a typical bitter. More like a hybrid with an Innis & Gunn Scottish ale.

Pours a clear light amber with a slightly red hue. Slight head and lacing that doesn’t linger. Slight nose of pine hops against a sweet background. Light medium body and good carbonation. The taste is laid back with a mild bitterness predominating a light sweetness. Very well balanced with a short burst of mild hop flavor that is balanced between pine and citrus. Clean crisp finish with a slight lingering bitterness that is somewhat tart. A very good session beer for non-hopheads.

This Goose Island Classic has a nice golden/amber color and a thick light tan head. The head was actually just a step darker than off-white.This beer has a nice malted wheat taste that is slightly sweet which balances the bitter hop notes well. Honker’s Ale seems like a straight up ale that isn’t terribly complex. It’s a medium bodied beer with nice carbonation that stands up well to typical pub food.
Deep golden color, white head. Aroma is malty and some honey. Medium body, honey, hops, fruits.

Appearance: Hazy amber/copper with cm thick ivory head which was quick to disappear.
Aroma: Mango, boiled sweets, treacle, apricot jam.
Taste: Medium sweet, with low/medium bitter and sourness.
Palate: Thick smooth texture, light body, low carbonation, abrupt spicy sweet apricot jam finish.
Comments: Tatsy
English yeast character in the aroma. Some light caramel flavour and some american hops. Bitter finish.
Nice copper color when poured with a pillowy head. Slightly bitter with a bit of a fruity aftertaste. Wife liked it.

Pours copper with a minimal white head which quickly dissipated. Initial flavor is citrus which quickly transitioned to a biscuity, malt finish. Medium carbonation and overall very drinkable.

Pours a pale copper color with a white head. Biscuit, grain, hop, caramel and malt aroma. Malt, biscuit, grain and earthy hop flavors. Light body and moderate carbonation. Smooth mouthfeel and biscuit finish.

I had this at Global Brew. Pours amber with a white head. Taste sweet, Carmel, bitter. I thought this was good. I could drink this again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled, 0.355l. Clear pale amber color with average creamy, mostly diminishing off-white head and sparkling appearance. Aroma of moderate citrus and herbal hops, berries and mild tropical fruits. Taste starts with moderate sweet caramel malty backbone, follows light fruity with spicy mouthfeel and light bitter finish. Full body, creamy texture and average carbonation in palate. Easy drinking bitter, very aromatic with much more hops than in English bitters...
Somewhat refreshing while being kind of malty and kind of bitter. Didn’t have a bad aroma though.
Red/ochre colour. Small head. Close to no aroma, but what I smell is hoppy and ok. Sub-standard, boring bitter taste. Don’t waste your money.

From bottle to glass at room temp. Amber in colour with little head. Slight hop on the nose and malt flavours coming through on the taste. A little too much carbonation to be a ’an English country pub ale’.
Good beer. Nice taste. On the lighter side but not too light. Doesn?t fill you up. Nice ESB

The aroma is sweet with nodes of fruit and citrus. Has a hazy light amber color with a small white head. Has a very malty character with hints of coriander and nuts. A nice slightly bitter and fresh finish.

Incredibly malty and hoppy aroma, very sweet. Muddy brown appearance. Really malty, not very ’English country pubs’ to me but better actually. Although slightly surprised by the sweetness, possibly some unfermented malt going on here - not sure. Good, although somewhat simple.

Bouteille de 12 oz achetée chez Beverage Warehouse (Burlington, VT). Arôme: Légère odeur de céréale avec une pointe fruitée. Apparence: La couleur est dorée avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence d’un mince col mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de céréale avec une pointe d’houblon et de sucre. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Arrière gout légèrement houblonné. (Rating #5291)
Poured from the bottle into a glass. A nice ale very easy to drink. Had as part of a variety pack and this was the 2nd best one.
Probably one of the better mass produced beers that goose island has. Descent flavor but really a mediocre beer at best.
Bready malt, a hint of caramel, and some pine hops. Very dry. Nothing complex here, simple and drinkable.

12oz into pint glass. Pour is a clear amber color with a finger width of thick off-white head. Aroma is moderately hoppy with citrus and bready notes. Some caramel sneaks through too. Taste is mild with a slight hop bitterness and some malt. Good balance, light to medium body and easy to drink.

Better than expected. Mildly piney hop aroma, which made it promising. Dark golden color with a white head. Good carbonation and somewhat watery palate, which to me seemed to fit the style. Some hops bitterness up front with straw and grain character as the backbone. Goes well with food.
Bready and earthy malts and floral hops. Some autumn baking spices. English bitterness. Medium body. Decent and drinkable

A: Amber Hue, Passes Most Light, White Head, Decent Lacing

S: Malty, Earthy, Mild Floral

T: Malty, Floral

M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Malty, Mild Bitter

Overall, a decent over produced beer. Drinkable.

AMber with foamy white rimming lacy head; aroma is light with hints of raspberrie; flava is of fresh malt grain some fruitiness of raspberries; feels light and silky with slight fizz; finishes sweet yet dry and bitter with notes of hops mixed with grain and hops
Blah. Bottle might be skunked. Lots of oily head. Looks pretty tasty. Aroma is mild. The flavor is muted. A slightly bitter finish, but over all leaves a clean mouthfeel. Not my favorite.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a pint glass. Has a very deep amber color and a thin, quickly dissipating head. Has an aroma of sweet bread.. or biscuits?? The aroma was faintly similar to that of a pilsner. Also smells of some indistinct fruits. Taste is crisp, sweet, and spicy. Hops are noticeable in the finish.

Goose Island Honker’s Ale has a thin, creamed-colored head, a clear, copper appearance, some bubble streams, lots of tiny suspended white particles, and some lacing left behind on the glass. The aroma is very fruity (citrus, mostly), bready, and caramel. Taste is of caramel, citrus fruit, bread crust, sweetness, and a slight bitterness. Mouthfeel is light to medium and slick, and Goose Island Honker’s Ale finishes semi-dry, refreshing, and easy drinking. Overall it is very good. RJT

12oz bottle. Pours a crystal-clear copper with a finely-textured head. No aroma to speak of; this is not a hop-forward ale. It is, however, an exceptionally well-balanced brew with a rich, full body that is neither sweet nor bitter. It is just right--and an eminently drinkable ale.

Aroma is hoppy with a mellow malt smell. Appearance is golden, a medium color, with a small head. Taste is very well balanced between hops and malt, with a medium body. Overall, quite delicious.
Pours amber with slight head. slight malt flavor, not very bitter. Okay brew.
For a bitter it’s actually not that bitter. It has a sweet fruity taste that finishes bitter. I like it in moderate, infrequent quantities.
slightly malty slighty hoppy very carbonated a tinge of metalic aftertaste. nothing outstanding here. meh.

Goose Island Honker’s Ale is a pleasant ale, but nothing outstanding. No aroma detected. Amber pour was topped with a decent head. Honker’s was well-balanced but not particularly a standout. Finish was clean on the palate. Honkers Ale is a decent ale.

On tap at Harry’s. A hazy orange amber color with a thick, creamy, white foam head that retains well. Aroma is citrusy, grapefruit rind, with strong notes of fresh grain. Taste is sweet toasted malts and caramel up front followed by some woody notes and flavors of unsweetened black tea. A good amount of hop bite is present in the finish. Medium bodied and creamy.
Light malty aroma, color is a muddy red. Flavor is nice sweet buttery malt, but it is a little muddy, not to crisp clean or to the point.

Umm. Now that was quite good. Actually better than I thought. Nice old penny copper color. Head didnt hang around long though. Nice balance between the malt and hops. Nice chewy aftertaste-not unpleasant at all. I'll buy it again.

Pours dark copper with a white head. Citrus aromas come through. Mod bitter taste with a better bitter finish.

Aroma is mild yet pleasant with a touch of semi-sweet malts and perhaps a spicing from hops. A real solid smelling beer considering the bitter style. The drink is bland with no real taste other than a minor bitterness of hops whereas the malts are missing altogether.
Purchased at the craft beer section in my local grocery. A nice dark colored ale, smooth, not too bitter, and drinkable. Would try it again.
bottled, at some swanky bar in edinburgh. amber with a thin but lingering off-white head; aroma of toffee and wet metal; light bitterness, some caramel and stone fruit; quite pleasant all in all
It’s a nice bitter with a very obvious bitter nose and palate. Very drinkable. Could easily be made into a hoppy session ale
Pours a nice golden amber color with a white head and medium lacing. Very little aroma, just a bit of an apple scent and a little malt. Flavor is sour more than bitter with a little aftertaste.
Bright golden pour, small head. Malted taste with some caramel. Bitter finish. Medium mouthful. Ok not great.

12oz bottles, Milwaukee bench, Chicago bars. Premeditated sessioner with watery characteristics and bland malts joining a selection of decent UK+US hops. Some caramel/toffee, some spice, far from an advocate for ESB’s in the US.

Bottle from Wal-Mart: Appeared a golden orange hue with slight dusting of sediment while a frothy topping of head rested on top. Aroma is mild yet pleasant with a touch of semi-sweet malts and perhaps a spicing from hops. A real solid smelling beer considering the bitter style. The drink is bland with no real taste other than a minor bitterness of hops whereas the malts are missing altogether.
Clear amber with a white head. Fruit and herbal hops on the nose. A bit fruity. This is a drinkable beer.

A good pizza or sandwich beer. It is a really balanced flavor staying lean on the hops (bitter flavors). The smell is very light almost not there so don’t smell this one too long looking for hidden scents. The taste is smooth and fresh in your mouth, the liquid is feels soft almost not very carbonated. Overall this is beer is a standard to follow when you want something simple, pleasing, and drinkable. I would drink this in every season but winter.
Delightfully malty. Very well-balanced. Not especially hoppy, but still pleasantly bitter.

330ml bottle from K-Citymarket Sello, Espoo



BBE 29.06.2013 - Pours cler golden orange with a small head. Aroma of bready malts, caramel, toffee and hints of hops. Taste is sweet, caramely and malty with hints of toffee and vanilla. Finish is sweet and fruity with hints of hops. A bit unbalanced, quite sweet and malty for a bitter.

On tap in Miami. Amber color with a white head. Aromas of fruit, spice and malt. Slightly more bitter than an amber ale, but close. OK beer.

Refrigerated 12 oz. brown bottle poured into an English pint glass. Pours clear medium amber with small off-white head. Aroma is nice light herbal hops, medium/light body, low carbonation, and medium/thick small bubble lacing. Taste is caramel malt with balancing hops and hint of pine. Pretty good for the style.

Pours clear light amber with an off-white head. A finger. Aroma is fruit and spices. Some berry and apple. Taste is a pairing of bready malt with fruity notes and slightly bitter hops. Finishes much the same. A little bit thin and unbalanced but a quite decent offering.

Bottle. Pours deep clear amber with a white foamy head. Aroma of pepper, fruits, caramel, and bread. Decent malty ESB taste, but surprisingly watery.

Bottled. Had many times and can’t believe I’ve not rated it. Pours a clear amber color with a medium sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have caramel, toasted malt, grass, mild fruity hops and light florals. Decent enough for what it is.

Pours clear orange/amber with a thin tan head. Nose is grapefruit, apricot, caramel, a touch of smoke. Neutral flavor, not sweet, with mild bitterness. Rather watery mouthfeel. Faint smoky aftertaste. There is a slight astringency. Not a bad session.

Draft at Pony with Linh. Pours a light amber body. Aroma is light hop, some grass, tons of malt and caramel. Mouthfeel is medium to thin with nice carbonation and notes of vague hop, muted citrus fruit, grass, and a ton of caramel malt.

4 month old 12 ounce bottle. Poured into an English Pint. Pours a translucent copper with a big white head of foam. The aroma is floral and a bit piny. A light malt sweetness creeps into the picture as well. The taste is fairly sweet with a dryness about midway through the sip and finishes with a bread profile. Of the bitters I’ve been trying of late, this one is superior to them all. Very sessionable while remaining flavorful enough to maintain my interest.
Pours medium copper with a thin lasting head. Very slight malt aroma. Flavor is well balanced with very little aftertaste. Somewhat tame but quite easy to drink.
Copper amber color and beige head. Aroma up front is crystal malt and some grassy/ fruity hops. Flavor is more malt forward with some delicate hops lending a hand to balance. Very good beer.
Amber color with a white head. This is fruity and malty. A nice beer for the style.

The only craft selection on tap at a non descript restaurant in Sturbridge MA.
20 ounces come to the table a clear amber color with a smallish off white head. Smells of toffee and caramel with a hint of chocolate and a bit of earthy woody hops. Nothing horribly complex, but a nice clean flavorful easy drinking ale.
had this on draft. Good flavor and easy to drink. Mildly sweet with a touch of bitterness in the finish. The best beer available among a bunch of Bud and Miller products.

On tap. Pours a clear copper color with a thin white head. Aroma is malty with a hint of fruitiness. Tastes is also very malty, with some caramel sweetness, and bit of citrus bitterness in the after taste.

I really enjoyed this one, even though it’s quite easy and simple. Gentle IPA-character, some yeast and fruits/citrus in the aroma. Well-balanced and the taste is softly bitter. Good!

12 oz. bottle. Pours a light golden brown with a thick, dense, off-white head that dissipates slowly. Aromas of caramel, citrus, and dough. Taste starts out slightly sweet and then follows up with light bitterness. Medium-bodied with a smooth texture. Average carbonation with a long, light-bitter finish. It doesn’t have any outstanding characteristics, but it’s fairly solid across the board. Overall, I would say this is a perfectly fine beer that I would happily purchase again.

I often surmise that if the American Pale Ale was considered the hoppiest version of the British Ale family the world would be a better place. More people would be drinking bitters and English PAs and the scourge of the earth known as the India Pale Ale would’ve never emerged from its hoppy hell.

As Goose Island’s description says, this is a balanced beer. Unfortunately everything was balanced towards the bland direction. Decent to look at, but a snooze to drink. Mouthfeel was a particular letdown, seemed very watery.

from bottle. enjoyed 3 6 packs thus far. pours a medium amber. modest white head. mild caramel malt and just enough bitterness. Being a Newcastle fan, I prefer lightly hopped ales. it’s a nice bitter standard bitter, if not on the slightly watery side. Made it very drinkable in Florida Summer.

Aroma is bready, but it’s not a very aromatic beer. Amber colored with a medium off-white head. Not very bitter for a Bitter. The flavor is heavy on bread & toast, with some holiday spices - this would actually make a decent winter seasonal. Some crisp hop notes, but it’s more of a malt-focused brew. Fairly light-bodied, and the flavor fades pretty quickly.

Appearance-- pours a cream colored 1/2" head that recedes slowly leaving decent lacing. Color is amber/copper and mostly clear with abundant carbonation bubbles streaming.

Aroma-- very malty -- smells of slight cinnamon and a moist dough, such as a warm muffin from the oven, a peppery hop spice is also evident.

Mouthfeel-- mostly light, watery, and refreshing. Has a somewhat lager like mouthfeel with a dry finish, although there is some of the fluffiness which should be present in the English Bitter style.

Flavor-- well balanced, hops are in the background and subservient to the malt. Flavors include a peppery and earthy hop spice, a rich bready malt (again like a fresh warm muffin, or a fresh whole wheat bread). There is some caramel and just a hint of cinnamon. This beer is not overly sweet and the aftertaste has a lingering citrus rind bitterness.
A very approachable Bitter, glad to see Honker’s now available locally - love the combination and balance of light hoppy flavors mixed with near amber malts.

A great beer! Has with fish and chips at an awesome classic Irish pub! Great flavor nice and just a proper ale...

Weak beer. Watery very slight bitter. Not very smooth. Don't taste much in hops or malt

Beer appearance is redish brown with minimal head. Light malt flavor with cherry citius flavor.

I must be losing my mind. I assumed this was a red ale... because this comes in a bottle with a red label. When it poured into my glass it looked really light in color. I thought to myself, "well, this is a horrible looking red ale." Still, thinking it was a red ale, I did, regardless of its color, smell some wonderful, rich, fruity caramel aromas that impressed me. And then I learned that this was an English bitter. Boy, do I feel stupid. Still, its sweet, full nose stood out to me, even thinking it was a red.

Very clear, like a sheet of glass-like amber, this beer has a very airy head and no head retention. Its sweetness is very English-like, with a fruitiness that almost reminds me of a winter warmer or fruitcake. It’s wicked good in the mouth: clean, balanced, and with a big fruit factor that is very well-balanced with malts and hops (still with the fruitiness defining the beer for me). It’s like a light winter warmer. As slippery in the mouth as it is on the nose, it goes down way too easy, tickling my sweet tooth with each sip. This may be one of the best sub-4.5% ABV beers I’ve ever had. Not bad! Very sessionable, and full-palated for such a light beer. Tons of residual sweetness somehow works out here.
Pours a rich amber color with a medium head. Mild bitterness, with some tasty fruit and bread notes. A good beer.

Amber brew with the smell of mostly malts. Taste is that of caramel malts with a hint of hops. Overall a good brew but without something to really catch my interest can’t say it would be something I will be looking for at the store.
Aroma of malt and hops. Pours with a one finger head and tastes of malt and coffee with a little bitterness. Good for something that’s getting shipped all over now.
Brown side of gold cloudiness. Aroma is hues of citrus. Not particularly pungent. Flavour is non descript with slight dry bitter finish. Foam head off white. Un complex beer, a bit disappointing.

Une petite bouteille.  Une mousse nonchalante qui flotte sur un liquide scintillant et ambré. Un nez qui est plaisant avec ses notes maltées grillées, son caramel, ses effets fruités vagues et ses houblons en feuille de thé. Un goût qui facilement aimable avec ses notes grillées et ses houblons aux allures américaines et anglaises. Une bouche légère qui se fait traverser par des bulles actives. Une texture légèrement huileuse. Une finale plutôt sèche, assez courte et peu intense en amertume citronnée.
Bottle at Janoinen Lohi, Helsinki. Originally rated 19082011. Colour is clear amber with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Bitterness, sweetness, hops and malts.

I had this on draft at Brighton Music Hall in Boston at a Stranglers concert. The beer was not as good as the show. It was a dark amber color with little head. Pours clear apricot color with medium head. Aroma is malts, hops, dried fruits. Some butter. Flavot is malty with hops and fruits. Nice beer! I think that this goes well with grilled sausage.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Beer and Beyond store. Thanks Tom. Pours yellow to bronze with a small head, aroma of caramel, honey, butter cookies, flavor of caramel, dark bread, bizarre bitterness, medium bodied
Decent beer..enjoy the balance a good beer... found this at a hockey game once.., good sipping beer.

Pretty good, but now part of "And how’s her bush", so there is reason for skepticism about how this will all flesh-out. Watch how it will all of a sudden start hogging shelf space, now that AB owns it. It is all about shelf space and distributors in the liquor business.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Beer and Beyond store. Thanks Tom. Clear dark gold with white head. Sweet and a little malty aroma, mild bitterness in the mouth. Light body, abrupt finish, a little malty.
Okay aroma of classical english ales, biscuit appearence and a palate close to the english bitters. Malty taste which is heavy but delightfull.

12 ounce bottle from Fort Collins, CO was served chilled in a snifter.

Appearance - Poured sparkling clear, dark amber in color, with a fine, creamy bone-colored head.  The head had disappointing retention. Good lacing on the sides of the glass. 

Smell: About equal mix of malts and hops; A bit floral with hints of brown sugar..

Taste: Like a relatively bitter, earthy and hoppy amber ale: i.e., mildly bitter and true to style. Well balanced.  A trace of ripe fruit. 

Mouthfeel: Near medium bodied, with good lively moderate carbonation.  A bit crisp with a semi-dry finish. 

O: Flavorful, interesting and just 4.3% ABV, this is a good session ale.

A decent beer, but not up to the level of other Goose Island Brews. Pours a yellow orange with a white head. Smells and tastes like tropical fruit, but a little boring. Had at bottle rock in napa.

Bottle: amber pour with medium-sized beige head. Aroma is slightly metallic with malt and bisquit notes. Flavor is sweet with malt and honey, with a mild grassy hop bitterness in the middle, and some bready tones throughout. Easy drinking with mild flavors, just a bit much on the malted flavor.

Aromas of nuts, caramel, and orange peel.  Clear orange-amber with a small, fairly lasting, white head.  Dry, bitter, nicely balanced with earthy hops and nutty malt flavors.  Light-medium body, crisp carbonation, and with a clean finish.

How is this an ale? Its more like an amber in color. Aroma is hop-malt mix. 
Smooth finish - drinkable, but I would recommend this beer for fall or winter.

pours a clear copper with a very small off-white head, and good lacing.

smell is of malt, grain, corn, and some caramel.

taste is somewhat chewy, grain, caramel, malt, and a few hops.  ends on the thick side and just a wee bitter.

12 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Pours a very nice looking reddish amber (clear) with a nice white head, OK lacing too. Aroma of grain, malts and yeast quite faint, some fruit in it too. Taste is malty sweet but it also has a nice bitterness to it, hardly any hops; but overall is a very decent drinkable beer.

On draught at the East Village Grille, this pours amber into the glass with a wispy head that leaves thick suds lacing. The nose is somewhat fruity. Flavors are citrusy with some tart cherry, lots of tannins through the mid-palate, and a nice clean bitter to balance. Light-bodied and semi-active in the mouth, it's an easy quaff. English style prevails strongly here.

Smells of cereal and toast.  Pours clear copper with a thin white head.  Taste is somewhat metallic and bland, but finishes with strong malt flavors.

Wow...another I consumed at a picnic and was surprised to see I had not rated it previously...probably had upwards of 4 dozen of these in the past decade plus, as it is a ’upper-middle class’ beer at your standard Chicagoland party...pours a standard amber brown...medium whitish head.  Aroma is bready/biscuity/doughy...some sweet malt, generally bitter.  Flavor is both sweet and bitter...not particularly ’hoppy’ - some caramel notes.  Palate is light-medium and this is an easy drinker with a bitter finish...will this blow your mind?  probably not, but it is a highly sessionable, well-brewed ale.
Overall this was a fairly ordinary ale.  Nothing too special about it.  Drank from the bottle.

Clear amber pour. Cloudy eggshell head with lots of retention and lacing. Aroma is very traditional English ale aroma. Biscuity malt aroma and English yeast aroma. Then becomes more american with earthy floral hop aroma on the back end. Flavor is very similar. Malty, bready, yeasty up front. Hop flavor finish. Very smooth neutral finish.

This beer looks delicious, nice color, taste was ok. I?m not a big fan of English tasting beers though.
Red pour with a thin head.  Some lace.  Aroma of grain and a little sugar.  Mouth is very light.  Taste is sweet. Some caramel and lots of grain. Long grain aftertaste.
Clear amber. Small white head.  Aroma: Citris, wood.  Flavor:  Hops, grass, spices, somewhat thin but very drinkable. Dry, hop finish.

Caught me off guard. Pretty damn good. Nose is sweet. Cinnamon molasses spices. Taste is earthier with a Spicey finish. Deep copper on color. Good.

12oz bottle. Clear amber with a small to medium off white head and some lacing. Aroma of toasty British malt, herbal tea, light citrus and dough. Flavor is more toasty malt and caramel with a mild hop bitterness and light fruity yeast esters. Medium to light body with a soft mouth feel. I remember drinking this on tap in Chicago before I was big into beer, seemed a bit better then but it’s probably that my tastes have changed.
From bottle, sits between the IPA and the wheat offerings which isn’t a compliment.

I usually like bitters, and I was pleased to find a beer I haven’t had a the Durham Bulls stadium, but this wasn’t doing it for me. Pours a clear tea-brown with a thin white head. Nose isn’t much... biscuity malt notes, some toast, mild crisp bitter hops. Taste show more bitter hops, but also quite sweet. Probably will go back to Foothills at the Bulls Stadium next time.
Smells right on point, good English hop and malty aroma.  Good sessionable bitter.  Great representation of the style.  Flavors come together nicely, good lingering hop finish with mild bitterness.

Pours a copper color with a floral aroma.  Taste a slight hoppy.  A very easy drinking beer very nicely balanced for a bitter.  No distinct aftertaste, with a very very slight bitterness after the swallow.  A nice beer for a sunny day.
This beer is barely noticeable. The aroma is non-existent, the color is nothing special, in the taste is average.

Pours a clear deep orange, lots of carbonation, about a finger’s worth of dense off-white foam leaving behind quite a bit of lacing. Aroma is very earthy and bready, with some caramel and a bit of fruit. Taste is biscuity and hoppy, a bit grassy, with a bitter finish. Nice stuff.
Bottle pour.  Great example of a quality bitter that has a hint of fruit hiding underneath it all.
Bottle.  Pours amber red with white head.  Good looking beer.  Fruity notes in the aroma.  Very restrained in flavour and aroma.  Some fruitiness in the flavour and finish

Bread, biscuit, toffee aromas.  Wonderfully clear with a nice toasty thin head.  Toffee with hints of biscuit and grainy/grassy malt, touches of carmel.  Stiff bitterness forms a solid backbone and lingering bitterness with lingering finish.  Nice semi-soft mouthfeel, should be slightly softer.  Overall hits the notes a classic english bitter should, but doesn’t shine in any single area.  Middling.
Poured into a Goose Island branded glass. A medium brown color. Nice soft taste. A touch of hops  but mostly malt.   A little bit of dryness. Easy to sip.

On tap at Johnny’s Pizza. Pours a clear dark amber with a foamy white head. Tons of lacing all the way down the glass. Aroma of pale malts and vomit. Taste is of straw, grain, pale malts, caramel, and bitter hops.  Bitter finish

Notes of swamp grass, dirt, pine, butter, and toast. Definitely some roasted malts in here. To be honest, I’m not very familiar with this style and don’t have much of a reference point in terms of how this is "supposed" to taste. It’s not bad, though. I find it interesting enough. Not really a refreshing beer, and not really a hop or malt bomb. I’m getting a little bit of a taste that a Magic Hat beer in a spring mix pack a few years ago had. There’s maybe just a hint of what you’d get in a Stock Ale, an Irish Red, or an ESB blended together. Also reminds me a tad of some of the Wild Goose (defunct mid-atlantic brewer) beers- similar hops or yeast strain, possibly. Low ABV for an American craft beer, but I think that’s characteristic of English-style bitters.

Bottle. Nice amber pour, with slight head that recedes. Quite hoppy/malt aroma. Pale ale-like hop hit, quite grassy, yet manages to have a very typically smooth English bitter-type finish. Mildly fruity, perhaps a bit of spice? Quite interesting actually and very drinkable too.

Pours reddish amber with great head. Nose has mild malts, some dark fruits, plum, cherries and grapes. Very light in body, with taste of juicy red grapes. A slight bitterness on the finish. Good beer.
Not a big fan of bitter beers. this ale has a very bitter aftertaste with hints of fruit and hops in the finish. It is a decent offering for a bitter but really not my style

First time having this. Bottle form september 12. Smell is yeast and light grain. Flavor is bready, slightly hoppy, with a noticeable english yeast  character. Rubber in the aftertaste. Lighter bodied.

TAste of sweet caramel malts, light soft hops, malty sweet quite syrupy light malts, hint of yeast, just very sweet malts, not much hop, no...this is boring

355ml draft at Don’s Restaurant in Calais, ME. Good looking pour with a clear, deep red/amber colour and moderate creamy, white head that lingered quite a while. I was almost expecting this to be classed as a red rather than a bitter. This was the most flavourful standard bitter I’ve had, maybe ever. I quite liked it.
On tap at Miller’s in Altamonte.  Pretty much the only decent thing they had on tap. Amber color. At least they didn’t pour it in an ice cold glass. It’s actually not bad. Refreshing for it’s ABV.

Enjoyed this on tap at the new @streamsonggolf Streamsong resort in Florida. Faint nose but good look to it, good flavor but I would like it to be stronger and deeper, followed by a body that is way to light. Aroma: Slight maltiness initially. Some frusity esters come out as it warmed as well. Hint of earthy hops. Appearance: Crystal clear pale color, low head but good rentention. Taste: Initial sweetness from the malt gives way to a mild bittering on the tounge. Has a very clean aftertaste. Palate: Very good mouthfeel for the style, clean finish with a nice malty and hoppy aftertaste. Overall impression: A very nice beer, I find it hard to find a good english bitter in the US, but this is a great example of the style.

The appearance was a copper yet transparent body with some amber notes here and there. It had a creamy colored head that disappeared within a couple seconds. It left a foamy ringy lacing. The smell had some light yet sweet malts. The taste is fairly dry and sweet throughout the beer. There is some toasted bread notes in the taste. The palate is about a light to medium. It is slightly crisp and stays carbonated throughout the beer. Overall, this was pretty good, sweeter than most English bitters, but still decent.

Malty aroma has a firm fruity note and a hint of spice. Comes out of the growler a clear tawny brown with a fairly thick pale wheat head. Malty ale has notes of cloves, apple and a hint of nutmeg. Texture, though, is the weakest point, being on the watery side, though it has a good fizz. Maybe this is because I had it from a growler? Still, a worthy brewski.

Tap at Top Hops. Pours a clear golden orange. Head dissipates, moderate lacing. Scent nearly non existent.. light spice. Taste is a bitter.. spice and hops are well balanced. Medium body, moderate carbonation. Refreshing but not my one of my favorite styles.

an english bitter, huh? yeah i guess i can see that. a nice light balanced ale, decent level of hop to malt flavors, easily redrinkable. not super exciting, but solid, and if this gets the distribution i imagine it will from InBev, it will make a welcome alternative to shit bars that only sell AB products otherwise. id take this over Bud or Shit Top any day.
Really weak session ale. In Goose Island tradition made for mass consumptionbut still decent. Deffinately not a beer geek beer. Barely bitter. I am thinking the English would love this.

Bottle->mug.  Cloudy amber with light head.  Aroma is mainly malt and some roast.  Taste has some hops with the malt.  Slight bitterness.  Pleasant.

Poured from a regular bottle into a trumpet glass to drink.  The beer had a semi-cloudy full amber color with a good-sized foamy white head with good retention, lots of cling, and good lacing.  The aroma featured citrus and grapefruit, with some floral touches, and light spices and sugar, with a touch of yeast.  Its taste was wet and sour with a fruity body, and was exceptionally bitter, with floral and yeast touches.  The body was wet and full, and a bit watery and thin, with low-to-average carbonation and life.

Slightly hazy amber beer, small white head. Mild creamy malt nose. Dry crispy palate. Minerally creamy malt, dry and slightly lagerish. Dry finish. Bland.
