l, orange, amber, lightly bitter, light body, lively, bitter, delicious compliment to buffalo wings

Copper colored pour with a tall off-white head. Nose is bread, toffee, toast, and herbal hops. Floral and grassy notes, some hints of caramel, and very subtle citrus peel. Tastes mostly of toasted bread with some caramel and toffee notes, too. Decent sweetness with only a mild herbal and pine hop bitterness. Light grass and floral hops, maybe a bit of citrus, too.
I tried this for the first time in Chicago O’Hare on my first flight to Europe.  This was a better bitter than any I tried over there.  Mild, easily drinkable, grassy hops, and a light caramel body.
Very hoppy, a delicious pale ale. I have never had this prior to the AB purchase, but it is wonderful and I don’t see what people are so worried about.

Bottle at home.
Clear amber wiith a medium white head, nice lacings. Aroma medium+ hoppy, medium malty (caramel). Flavor medium sweet and bitter, long lasting. Medium body. Nice.

16 ounce pint - $5.25 at Taco Mac in Kennesaw, Georgia.



Appearance: Served up a rich, copper-colored body with a half-inch of smooth, off-white foam. Good lacing, too.



Smell: Pale maltiness with a notable note of toast. Additionally, some fruitiness, herbal hops, and some implied sweetness in the taste.



Taste: Pale malts, then, a light toastiness joined with a crust of caramelized sugars for a touch of sweetness. Some fruitiness present giving off a bit of dehydrated apple and even, maybe, a little bergamot. Herbal, spicy hops with ample bitterness. Leisurely drying, light finish with a carry over of some of the bitterness.



Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. Medium carbonation.



Overall: A likable, refreshing little ale.

Murky copper beer with an off-white head. Aromas of toffee, and caramel emanate from the glass. Tastes of toffee, caramel, some prunes, tart fruit, and an underlying sourness that works out quite well. Biscuity malt in the dark fruit finish. Not the typical bitter, but smooth, and enjoyable.

Good dark copper color. Nice lacing though the head does not hold up. Perfumy floral, bread and candied malt nose. Taste is flowery sweet biscuit and some mild light fruit. It’s definitely not an offensive attempt at a real English bitter. Wish I could have tasted this brew in the 90’s.

On tap a Taco Mac. Copper color, with a medium, tan head and absurd amounts of lacing. Notes of white bread, tangerines, earthy hops, and some coriander. Mild bitterness up front and a little sweetness throughout. Medium body, crisp, and lightly acidic. Overall, this is a solid, drinkable, and unique beer.

Pours amber with a thick white head. Aroma of heavy caramel malt and piney hops. Taste follows, just a slightly hoppy ESB. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Fermentation. Light brown pour with a bubbly white head with decent lacing. Aroma of nutty English malts, light toffee and earthy hoppiness. Light sweetness in flavor with more nuttiness, toffee and earthy hops. Medium light bodied and a nice drinker.
Pours cooper with a white head.  Fruity aroma.  The flavor is sweet and malty with a fruity spiciness.  Semi-sweet finish.  Light body with medium carbonation.
Pours light amber with a thick off-white head. Aroma is "pilsnerish" & sweet. Taste is slightly hoppy up front followed by a black pepper bite mellow malts. Not bad & sessionable.

Pours a clear amber with a medium white head.  Aroma has light caramel and tea...bread.  flavor has some toffee and dry leaves...a bit of a biscuity note...nice earthy hop character late.  Mouthfeel is medium and the finish is earthy/hoppy and dry.
Orange amber in color with minimal head and little aroma.  Nice malty flavor with a smooth finish.

Bottle to sampler cup.  Poured a darker yellow with medium head.  This supposedly had more IBUs than the "mild winter" but I couldn’t tell.  Seemed more mellow to me.  It was alright, but another "meh"
Bottle from the Goose Island pub at Chicago O’Hare. A golden brown colour, with standard US gas. Poured with not much head.

Pours dark orange with a creamy white head. Flavor is berry fruit an a little punch of orange. Caramel malt body. Light hop aroma and flavor. Bit of grassy hay hops in the aroma. Finish is a decent bitter. Decent seasionable beer.

Very german- ish smell , pours clear amber small fading foam , 
Light mouthfeel , somewhat this typical ferman taste again . I do not love that ,  but this is drinkable . Bottle says best before 21-1-2011 so prob tasted better before that . I taste no hops in this, at all
Tap at Beer Study. Dark orange amber with a small to medium sized off white head.  Nose is metal, buscuit, toasty malt, earthy hops.  Flavor is similar, well balanced, a tad grainy and cereal like.

Deep brown pour, low carbontaion, aroma of caramel malts with a bit of citrus zest, quite well balanced, a nice beer, a decent interpretation of a UK bitter, cask conditioned in a nice country pub it would be a fine session beer

Had from a bottle at McGrady’s Irish Pub in Charlottesville. Pours a rich dark orange/copper with an inch of slightly off white head. Aroma is some sweet caramel, a touch of grain and a bit of spice. Taste wise, mostly caramel to the exclusion of anything else, perhaps a trace of hop bite in the very beginning but otherwise pure sweet caramel. Medium bodied. Simply too sweet for an authentic English bitter, lacking the dry, clean crisp finish of something like Young’s Bitter. Inspired by English ales? Perhaps. Living up to them? Nope.

12 ounce bottle.  Pours a nice amber with a two inch beige head that slowly fades.  Taste is of malt, hops, citrus, pine and some resin.  Similar aroma.  Has a nice fully body with a slightly bitter finish.  Lots of flavor at a lower alcohol content.  A nice beer that is worth taking the time to enjoy.

Bottle from Connollys Wines, Solihull.  Poured a cloudy orange toffee colour with a thin white head.  The aroma is rich and fruity.  The flavour is rich, malty and with peppery dryness on the palate.  The initial flavour is OK, but the lingering taste isn’t so good.  The occasional bottle is fine, but it’s not a beer that I could drink more than one bottle of during an evening.

12 oz bottle.

Wow, this was a pleasant surprise.
Copper hue, lacey medium head. Citrus hops with malty notes make it bitter but quite bearable.

Draft at World of Beer (Land O Lakes). Pours a clear amber color with a medium packed beige foam head.  Aroma is fairly mild with some sweetness.  Flavor is mild, caramel malt sweetness up front followed by a nice balance of hop bitterness.  Very easy drinking.

355ml bottle - a thin white head on a pale brown body. A sweet nose, malts, bread, mild caramel. Taste is quite buttery, cream, popcorn, sweet again, mild hops. Very pleasant body, but if this is inspired by an English pub bitter, GI are trying too hard. Very complex, enjoyable, but not very British.
Pours a clean soft copper amber with one finger of sudsy off white head.  Nose is malty/bready with herbal hop notes and a lite sweetness.  Moderate bitterness and light bodied.  Easy going.
Light in color for an English ale, weak nose. Both are indications of what is to come:  nothing. A tasteless, low alcohol waste of money. Buy Bud Light instead.

Appearance - Golden, white creamy foam.
Aroma - light malt and citrus
Taste - malt, iron and light bitterness in the aftertaste
Palate - light/medium body high carbon

This is another one of my favorite mass produce beers.  It is a full bodies ale with great color an flavor.   One of the better ales you can buy and I would recommend to anyone. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap @ Proof.  Toasty, caramel, bread, earthy, citrus.  Drinkable.  Ok, but nothing to write home about.

Pours a hazy copper color on tap with thin, off-white head and moderate lacing. Aroma of pale malts, german barley, and roasted notes. Taste is similar, lots of nice roasted munich malts, slight chocolate notes. Good, easy to drink.

Very mild English pub ale. Great flavor and excellent balance. Screw Flanders. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Slight hop haze. Amber in colour and tin persistent head. Good lacing. Initial fruity hop aromas fade to leave more biscuity nose. The flavour is hop driven. Similar hop character to the the IPA, just toned down. Finish is chalky and thin. Perhaps harder water would support the malt flavour and body a bit.

Tap @ Sheraton Bradley Airport: Clear gold with a foamy white head.  It has a wonderful fresh bread aroma with an average thin taste like an ESB.   If the taste was only half as good as the aroma this would be an amazing beer.
Bottle at genos.. red pour ..white head...malty aroma ....kinda just ok.   Sorta plain...
Draft. Medium brown. Decent roasted malt flavor. Smallish off-white head. A little heavy in the bloat factor. Meh.
Good pleasant aroma, light. Looked a medium golden color. Taste was very classic ale, slightly bitter.  Overall i really enjoyed this one.

Pours a deep amber with small frothy white head. Aroma of butterscotch, caramel malt, nuts, fruit. Taste is mildly bitter up front with a subtle bitterness through the finish. Light bodied with a tad too much carbonation for the style.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours hazy amber with a small head that diminishes into a white ring, with good lacing.  Aroma is sweet and fruity.  Taste is nice - only moderately bitter (much less than I expected for a "Bitter" style), but interestingly the bitterness disappears almost instantly - making it a pretty drinkable beer.  A dose of bitterness without the clinging aftertaste.

Thanks to Owen for the beer. Gracias

Orange amber color with a one finger off white head. Good staying power and body to the head before finally falling to a thick foam. Good ringed lacing with this. 

Nose is soft but that is OK. Slight bits of orange and grapefruit with a decent caramel backbone to support this. 

taste is caramel, bread and orange. Just enough hop bitterness to make this interesting but the malt body is quite nice. Slight bits of metal here and there but nothing too awful. 

Creamy body and quite delicate. Ample carbonation to help break the thinness in this.   Bit of a long lasting metallic orange though. 

Decent session beer

Bottle @ Monks CafÈ Wallingatan. Pours tiny hazy amber with a frothy offwhite head that leaves both lacing and trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is sweet and malty with sweet dark bread, pine, orange peal, overripe apples, caramel and hints of moist compost. Taste is slightly sweet and tiny malty with sweet dark bread, red apples, orange peal, pine, resinous wood and hints of wet leaves. Mouthfeel is tiny round, slightly crisp, watery and light bodied. Finish is slightly sweet and bitter with bread, red apples, pine and moist grass.
Very good beer. I like almost all the beers by goose island. Not a stout fan, so this is very yummy!

Poured from a bottle into a plastic cup at Comiskey Park. 

A: Pours a copper color with a fluffy, yellowish head that had some good retention and melts down to little pillow across the top of the drink. Good lace down. 

S: Smells cracker and toffee malts with a citrus hop profile. 

T: Much like the nose, but more emphasis towards the bitter side. Bready and cracker-like malts with a bitter citrus hop punch at the end. 

M: Medium to light bodied with smooth texture and good drinkability. 

O: A very decent brew. Great to be able to drink something like this a baseball game. The $7.50 price tag wasn’t all the appealing though.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-15-2011

Hazy goldish amber with a thin quick disappearing light lacy white sticky head. Soft smell of fruit - peach, malt and light caramel and very hoppy. Medium oily body with soft carbonation. Medium bitter-sweet start with a hoppy citrus orange overly dry finish.Smells like a bitter but overall doesn’t taste like it. Seems like its moving closer to an IPA or APA. Seems like a weird bitter to me. Nonetheless enjoyable.

Draft at a concert so served in a plastic cup.  Amber color with minimal white head.  Aroma of caramel malts and some very light citrus hops.  Taste is light with a nice mix between malty and hoppy.  Palate is light also.  Decent, certainly better then the big-3 macrobrews there.

Bottle. Pours dark orange with a soapy white head that fades. Aroma is English malt and some caramel with faint earthy muted hops. Taste is malt forward with some earthy spiced hops. Palate is thin to medium and has a chalky dry finish. Pretty straight forward with nothing out of the ordinary.
Amber in color... Minimal aroma, flavor is mostly caramel malts, not much of a hop presence in this beer, would not say it is very well balanced...Pretty disappointed.

Bottle at Monks Wallingatan, Stockholm. Amber/copper beer with a quite nice offwhite head. Malty aroma, hoppy floral, caramel, fruity, citrus, some hay and cream. Creamy flavor, hay, floral, fruity, pine, lemongrass, some caramel.

Bottled at Monks Wallingatan
Clear amber with a large head. 
Sweet maltiness with red berries. 
Red berries and very sweet toffee in the flavour.

If I was ever found out... hmm... life would be so different. There’s 3 majors, how it all carries on I don’t know - if none of it was there then I guess things would be simpler. This is a simple beer, helping provide quiet reflection, if only there was someone sitting opposite me right now I could clink my glass with.
Kolaarom med lagom beska, kanske något klen i eftersmaken. Ett bra försök att imitera engelsk ESB/Bitter utan påträngande amerikask humleprofil.
Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; pours copper brown with a small beige head, malty taste with bitter end. Middle of the road.

12oz bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy honey colour, with a light tan head.  Some nice malt notes up front, with some light pine/tropical fruit hops.  The taste is a little watery with dusty, biscuity malts, heavy minerality, and some light resinous metallic hops in the finish.  Reminds me of a much lighter Mill Street Tankhouse Ale.
Draft to pint (from notes). Looks decent; copper with off-white head. Smells and tastes alright; hoppy and malty. Average on the palate. Not very complex, but easy to drink.
20oz on tap.  Hazy copper color, modest stable head.  Medium-crisp for a "bitter".  Good lacing, light mouthfeel & body.  Good carbonation.  Easy to drink, good standby, this has wide distribution.
Copper hue, lacey medium head. Citrus hops with malty notes make it bitter but bearable. Found on tap at The Hornets Nest in Browns Mills, NJ.

Chicago airport United Lounge. Open bar is Bud Light and Honker’s--had to try one of these. I’ve had a bunch of Goose, mainly their big-bottle stuff, but also some of the brewpub fare, in addition to Green Line and of course 312. This is definitely my favorite after Matilda. Just a really great, balanced beer where you can taste everything. This would make a perfect "gateway" craft beer for the uninitiated. Pour from tap into small weizen glass. Deep amber color with a nice head that laces well. Flavor has a great earthy quality. Sweet and bitter are really in harmony here, and this beer is total sessionable flavor.
pretty good beer, nice mild very drinkable easy going beer as is everything from england.
Dark amber ale with a caremal malt flavor. Roasty malt flavor lingers. Not very hoppy at all, but a nice dark ale.

@ Basunen: mycket brödig doft. Ganska maltig. Ganska lätt smak med tydlig malt, en lätt kolaton och en svag gräslig smak. Helt ok men inte någon större grej

Judging by the score this Goose Island beer received...you will be pleasantly surprised with the product.  A bit of an acidic taste but this is a good ale.

Wonderful crisp and refreshing citrus ale with a nice bite to it. Great deal for the quality.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap. Copper color pour with a foamy one finger off white head that fades and leaves a trace of lace behind. Slightly metallic aroma. Taste is watery up front followed by a hint of lightly roasted malt and balancing hop bitterness. A little fruity as it warms but way too thin for me to make it a regular pour. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. A slightly Hazy amber beer with an OK off white head. The aroma is sweet caramel, toasted white bread, with some restrained sweet fruity hop notes of peach and abricots. The flavor is malty sweet with dusty, light earthy and citrusy hops leading to a medium finish. Light body, smooth texture. Ok and easy to drink.

Crystal clear and golden orange hued, the beer has a thick inch of white head that leaves numerous ringlets of caked on lacing. The aroma is pretty weak, with faint scents of malt, hops, and lightly toasted bread. The flavor is decent and well balanced. The finish brings a fair amount of bitterness. The feel is medium bodied, more robust than I would have expected from a session ale. Overall, a drinkable brew and worth trying.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 04-21-2011

Nose smells similar to old English ales with a hops/ malt/ tea smell. Has a medium sized head and is very smooth with a balance of malt and hops with a hint of herbals (tea maybe) in the taste. Overall a very good beer.
Pours a bronze color. Smell is of malts, some hops. Taste is malts up front, some hop bitterness at the finish. Overall a pretty good beer.
Nice thick white head.  Dark orange in color.  NIce malty beginning.  Hints of fruit with mild hop overtones.  Smooth with a clean finish.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Wegmans Leesburg.  It pours a hazy, ruddy amber with a decent off white head.  The nose has a touch of caramel, dough, and biscuit.  The flavor features a touch of sweet malt, light toast notes, and an ever so slight bitterness.  The malt is clearly the highlight of this easy drinking brew. Light to medium body with average carbonation and a medium to short finish.  I wouldn’t mind a touch more flavor, but easily sessionable.
I enjoyed the taste of this. It was smooth and had hints of bright flavors. Aroma and appearance were both lacking but still a good overall beer.

A copper orange pour with a medium white head. Aroma and Taste of caramel malt, yeast, some grassy and citrus notes, with mild bitter notes.  A medium bodied brew with mild carbonation on the palate. Finish is light toasted caramel malt, yeast, grassy citrus notes with some mild bitterness on the end. Overall a nice mellow brew.
Malty ale with hints of caramel and light citrus. Finishes with a nice lingering grapefruit and sweet malt.
12 oz bottle pours clear amber. Hints of citrus and slightly malty. Not very bitter and relatively refreshing and easy to drink.

21-JUL-2012, bottle @home, from "Fish&Beer", present from Minitøserne. 
Slightly hazy amber with off-white head. 
Fruity malty aroma with bread and orange. 
Taste is very fruity malty. Overripe fruits like apples and apricots. Finish a little hoppy bitter. Sweet with medium body and carbonation.

Beer Bloggers Conference 2012 

Amber in color, clear with a thin head.  Nice bitter aroma and flavor.  This was very much like a great bitter.  Very tasty and easy drinking.

12 oz bottle tasted about six months from the bottling date. It pours a nice orange/copper color with a nice off white head. The aroma is huge on EKG hops with some caramel and toffee for a good balance. The flavor is kind of fizzy and a bit watery with big flavors of caramel and toffee and a subdued herbal/floral hop presence. Some mild fruity esters near the finish. Not a bad bitter, but i prefer these beers on cask.

Amber color with thin white head that quickly dissipates. Slight fruitiness in the aroma, but mostly malts.  Didn’t find this to be very balanced as the description suggests, more so on the malt side.  For a "bitter" I do not think it was a very good.
Bottle. Golden amber with head that fades to a ring. Floral hop aroma with some light Christmas spices and toffee. Taste of caramel and toffee with floral hops. Balanced palate. Not bad

The aroma is malty and slightly nutty with grassy hops. The appearance is amber/copper with a medium head. The taste is like the aroma with a slightly toasted finish. The palate is average. Overall a decent bitter but watery.
Pale copper with an off-white head a a fruity aroma.  Slight fruit flavor with caramel and balancing hops.
Had this one at a bar in Aalborg, Denmark. Aroma of grass, cereal and nuts. The taste is the same, but also a clear note of raisins and some vanilla maybe. Easy to drink and quite enjoyable.

Reddish gold; moderate rapidly diminishing head; the ’rich malt’ in the commercial description is the defining characteristic; slightly sweet with some background fruit; a light hop bitterness develops; smooth, easy drinking and well-balanced; it gave a sense of warmth unusual for a relatively low abv beer; very decent.
Floral aroma.  Medium copper.  Fizzy.  Thick head.  Small body accents the bitterness well.  I like it as a session beer.
Bottle 33cl. Amber, clear with a min offwhite head. A hoppy nose with some caramel sence. Light bitter with a caramel end. Watery

Better taste than aroma but still there are plenty supperior ales of the same style out there. The palete is standing between american and english ale without reaching any of those. Will drink it again though

Had with my father in Holden. Great flavor and taste. Had in a bottle with some Mexican food. Great taste and finish.

(bottle).  A very mild aroma of hop after the pour and malt thereafter.  Appearance is medium amber with lacing.  The flavor is a watery malt with thin palate.  Not bad for a ball game.   

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Off the tap into a pint glass. Copper color, big bubbles in the half inch head.

Smell: Fruity, citrus. Nice.

Bitter! A good bitterness though. Grapefruit and other citrus flavors.

Light body, crisp, moderate carbonation.

A solid ale. I did not find it to be in the style of an English Bitter, but it was still a good beer.
12 oz bottle.  Pours nice amber with a good size head.  Nice aroma but not overpowering.  It has a good balance and is very refreshing and drinkable.

On draft into a pilsner glass at Buffalo Wild Wings.  Pours a dark brown with some reddish tones to it.  2cm of off-white head with some small runs of lacing on the glass.  The nose is almost all biscuit and caramel malt smells, a little touch of roastiness.  There is a quiet floral hop smell as well.  The taste is very malt forward, sweet and rich.  The hops appear, very quietly without a ruckus, as a gentle fruity bitterness.  The mouthfull is middle of the road, fair carbonation.  Overall, a pretty good bitter; sessionable.

12 oz. bottle from Total Wine in Chesapeake, VA.  Dark orange pour with a reddish tint and a foamy off-white head.  Aroma of graham cracker and caramel with hints underlying citrus.  Flavors are well-balanced with light floral and citrus hops upfront and sweet malts on the finish.  I find this style dull overall, but this at least gets it right and is a good representation of a bitter.

On draft at O'Hare.  Little carb creamy white head that lingers apple juice color and apple aromas. Crisp finish with sweet up front. Quaffable.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Great bitter from goose island, memorable use of lighter caramel malts and refreshing palate overall

Delicious!  I love a good slightly sweet malty beer with balanced (not prominent) hops.  This beer is very drinkable and refreshing.  It’s drinkability makes up for it’s low ABV. Easily one of my favorite everyday ales.

Bottle from Stirchley Wines & Spirits, Pershore Road, Birmingham.  Pours headless, mid brown/amber.  Hoppy, fruitcake aroma.  Fizzy mouthfeel - perhaps a little too fizzy for a bitter.  The flavour is pleasant enough - bitter, nutty, fruity, dry, slightly smokey and undeniably drinkable - but the finish is too abrupt and the taste a tad watery.

Excellent offering from the Goose.  There is something about the malt selection that makes this quite drinkable, but with just enough hop profile to make it interesting.  Perhaps one of my favorite low-alcohol offerings.  Glad I finally tried it after passing it up for years.
Pours lovely amber...nice fluffy head....some citrus and caramel on the nose

Pours to orange-copper with a good fluffy head that downsizes to about half a finger length before lingering nicely and leaving good lacing.  Smell is pretty fresh, floral, and citrusy - would hold up well against many APAs.  Taste is milder - clean and vaguely malty.  Good mouthfeel.  This is a great summer beer - very crisp, refreshing, and not heavily bodied or hopped.  Would like a bit more flavor to it personally, but to be fair, it’s in the Bitter style, which is supposed to be milder by default.
Bottle, Pours nice amber with good head. Nice aroma, some hops, fruit and honey. The taste is a nice surprise of great fruity flavor and honey. Somthing i will have a gain.
a nice light aroma with hints of floral and caramel.  a very light flavor with a clean dry finish with a slight hoppiness.  very drinkable

Served in a very long glass at Yard House in Boston MA.  Made it a bit difficult to enjoy the beer, but a funny experience.  Amber in color with good carbonation.  No head...probably because of the glass.  No WOW factor.

Bottle from thedrinkshop.com. Amber color with small beige head. Caramel, toffe, honey in aroma. Taste, starts sweet with honey, but than nice floral bitterness with pines arrived. Bitter finish. Enjoyable beer.

Bottle from Wegman’s Cherry Hill. Pours out a moderate copper color with a small white head. Aroma is sweet biscuity malts, subdued grassy hops, caramel and bread. Taste is caramel malts, biscuit, wet cardboard, light grassy and floral hops.

12 ounce bottle. Nice copper color topped by a fluffy white head. Fragrant spicy hop aroma. Caramel-like malt flavor balances nicely with the subtle hop prescence. This is a smooth flavorful ale that reminds me of Boddington’s or Fuller’s. Nicely done.

12 oz bottle pours a hazy golden orange with lasting white head but hardly any lacing.  Smell is malty with some floral hops.  Aroma is the same with caramel, sugar and perhaps citrus.  Taste is slightly bitter, with a clean finish.  Body is light and carbonation is average. I enjoyed this more the first time I tried it, on tap, a few years ago.  A good but not great beer, which doesn’t begin to compare to some of the great bitters I had the last time I visited England.

Bottle (355ml, The Goat, Glasgow):


Hops on a malt base along with a good summer fruit like smell. There are hints of citrus and a touch of caramel but not a lot of it.


Copper to orange, a small bubbly white head that stays throughout.


Malt base with some fruit hops on top. It is almost like an English IPA with some sweet flavours and a helping of sugar. There is a very light pine taste and touches of citrus.


Medium, smooth but with a slight sticky sweet end that is coupled by some nice bitter notes. Sweet overall & complimented with bitter finish. Easy to drink and refreshing too.



An excellent beer, a lot lighter and more refreshing than I had been expecting. The taste is nice and sweet with a good balance between it and the bitter finish,It wasn’t an overly exciting beer but one that I enjoyed and will probably seek out again.

Honkes ale pours a bright and clear amber color. It has a good size head and is off white in color. Light carbonation. Aroma is malty with pale and crystal malts and light hop aroma. Flavor seems alittle weak. There is thin malts toast and some faint fruity esters at the end.
Medium feel with a bit of a harsh bitter finish.
Drinks pretty nice aside from the harsh finish.
12oz bottle.  Aroma of caramel malts with a little toffee and floral and slightly citrusy hops.  Flavor the same. Average texture.  A decent beer.

April 2007: from BA. Brown 35.5cl bottle, red backed front label, black rear label telling me to drink it before 07-2007, so I did. The rear label also told me to pour it into an imperial pint glass, so I did that too. Bought in Tanner’s, Bridgnorth, Shropshire. 

Almost cloudy, not the sparkling bitter look I was expecting, dull copper in colour, the small white head just vanished before my eyes leaving a wispy floating scum of a covering. 

Malts in the aroma, sweet esters of caramel too. 

Fizzy, it made me burp. Fairly bitter, none of the sweet aroma comes out in the taste, the malts are still there, but not as prominent as they were in the smell. As the beer warmed up, I enjoyed it more and the maltiness re-asserts its self. 

Not a huge mouthfeel from this beer, almost watery, but that would be unfair, there is a lingering metalic feel which I don’t like though. 

Glad I tried it, got to see what you chaps over the pond are drinking haven’t I? This isn’t a typical English Bitter by any stretch of the imagination, but I would like to try it on tap one day, just to see what it’s like served in a bar.
Notes Only.  Rated out of a plastic cup at the Prudential center.  Yum.  Malty, mostly caramel.  Tastes a bit of plastic... wonder why.

On bottle
Golden reddish, good foam
Balanced beer, some hoppy notes
Medium body & complexity
Very enjoyable

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured into my Sam Adams Perfect Pint glass from a 12 ounce bottle bottled on 2-20-2012.



A: Crystal clear amber body with a steady stream of fast moving carbonation rising to met a dense light tan head that leaves a mess on the glass. This beer looks stunning in the glass.



S: Decent aroma here, smells like "beer." Toasted malts, mild floral notes, and light citrus.



T: Mildly sweet caramel, slight toasted malts, and a very slight floral hops. Easy drinking beer, I could drink this all day.



M: Light to medium body with very slightly soft carbonation on the finish with a mild stabbing on the tongue after the beer is gone.



O: This is a great easy drinking summer beer I could drink all day, especially at the ABV. This is how a low ABV beer should be done.
330ml bottle. Amber body with a medium beige head. Aroma of malts,  citrus and flowers. Light malty and flowery taste. Medium body and bitterness.

Dark orange pour with a frothy head.  Pretty nice aroma of citrus hops, pale malt, and some fruitiness.  Taste is very smooth with lots of flavor.  Medium mouthfeel.  Mostly taste the hops when drinking it but still very good.  Highly recommend for a good pale ale.

Tap. Pours amber gold, clear, with a full white lasting head. Aroma is weak, with a little piney hops. Taste is slightly bitter/sweet with caramel malt notes. Clean finish with minimal aftertaste. Not a bad beer.

Originally reviewed: 4/8/10. Poured into a mug. Pours a rusty copper with a thick beige head resting on top. Retains pretty well, but leaves little lace behind. Scents of warm fresh bread, some mild hops, and a bit of a tart citrus twang. 

The body is crisp with a moderate carbonation backing, but still retains a smooth, creamy feel. Great filling bready flavors. Nice bitter backing from a good hop presence. Sweet balance is there, but it’s subtle. Really smooth and clean aftertaste. Wow. I wasn’t sure what to expect from this little offering, but I love it! I wish I had access to this locally. With the low ABV, I could see this being a regular sessioner, no problem.

My wife brought this one back from a trip to Rochester. +++ Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a caramel-orange color with a large foamy orange-white head that left some lacing. The aroma was pine, tropical fruits and was somewhat tart. The flavor was pine, grapefruit, tropical fruits and sugar. Long sugar and fruit finish. Moderately full bodied. Solid.
This is my first bitter, so I have no reference point.  Seems very balanced and the tastes matches the bitter description.
Nice smell. A sweet and rich smell. The taste is strong with not a long aftertaste. Has hints of caramel in it.

33 cl bottle @ home. Pours copper with a large off-white head that slowly fades and leaves quite a bit of lacing. Aroma is fruity and very malty with hints of caramel. Taste is quite subdued – there is a little caramel malt in there but that’s about it.
Bottle. Color amber with small white head. Aroma malt, caramel, fruity. Taste sweet, caramel, orange.
Walnut and leaves aroma, not strong. crystal clear auburn, thin head, fair amount of lacing. Tame dried leaves flavor. White crustless bread finish. Fizzy.

Draught at TJ’s:  Very faint malt and grain aroma.  Poured amber in color with a small, creamy, dense, off-white head that greatly diminished but lasted throughout.  Clear.  Not sparkling.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of malt, hops, grain, and some spice.  Medium body.  Lightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Lightly sweet, lightly bitter, malt, hop, spice finish is lightly dry.
Bottle. Great exmaple of a bitter. It puts the majority of English bitters to shame.

Bottle. Aroma is faint hops with some caramel malt.  Taste is english light caramel malts and a slight fruitiness, with a well balanced finish - not bitter, not sweet.  Quite the head after pouring and nice lacing - with a smooth mouthfeel.  Good example of the style, but not my favorite style

Pours a clear deep amber color with a large white head and decent lacing.  Nose is very fruity along with spicy hops. Taste is crystal malts with citrus hops and a touch of tropical fruit. Light-bodied and easy drinking beer.
Decent- nothing special. Touch of diaceytl on the nose. Nicely balanced flavour-wise. Touch of spice. Carbonation is a bit too vigorous. OK.
This beer i dont need to taste again, Water, barleymalt, wheatmalt, hops and yeast.

Dayton Dragons single-A baseball game. An oasis is the desert. I almost cried. A good beer under normal circumstances, a great one under these. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at the Water Street Tavern.  Pours a dark ruby color with a thick head.  Nice balance of malt and bitterness but there was nothing outstanding about this beer and it was kind of forgetable.  Well made though.

While in Chi-town, I tried this at a local pub.  Not great.  Not bad.  Not mediocre.  It is what it was, and shall be.  It was who I thought it would be, but I let it off the hook.  But I digress.  If there was a table with this stuff, Schlitz and Blatz, I would pound the Blatz, eye the Schlitz and let the ill-educated city folk have at this overpriced swill.  All the while gleaming with VICTORY beaming from my blood shot eyes.  Don’t question it.  Don’t bother.  I’ve been to Milwaukee so I ought to know.
Bottle at Monk’s Café, Sveavägen, Stockholm, Sweden. Very drinkable beer, not all that exciting but refreshing and enjoyable.

I was taken with this bitter-style beer as soon as I released it from its translucent brown limbo. The citrus and powerful hop aroma is something that I love, and something that this beer has in heaps, and is strong and seductive enough to excite you about the coming flavour. In tasting you will not be disappointed as the flavour of the hop is highlighted, with a medium bitterness. The texture is fairly thin but this allows for repeated enjoyment.

A very nice bitter. Dark amber with a small head, the aroma is bread, grain, grass, some earth. The flavor has a bit of roast malt and a nice sweetness up front. Very well balanced and easy to drink. Finish is dry and smooth.

Draft. Served in a standard pint. Transparent yellow color, sizable white head with nice retention. Moderate carbonation. Nose of caramel malt with light hops.  Lighter body. Flavor starts with some hops, turns into sweeter malt, and finish mildly bitter. Simple and easy to drink.

pour from a 12 oz bottle. Amber bre with energetic head. Aroma of spice, fruit, a little vineous. Taste is mild malts with a dry finish, pleasant and drinkable but rather simple. Bottle is out of date so I’ll revisit with a fresh one. Ovaerall, pleasant nice brew.
Copper almost brown appearance, slight to medium head. Slight malty undertones of caramel and toffee. The taste follows closely to the nose. Not bad, but not great.
A nice color, pretty good tasting beer. It’s easy to slam a few back on any given day while still having good beer.

on tap at a subterranean bar in Chicago, Streeters? served in a pitcher with frosted mugs (boo) its a nice amber color and tastes pretty straight forward, true to its description you can slug the crap out of it..

Hazy-to-clear amber pour with a fleeting head, on-tap.  There is a little bit of malt and caramel in the nose, but not too much.  There is a decent balance of malt and hops, a fair balance of sweet and bitter.  There are some citrus notes that are too far away in the background.  I’d try it again, but I’m not going out of my way to.

330ml Bottle.  Pours amber, thin lacing.  Great caramalt aroma and taste... A warm tasty putty palate, the best part of this beer.

I drank this in my bed.
Amber with a small white head. Aroma of hops and malt. Hoppy flavour with some caramel.

Bottle 0,33l.  Amber with a moderate off white head. Fruity, sweet caramel malt aroma. Sweet caramel malt with a light spicy, bitter hops flavor. Medium body.  Happy suprise, above expectations!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Perfectly decent I suppose, but if I want bitter then I’ll buy superior bitter in Britain (as that is where I live).
Light and crisp, this is a great beer for a hot day. It’s satisfying and an easy drink.

On tap pours amber with a off white head.  Aroma of hops and roasted malt.   Taste is hops, yeast and a little malt.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Fruity, sweet caramel malt aroma. Amber with a moderate off white head. Sweet caramel malt with a light spicy, bitter hops flavor. Medium body.

From bottle (2 months over best before date). Slighty cloudy with a small white head. Aroma and taste of caramell. Very good balance. Easy to drink. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
amber color with a thin ring of white head. The taste is good with a decent amount of bitterness with a nice malt aftertaste. Fairly light  bodied.

Clear Dark Orange with a bunch of carbonation going on. Flavor consists of bread, yeasts and slight floral hops, not very complex but it tastes awesome. Feels nice and crisp on the palate. It’s a good beer to drink for any occasion, and sort of like the description says: You’ll look forward it to time and again!

This is a great session beer.  Beautiful and aromatic with hops on the nose but not too much.  It’s got a fruity aroma steeped in citrus and floral with honey and cereal overtones.  The color is a a bit towards light bronze.  Very cloudy.  The taste is similar to the aroma with a nice balance of hops and malt that leads towards a slightly bitter fruit and medium cereal flavors.

Overall it’s an easy drinking beer that can be enjoyed year round and goes well with lots of foods.
Bottle: Not a bad beer, but not great.  Very easy to find in the midwest, especially when the only other beers are lagers.  Plus for that.

On tap @ Salty’s. Pour is amber with a white head. Aroma shows toffee, orange, hay, and grapefruit. Flavor is somewhat sweet and shows plenty of biscuit and toasted malt underneath fruity citrus hops. Overall body is moderate and the finish is pretty balanced.

Bottle. Deep copper color with a large, white head. Malty nose, plenty of caramel, some red fruits, spun sugar and biscuits. The taste is more caramel maltiness, the sting of the carbonation leaves a little grassy acidity. Medium body, over carbonated in my opinion. Overall, forgettable.
Bottle at Oslo Mekaniske Verksted. Hazy amber colour with an off white head. Caramel, moderate sweet and light citric aroma. Fruity and hoppy flavour with a fine caramel background.
warm, tasted like piss and consumed at a cheap bowling alley in Philly. Disappointing for a brewery of it’s rep.
Gold color, modest white head. Aroma was malt and hops (pine?), and a hint of salt. Flavor was primarily hops, but the malt balanced it very well.  Mouthfeel was light

had on tap at a local watering hole, poured into standard pint glass

a: pale copper color with a silky 1/2" head with nice retention, slgiht carbonation

s: slight malt aroma mixed with citrus

t: soft malt flavor, well balnced with hop and citrus bittermess. Slightly dry malt/biscuit finish

m&d: slightly thin mouthfeel

Coppery color with small white head.  Aroma malt and faint hops in the background.  On the light side of medium body.  Flavor starts with some hops, turns into sweeter malt, and finish more on the drier side.  Not profound but quite decent and drinkable.

From notes.  First reviewed 4/14/2010.  Poured from a bottle into a pint glass.

Honkers Ale pours a dark honey / light brown color, slightly hazy. A 1 inch introductory head fades, but does leave some soft lace down the glass. Sparse bubbles refresh the head from the base of the glass.

The aroma is grainy, almost bready, with a hint of citrus.

Barely sweet roasted malt starts each sip, lemon/grapefruit hops push through, and a dry, slightly oily finish. Pleasing to the palette without overburdening it

Quite crisp and somewhat dry, which I find very pleasant for the composition of the beer. A bit of a light body, unfortunately.

Easily drinkable, and it is easy to see why this is the primary Goose Island offering available on tap around the city. Great for sessions with people who enjoy less intense beers, BBQ’s, etc.

Bottle. Had this Bitter in the past, but never rated it. Pours an amber with nice white head. Aroma is ripe fruit and slight caramel malt. Taste is largely roast malt with a distinct fruit/caramel note. I was surprised how much I liked this one. Very sessionable!!

On tap...Pours an amber color with a frothy white head....taste has a bitter finish with a mix of carmel...you get some carmel aromas, but also some small notes of orchard fruits...not their best offering...wasn’t really my cup of tea

Bottle. Poured a murky copper color, thick off white head, medium lacing. Aromas of bread, caramel, sweet malts, watermelon. Taste is fruity hops, sweet and bready malts, cinnamon. Usually do not care for this style but I really enjoyed this one.
Pours light copper with a slightly off-white head. Mild caramel aroma, low bitterness. Come off as bland and boring, but refreshing.

Nice aroma almost caramel  with something else I couldn’t pick out.  Not much with appearance.  The taste was a combo between sweet and bitter finishing bitter.  Good beer overall maybe more of a summer style....

29-01-12 Bouteille: Ambrée-orangée, limpide et claire, très légère effervescence et mousse abondante et épaisse qui disparait asser rapidement. Arômes fruitée et maltée avec des notes de farine et de fleurs. Légèrement sucrée, sans réelle amertume, bien balancé, fraiche et désaltérante. Crops léger avec une texture mince, mais avec une eptite rondeur en bouche. Carbonisation moyenne et finale maltée et asser courte. Bien gouteuse pour une bière à faible taux d’alcool et différente de la plénitude des big beers américaines.

Looks like a bitter - hazy copper with medium head and lacing. Light malty aroma that’s a tad metallic. Subtly bitter with good balanced finish. Not too dry and easy on the palate. The brewer should be commended for creating a traditional bitter when it is so tempting to Americanize old style with extra hops, spices and ABV. The result is a dangerously sessionable beer.
An old rating not much for notes but I bought a 6 pack and I enjoyed it.  Amber, light bodied, easy on the hops, easy session beer.

A solid ale. Pours a nice hazy orange with about 2 finger worth of bubbly foam. The nose consists of a predominant honey aroma. On the palate some sweet honey with a slightly bitter pine cone after taste. Very drinkable and quite smooth.

From a bottle stamped 0927NH-OCT 18 11, which suggests it comes from their New Hampshire brewery. The pour is medium amber with a small, fading head and pretty good clarity. The aroma is rather muted with average malts and clean hops but overall rather subtle. The creamy body is about medium.  The taste is pleasantly bitter, bready, and clean to the finish.

~Bready biscuity aroma with raisin like fruitiness. Low spicy hops.
~Pours a hazy light orange color with small creamy white head.
~Slightly bitter taste, spicy hop, light bready malts. Very non offensive.
~Med light body, med high CO2, Very dry,  mild bitter finish.
~I really enjoyed the english fruity character in the aroma. The flavor is lacking. Still an enjoyable brew that I could drink plenty of. Probably be a little bitter at cellar temp and less C02.
Bottle; clear amber with small white head; aroma-spruce, caramel, citrus; taste-light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, thin feel, lively. Good. Not great.
Amber color. Slightly cloudy. Some bitterness, but altogether not very strong flavors. Hints of apple. Could have been more fullbodied.

Medium amber pour with decent off-white head. Aromas of caramel and fruity hops. Somewhat light body and mouthfeel with moderate carbonation. Initial taste is slighly bitter or sour, but then the caramel and sweetness of malts dominate from there on. Very easy-drinking brew.

This beer pours an attractive light copper with one finger of fluffy white head. Decent retention and mild lacing. The aroma is inviting with notes of light spice and warm toffee. The taste is very good.  Biscuity sweet malt lay down a warm base and the floral hops lend some spice and complexity. The finish is sweet with some nice yeast flavors. Fairly complex for a smaller ale. The body is medium with moderate carbonation. A bit of fizz but mainly creamy. Very easy to drink. Overall I thought this was a very well done bitter. The beer has a nice complexity and invites you to take another sip. Very good stuff, cheers.

A very nice brew indeed.  Great color, nice head, good lacing.  Excellently balanced between caramel and biscuit malt aromas and flavors, with a fruity hops presence.  Superbly drinkable and sessionable.  A staple that I keep going to over and over again.

Aroma is a good balance of amber malt, english hops and a touch of caramel. A little nutty too. Pours amber colour with fair lacing head. Taste is well balanced too, clearly an english style bitter. Getting some slight roasted malt, quite a short aftertaste, slight biscuit note. Pretty enjoyable.

Draft from a flight at Hanger. Pours a clear amber with a small white head. Aroma is mostly citrus hops with a touch of caramel. Taste is light-medium bitter and very lightly sweet. Lots of citrus hops dancing around here. Medium bodied with a somewhat thin texture. Lively carbonation and a decently long, somewhat bitter finish. Overall, not bad. I wouldn’t seek it out but, seeing as how you can find it anywhere, you don’t really have to.
Pours cloudy amber with a decent white head. aroma is fruity and sweet. smooth taste, citrus, floral, and well balanced between sweetness and bitterness, but its a bit thin.

35,5 cl. bottle. Light hazy copper colour with a very thin white head. Aroma of caramel malts and floral hops. The taste is light sweet, mostly malts with hints of fruits, caramel and floral hops. Medium body with an average carbonation.  Finished with a little bit of bitter hops. Very well balanced and easygoing beer. Good performance despite the 4,3 % alcohol.
On tap pours cloudy amber with thin white head.  Aromas of malts and slight oak.  Flavor is smooth with a bit of a heavy lager feel.  Body is medium and has a bitter finish
Dark amber with a white head - good malt aroma with caramel - good malt body with a good fruity hop bitterness in the back that lasts for some time into the finish - good

12 oz bottle into a pint glass. Bottled August 19, 2011.

Pours a hazy dark gold with a decent one finger head. Decent carbonation but not much lacing.

Smell is of citrusy hops along with caramel from the malt.

The taste begins with an odd sourness but this goes away as the beer warms. Very malt-forward with some nice grainy flavors along with a hint of caramel. Hops are restrained although do contribute some flavor and bitterness. Mouthfeel is a tad bit thin.

Overall this is a pretty good sessionable beer although it is not really one of the best english bitters I have had.

Tasted from bottle into standard pint glass. Poured a clear, light amber color with moderate off-white foam. Aromas and flavors fairly true-to-style for an English pub bitter, except slightly watery and metallic. Decent but not great.

Had this one at the Chicago Airport waiting for a connecting flight. Pours a golden-amber colour with an off-white head with a bit of lacing. The aromas are nice and hoppy. Unfortunately, not as tasty as the scent. Kind of watery but with a slight hoppiness. Overall, nicely refreshing for those who like hoppy beers, but not on the bitterness-side. Quite expensive at the airport though.
Bottle. Pours amber, pinkish tinge, pillowy head. Aroma is malts and light fruit. Taste is fruity, some citrus hops, a lingering syrupy finish. A nice brew, very sessionable.

12 oz bottle.  Pours amber with a small white head.  Aroma is of citrus hops, caramel malt and ripe fruit.  Medium, crisp body.  Citrusy, earthy hops, bready malt, caramel and light fruit fill the mouth. Long, dry finish.  Tasty brew that I could drink a lot.
Bottle @ The White Horse, Parsons Green. Hazy dark orange color, small white lacing. Smell sweet, some bitter. Taste bitter, lightly sweet. Not very inspirational, just an average decent beer.
Unfortunately in a bottle.  Nose was a solid floral hop.  A touch of astringency early, quickly replaced by mildly bittering hops.  Mild bitterness lingers.  Moderate carbonation throughout.

Pours a stark golden with a fizzy white head and good lacing.  Aroma is slightly floral, malt and hop.  Taste is a great balance of malt and hop.  A bitter right to style.  Slightly sweet in the aftertaste.  Great everyday beer.

(35 cl bottle from Gammel Strand Øl & Vin) Pours a clear amber with little white head and lace. Aroma is pleasantly herbal hoppy with notes of tea. Full-bodied, oily texture with lively carbonation and a lightly bitter finish. Taste is mildly bitter. A pleasant and very sessionable ale. Girlfriend says: "It’s a bit syrupy."

hops and citrus fruits are noticeable and slightly malty, deep amber colour, very slight haze, nice head, good lacing but not prominent,  certainly bitter, creamy palate with quick bitter finish. Not remarkable but a fairly enjoyable quaff.

English Pint. Poured a burnt orange brown color with thin head and minimal lacing. Smells of hay and dough. Taste?s of bitter and slightly sour hops. Finish?s pretty clean with a decent aftertaste. Not a great beer, too bitter for me.

Draft in a pint glass - pours misty orange with white head and provides lacing. Nose is fruit and hops. Aroma is toasty and a hint of smoke. Taste is sweet and well, bitter. Creamy body and medium to long finish.  A nice discovery in terms of style.  Reminds me of Abita Purple Haze but only lighter.
Amber bitter with spicy tangerine hop aroma, initial fruit and dry malt followed by a pity finish.
Well balanced between sweetness and bitterness, with sweetness coming out on top. A bit thin on the palate. There’s both hops and malts in the aroma. Dark amber colour. (355 ml bottle)
Mildly bitter taste, malty and creamy finish with not much booze to bite you.  Not bad, not great.
Bottle - unable to pour from bottle to look at, malty flavor with a weird thick kind of texture

Clear copper pour with a rapidly fading ivory head.  Very nice malty, toasty, roasty aroma with a hint of raisin.  Malty graham cracker flavor with hints of molasses and a slight sweet aftertaste.  Ah, Honkers Ale.  It’s been a very long time since I had one of these.  Once my standard when I lived in Chicago.  AB-InBev buyout be damned ... these guys will always make great beer.  Cheers to Goose Island!
solid approachable easily accessible bitter. Pours a golden orange nose and taste are of fruity hops and light malts.

1. Look – A clear amber color ale with a nice head.
2. Sniff – There is a very fruity aroma.
3. Sip – A very light bodied ale with lots of fruity flavors with a wet finish.
4. Another Look – The head has dissipated, but has good lacing.
5. Evaluate - Overall, Honker’s ale is a very easy drinking English-Style Bitter.  It has a very fruity aroma and flavor.  I would recommend to Pale Ale fans that are looking for a lighter ale with a light bitterness.
Bottle at the Red Squirrel. Very hoppy on the nose but quite underwhelming flavourwise. Pours nicely with a good head. Disappointing really.

Bottle, pours clear amber with medium off white head... the aroma is caramel, fruits, flowers....the flavor is sweet, caramel, hops and some grape in the finish... medium body.... nice thick mouthfeel...
Bottle. Pours hazy deep golden with a medium off white head. The aroma is fruity hops and caramel. The flavour sweet fruity, grain, caramel and malt. Hoppy finish.

Small bottle. Misty orange body with a creamy, beige, fingerthick head. Citrus, malts and flowers on the nose. Light malty, piny bitter, light acidic flavors. Heavy carbonation. Loght to medium body. Watery texture. Dry tongue.

Draft at GI Clybourn on 8/4/11.  Pours amber.  Very mild aroma.  Some bitterness in taste.  Bready malts.  Good lacing.  Very dry.  Good mouthfeel.  Very solid session beer.  Have had this many times before, but this may be the first time as draft.  Goose Island is always solid and this, their flagship beer, is no exception, however there is nothing here that gets you excited.

Date: September 4, 2011 Mode: Draft Source: Shaker’s, Ottawa, IL Appearance: Light brown, slight amount of head and lacing. Aroma: Malt and hops. Flavor: Consistent with aroma but with some caramel, thin to bodied, slight carbonation and a bitter and slightly watery finish. Other: Decent offering from GI, but would not actively search this out again.
Bottle. Pours amber with a white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, grassy hops. Taste is malt, caramel, nuts, grassy hops. Medium body, soft carbonation. 030911
little head, deep golden brown. Nice malty caramel nose maybee with a little tea? Medium body and length. tea-tasting with some dry caramel,

Bottle. Amber with a low head. Dry caramel malt aroma with grass and earthy hops. Flavor of caramel, though not sweet, dry strawberries, grassy hops, lightly but cleanly bitter finish. Light body. Easy drinking. Nice.
On draft.  Pour was amber with minimal head.  Taste was mild in all aspects with a fruity/floraly hop flavor and light caramel maltiness.  Boring session beer that was decent.
050711: Amber color with a thin white head. The flavor is fine malty and has a good creamy fullness.
This beer is really pretty decent, but still nothing much to it.  I like some more complexity.
It poured a clear copper color with a little white foam. The aroma was of  fruity citrus with mild malts. The flavor was of medium biscuit malt upfront with some fruity malts.
Pours an amber orange color with an off-white foam head.  Has an ESB taste.  Those light and gentle bitters.  Nice sweet caramel flavor.

Pours amber with a small aoffwhite head.  Aroma is florals, grass,citrus and a faint hint if cereal.  Taste us sweet with a acidic fruit aftertaste.  Light and. Easy to drink.  Enjoyed at the Schooner Inn at Ocean Bay Park
Earthy and citrus flavors meet to create a medium bodied very drinkable ale. Bottle in oak bluffs ma

Poured a clear bright copper color with a tall foamy beige head initially. The head reduced to just a film rather quickly. The color of the beer was so nice I still gave it a 4 for appearance even though the head hardly lasted at all. There was a mild caramal malt aroma with a lesser amount of citrus hops and just a hint of an earthy peat scent. There were lots of carbonation bubbles rising up in the glass. The beer has a clean crisp taste and slightly dry. A caramal malt flavor is mild followed by a mild hops bite. The hops lingers into the finish which becomes very mild.
color cobrizo,maltas tostadas en muy poca cantidad equilibran esta cerveza con toques de fruta y lúpulo.bebida en goose island.
Pours amber with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, flower, pine and fruity notes. Flavour is caramel, bread, flower, grass and pine.

Pours a hazy and dark amber beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt and hops with grass and dirt. The flavor follows the nose with additional caramel. The palate is sweetness. Overall an average beer.

Bottle at home.
Dark orange color, white head that would make the beer lokk good if it lasted more than 10 seconds. Still a nice color.
aroma is a bit hoppy, good hoppiness, but not mush else. 
Caramel dominates the taste, joined by abrubt sharp bitterness. It’s not bad, though I’ll admit I was maybe expecting a bit more from it cause of their nicely balanced ipa. Bitterness is decent though, and I guess that’s what they wanted to create since it’s allegedly "inspired by english county pubs".
(Bottle 5/7-2011) Low lasting head, malty taste, mild bitter, light hoppy aroma.

12 oz bottle. Pours light brown with orange highlights with a 1/4" off white head. Slightly sweet caramel malt aroma with light citrus hop scents.  Taste is caramel malt, citrus hop in the aftertaste. Medium body with good carbonation. Very drinkable.
Drink Goose Island Honkers Ale: It’s malty ass shit! Pours dishwater brown from bottle. Not much aroma. Big caramel on the tongue along with a shitload of carbonation. Finishes foamy.

Slight raisin and malt aroma, cloudy orange/copper appearance, nice tan head, very light sweetness, lightly bitter, light fruit, citrus and rich malt flavor, light/medium body, creamy, more carb than traditional bitter, short finish. Solid representation of style, just not my preferred. The flavors become more noticeable as the beer warms to appropriate degree.

355ml bottle, thanks to Finn H for sharing. Unclear, orange coloured body. Faint amount of off-white head. Malt-fruity aroma. Citrus and malts in flavour. Mild ending with dry bitter hops. Half way pleasing (Tromsø, 02.06.2011).

A cloudy amber ale with a thick off-white head.  The aroma has a nice fruitiness backed with a bit of roasted malt scent as well.  The flavor is weighted more toward a nutty malt flavor with a bit of citrus hops taste as well.  The palate is just slightly thin, but a very drinkable brew.
Bottle. Pours clear copper with a small off-white head. Aroma of bready malts and hop. Taste is soft, caramel, moderate sweet with no bitterness at all, quite boring actually.

Süß-würziger, vor allem aber lecker hopfiger Geruch. Herber Antrunk, ein grasiger Ton ist ebenfalls vorhanden. Im Mittelteil ist das Bier etwas wässrig, der würzige Teil entschädigt dafür. Dabei kommt ein malziges Aroma nur kurz zum Tragen, auch im Nachgeschmack spielt es nur eine kleine Rolle, denn hier wird die Würzigkeit verstärkt, am Ende bleibt ein bitteres Aroma hängen. Insgesamt zu mild. 	 
Test vom 18.3.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 7,8,9,8,9,8 - 8,10

Poured into a snifter glass. Was on top floor/bar in the  3rd largest building in Chicago so it only seemed right to go for a Goose Island beer. Nothing really special about this one. Reddish color with a malty-esc aroma/flavor. Beer wasn’t special but given the circumstance it was a great beer.

I have no clue what a "bitter" is.  I’d call this "beer"  it’s pretty well balanced, drinkable, and has a respectable hop kick.  Better than any authentic british beer i’ve had..that stuff all tastes like old bread.  I drank it out of a bottle, so I don’t know what it looks like, but it tastes good.  Very sessionable.

Pours golden brown, with a minimal head. Fairly strong citrus notes with light hay background.  Full bodied, average carbonation, oily texture, astringent finish. Hoppy citrus flavor, with a bitter bite. Flavorful, easy drinking.  Good beer!
Hazy orange with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, karamel and moderate hoppy - peach and grapefruit. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and light bitter finish. 110611

Light orange-brown beer with a medium fine, shallow head. The smell is bitter hoppy, spicy, almost as intense as a good IPA. It starts much more lax then. Hoppy bitter, pleasant citrusy spicy. The further course is very mild, the bitter hops screwed back something. The aftertaste shows citrus-fruity aromas with a pleasant spicy note in background.
Pretty good for an American beer - but then again they did learn a thing or two from Shepheard Neame.

Bottle stumbled upon at local grocery store. Pours a rather brownish golden clear beer, with a minimal head. Fruity, biscuity, caramely aroma with some citrus notes. Great body, almost oily in my mouth. Wonderfully hoppy citrus flavor with some grapefruit, more biscuits and some caramel. Slightly bitter. Great balance, I think, and easy to drink. I wouldn’t mind more than one of these!
This is a great tasting beer with a bit of hoppiness that doesn’t overwhelm the taste of the beer.  Sampled it on tap; am hoping the bottled version is as good.

Always wanted to try a Honkers Ale, now i get too (pre-inbev bottle, if it matters) .. . Pours a light copper, medium head, good lacing .. . Well fuck my ozone .. . light bitterness, pretty smooth- a definite people friendly brew .. . Absolutely, I hear you! We’re saying we’re gonna do the drugs and then we’re gonna try and fix all the lights...

This taste remind me of spl tree fruits and also spray for repelling insect during evening festival of Jeddah in summer months. I am liking much foam getting stuck on my lip like kisses with hot lady in bath full of bubbles. I am think I need to visit Island of many gooses for lots of boosted beer and ale parties of many ppl of fame and fortune.
Clear Amber, not much head.. Bitter smell. Some taste of hops and some sweet malt. Over all well balanced. Better than most beers in Norwegian stores anyway.
Bottle from Selfridges. Pours a hazy gold, with a medium off white head. Quite floral, with citrus, caramel, toffee and a moderate bitter finish. Enjoyable, but nothing to get excited about.

On draft at Clybourn goose island brewpub.  Wow, this was an excellent APA.  The hops and malt was very balanced.  Aroma is faint grapefruit, semi sweet, and hoppy.   Color is amber.  Taste is semi sweet, citrus hops, malty, and caramel taste.  Finish is crisp, clean, and not lingering.  A must try. A.  This would be great with a burger, steak, or pork chops.

Very subdued aroma, some grain, caramel, and tangerine. Flavor is also very mild, slightly sweet, slightly bitter on the finish. Light bodied and very drinkable. Nothing wrong with it,  just not that much too it. A decent example of a simple and straight forward style.
caramel and fruit aroma,golden, clear, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, nice caramel/fruit finish.
Brown and a bit hazy. Has an off-white head, medium duration. Sweet aroma, sweet, roasted grains. Flavor is moderate sweet, fruity notes. Perhaps candy too. Light faint bitter finish. Creamy texture.
Poured into a amber colored ale. Not very aromatic, thin head. Initial taste of well balanced malts and ended with a pleasant but not over powering bitter. Very good.

Medium amber almost clear body, with a long lasting, off-white, creamy head that leaves plenty of lacing. The aroma is faint caramel and citrus. The taste is light sweet with a good moderate bitter finish. The fruity flavours are as faint as the aroma. Light to medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation. Everything’s fine and dandy, but too faint to be really exciting.


[35.5 cl bottle, from ICA, Hasle, Oslo]
Apr 28, bottle@Briar Street Theatre, Chicago.  Pours clear brown with a small head leaving some lace. Sweet fruity malty very malty caramel. Drinkable, refreshing. Acidy bitter sweet finish.

Bottle at CitiField for a Mets game (beat the Dbacks 4-1). This was fairly average. Plenty of caramel malt, a touch of cherry, and some oats. I’m trying not to let the whole InBev takeover thing cloud my judgment, but I kept comparing it to Bud American Ale.

Pours hazed golden orange with a medium sized beige head that fades leaving a small cap. Aroma of grains, floral and lemony citrus. Taste is excellent, it has that grain/caramel/toffee sweet smell of boiling wort along with some citrus. The finish is very mildly bitter. There is almost a tea flavor. Medium light body, medium carbonation. A great session beer. I wish I had access to cases of this beer.

29.04.2011. 0,355l Bottle from ICA Maxi Haugesund. Golden colour with white head. Nice malty aroma with good spicy bitterness. Bitterness is very good. Its spicy and it lasts. Very good bitter this one.
Out of the bottle at the Cheesecake factory of all places. Very drinkable brew but nothing overly spectacular. Sierra Nevada pale was better

Hazy amber color with thin head.  Poured from a bottle by the bartender.  Mild snappy bitterness and a farmlike maltiness on the aftertaste.  I am not sure how to describe it!  OK overall and quite drinkable.
Pours a nice golden color with a white head, Has a nice roasty malt flavor that was unexpected.

murky but clearish orange copper, a light watery head... nose with lots of citrus and toffee... taste is a bit watery, still toffee but a lot of the sweet is gone, bitter finish.. not bad but not one I’d have very often
Draft at O’Hare.  Hazy orange color.  Aroma of citrus/orange peel.  Taste is floral citrus.  Not bad.
Bottle 355ml. Pours clear copper with white head. Aroma is caramel, citric fruits, malt. Lifht sweet, medium bitter. Medium body, thin to oily, average carbonation. Good stuff.

Low, white foam on top of a cobber red ale.
Aroma of sour malt, some hop and some orange.
Flavour of malt and sitrus, with a pleasant bitternes in the back. Medium body, okey lenght, everything is very balanced.
Summary: A decent ale, but nothing special.

Bottle from Wholefoods Market, London. Pours orange/light brown. Nose is malty, bready and floral hops. Despite calling itself an English style this still has a citrous kick I associate with American IPAs and pale ales but more subtle. Malt character is much more present though and some English style fruity floral hops.
12oz in Chicago. Lots of up front flavorful, roasty hops in to sweet honey, full malting. Nicely balanced, finishes perfectly after malt wash. Tasty pint.

Copper clear, thick white head. smells of malts, flowers, grass. taste is quite malty with good sweetness and caramel. Feel is a bit thick, not sticky or oily. Finish has some grassy hops. A very good beer for its kind

Medium offwhite head. Beautiful amber body with carbonation. Caramelly toffee and floral hops aroma with roasty notes. Clean and vivid. Dry-sweetish roasty caramelly toffee taste with sugary notes. Mid-bodied. Mild, soft mouthfeel. Dryish orangey strawy aftertaste with papery notes. Very nice and drinkable, but low on hops. (0.33l bottle, ICA Maxi, Strømmen.)

Reviewed from notes.

Poured into a tulip glass. Color is amber with a nice off white head. Starts at 1.5 fingers of head and then falls down throughout. A good bit of spotty lacing. Nose is nice with a bit of caramel and nutty malt as well as some nice floral and citrus hops.

The taste is quite nice with a good dose of nutty malt with a slightly-sweet caramel and toffee taste. Good floral hops throughout. Feel is moderately light; nice body and good carbonation. Drinkability on this one is quite nice. I love that I can get this in DC, but please come to VA!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-12-2010

Bottle. Slightly hazy copperish amber with some off-white head. Aroma is florally hopped with fruitiness, biscuits, caramel malts. Taste is citrusy hops and caramel malts. Palate is medium and quite carbonated.

Bottle 355ml @ home

Pours clear dark golden with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel and citrus fruity hops. Taste is light sweet and light bitter. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.

35.5cl bottle at the local supermarket. Golden colour with a small white creamy head. Aroma is fresh with notes of grass, hops, malts and nuts. Flavour is subtle. Blend of citrus and grass, but also some hops and malts. Some bitterness. Easy to drink session beer or just to enjoy outside in the sun.

355ml bottle. Orange, almost lava-coloured beer, which is cloudy at first but clears a bit. A small amount of lace and nice gentle carbonation.The nose has honey and raisins. The taste has toast and honey. The palate has good texture and fairly good structure with a good clean finish. Overall, a good beer, if not a world-beater!

0.33l bottle @ Biskopen, Bergen. Pours a light golden/peachy body with a thin white head leaving lacing. Nose is low with notes of grains and caramel malts. Slightly light bodied with low carbonation. Doesn’t actually tastes all that much, but it’s light fruity with notes of apricot, peach and orange. Ending quite quickly and leaving a mild bitterness. Refreshing and light drinkable.

355 ml bottle. Slightly hazy, dark golden body with fine off-white head. Aroma is citric fruity with a hint of caramel. Flavor is citric fruity, caramel malt and a god pronounced bitterness. Medium body, bitter aftertaste. Rather plain, but balanced, nice flavor and really refreshing. Nice session beer.
Copper colour. Aroma of caramel and citrus. Flavour is caramel malts and citrus. Somewhat wooden and pretty good.
Pours copper with a white head.  Smells eathy with some toasty hints.  Tastes rosey and lightly fruity with some spicy touches on the finish.

35,5 cl bottle at home, Bought at Ica Maxi, Sandnes. ABV is 4,3%. Clear amber color, fine off-white head. Aroma is fruity hops and some caramel malt. Flavor has fine bitterness and sweetness, and a fruity finish. Fine carbonation.

Bottle from ICA, Oslo. Clear amber colour. Large offwhite head, good retention, some lacing. Aroma of dusty hops and some caramel. Light/medium body, average carbonation. Taste is well-balanced, mildly bitter, refreshing, very drinkable.

Bottle @ Biskopen. Pours a clear, light coppery body with a medium creamy white head. Aroma is barely present, only faint traces of caramel malts. Taste is smooth malts, caramel and hints of peaches in the aftertaste. Nice, but a bit bland in the end. Then again, I’ve come to realize that I don’t really fancy English-style bitters all that much.

Aroma: Hints of citrus with bread and fresh dough aromas readily apparent.
Appearance: Cloudy orange with a thick white head that dissipates quickly.
Taste: Heavy sweetness balanced by a light sourness and hint of bitterness. 
Palate: Medium body, thick, creamy texture, soft carbonation, decent finish.
Overall: A good session beer. Quite quaffable, but a bit malty for my tastes. Still, very drinkable and enjoyable beer. I could easily see myself putting a back a few of these on a hot summer day while maintaining the coals on a long, smokey barbecue.

Bright orange colored, cloudy appearance. Medium sized yellow head. Rich appricot-orange aroma with flowery hops, some bitterness also come up. Medium bodied, smooth palate. Flavor is more bitter with lemony tone, some grains and flowers here as well. Carbonated and round aftertaste with lemon.
Amber in color with little head. It has a mild hop flavor with a hint of malt. This is a very drinkable beer, with a nice balance of flavor.

Bottle; Pour is copper really, with an average off white head. Very light lacing here - There is indeed a light fruity aroma on the nose, while the head reveals a certain breadiness. The brew is a bit bitter on the tongue, with florals, tropical fruits, and a sweet bread style malt character. I suppose that other than the bitterness on the tongue - the brew is more stylish on the nose than in the mouth.

Aroma of light resiny hops, a bit of rye spice, caramel and biscuit. Appearance is red/copper with 1/2 inch tan head; perfectly carbonated body. Flavor has an emphasis on light resiny hops up front, with perhaps a touch of citrus; the finish is caramel and the reoccurring light rye spice. Palate is bubbly and finishes creamy with a slightly sticky mouth feel. Very nice and easy drinking, but still quite flavorful. Worth a return trip, or perhaps a permanent spot in your fridge.
Draft at pizzeria in Chicago.  Pours amber with caramel malt and hop aroma. Good balance of malt and hops.  Decent beer and not one of my favorite styles.
355ml bottle.  Pours a hazy dark orange with a thin head.  Aroma is bready malt and orange hops.  Bready start, watery orange hop finish.
Really an APA/Bitter hybrid, mainly based on the American hops used.  Good fallback session.

Pours a cloudy caramel color.  Smells fruity and hoppy.  taste is medium bitter and medium carbonated.  tastes mildly of tropical fruit and some hops.  Reminds of the beers i used to drink when i lived in Australia.
A solid, highly drinkable beer. Light but refreshing taste, simple aroma, and a delightfully airy palate.
A really solid ale.  I’m a big fan of this style, and when I have a choice, I’ll almost always go with this ale.

Had this with dinner at Bubba Gump’s in the Navy Pier. I wasn’t suprised when their 312 Wheat came in a weizen glass, but I was when this did.

3.0 A: Clear amber color. Not any head to speak of since it was poured right up to the top of the weizen glass. Bad pour, but I gotta call it like I see it. Sorry GI.

3.5 S: Aroma wasn’t anything special. A little bready, a little more grainy, and some crystal malt.

4.5 T: Taste was much better than the aroma. Caramel malts and a very pleasant nuttiness to it, almost like it was a brown ale. There was also a good helping of citrusy hops.

4.0 M: Medium body. Good carbonation. Not bad.

4.5 D: This is a very sessionable ale. The taste is damn good and never got boring.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 06-27-2009 05:41:42
Caramel color in the glass with a thin white head. Aroma of hops and caramel malt. Good balance between assertive hops on palate with a pleasant malty background. Nice.

33 cL bottle poured into a Westmalle glass.  Red ale, with a shortlived fluffy head.  Smells terrific, fruity and hoppy.  This is a bit too sour and over hopped for my liking.  That said its quite a reasonable tipple.

Appearance- Nice amber hue

Aroma- floral hops, caramel sweetness and a little citrus.

Taste- pleasant hop crispness upfront with just a little caramel sweetness following. Not much of a finish and the flavor could be a little bolder for my tastes. But still very enjoyable.

Mouth-feel- Light bodied.

Drink-ability- Easy

Pours an attractive copper color with a white head forming.  The aroma has a nice light hop charcter and maybe a nice sweet malt quality to it.  Fairly light aroma overall.  The flavor is also light with a tart bitter hoppiness tuat leada towards some grain and caramel malts.  Very drinkable.

Mad Hatter, DC pint ($6): Pours a pale amber color with a creamy white head. Aroma of citrus, grapefruit methinks. Taste is pretty much in line with the aroma. Nice body for a low alcohol beer. Well-balanced and very drinkable.
Bottle from the Beer Temple Amsterdam, Amber beer with small head. Not bad for the style.
12 oz bottle, pours a lear amber w/ a resilient white head, aroma is light toasted malt, clean malt backbone w/ ligt bitterness throughout, smooth

Pours clear golden amber with a fluffy white head. Smells hoppy with malty undertones. Has a mild flavor, lightly bitter and still satisfying. Between light to medium-bodied with a creamy texture and softer mouth carbonation, Honker’s Ale finishes smooth and satisfying. Quite drinkable.

Considering the low alcohol, this has a good deal of flavor.  Enough taste to be worth drinking without being assertive.  Perfect for an evening when you know you have to be up and alert the next morning.

Bottle at Chipotle, London. Hmm, no glasses anywhere? Can’t tell how this one looks. Pleasant aroma of toffee and fruit, but I may be missing things without a glass. Taste: quite malty with toffee, some butter, clemetines/tangerines, medium bitterness. Medium body and carbonation. This is pretty tasty and worked well with my tacos.

Beer poured a slightly cloudy golden orange. Head was foamy and off-white. Wet-dog aroma with mild pine and biscuit. Funky sourness with very earthy flavors. Peat comes to mind. Not sweet. Acrid actually. Hops are prevalent and very dry. An aftertaste like celery! Medium-high carbonation - effervescent - with a dry finish. Medium-light in body. Texture fizzy. A wierd brew but I enjoyed it a lot.

12 ounce bottle from thetomG (Secret Santa Winter 10). Thanks! Pours a clear pale amber color with a medium sized frothy offwhite head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel, toasty malts, husky grains and a floral hop finish. The taste is bitter hops, bitter malts with some toastiness and a grainy finish. Medium bodied. Nice. Highly drinkable.

Clear copper golden with a rim of white foam.  Light fruity citrus aroma with mild malts.  Flavor has a medium biscuit malt upfront with a backing of fruity malts.  A session ale for sure.  It doesn’t take much thought but has a nice overall flavor and an abv coming in sub 4.5.
Pours brown with a light head. Rich aroma of malts and caramel. Flavor is malts and mild hops. Quite nice.
Rich character for the style - nice balance of malts and somewhat bitter hops, an earthy character as well. Good bitter.
Clear orange with a fluffy white head. Musty caramel and toffee aroma and taste with a bready slightly bitter and earthy finish.

Small bottle from ØlKonsortiet, Aalborg.  A finger of dense blond foam, over a foggy orangey red body. Toasted bread and fruity hops on the nose. Smooth and creamy in the mouth. Taste is rounded and balanced; soft malts with a sourish twist, a fine fruitiness, and mild bittering hops. Light-bodied with sparkling carbonation. Not very ’English’, yet a balanced and drinkable ale.

Absolutely gorgeous ruby red color. Weak aroma (poured from bottle to glass) but what was there was just a bit above your average beer. Taste was malty, nothing surprising but good for what it was. Not sweet at all, to me. Was a tad thicker than average beer, very nice lip feel.

Got a 12 pack for my birthday, am glad to say I’ll be enjoying all of them.

Pretty solid beer, nice malty backbone with a slight hop presence as well, tasted almost like a lager to me, but with some hops mixed in.  Syrupy thick quality to it, relatively easy drinking, good fall beer.

355ml bottle.  Friday, November 12, 2010
good white foam.  Amber colour.  Great tasting beer :-)

Had this on tap @ Gosse Island Wrigleyville.  First tasting of a bitter, I usually stay away from lighter English styles as the malts are too bready.

20 oz. English Pint.  Poured a clear red, with ample head with good retention and lacing.

Good hop aroma, citrus and pine.  Hope taste was citrus and grass, typical of European hops.  I don’t typically like grassy hop taste, but this was a far cry from a pilsener taste, so it was fine by me.   I suspect they added both American and English hops to get this character.

Mouthfeel was on the lighter side, with a touch of slickness.

It certainly fits the category of a bitter, but given the prevalence of IPAs and APAs, it cannot be considered truly "bitter" by American standards.  The taste was balanced, but the malts shone through stronger than hops.
