Overall it was good and I would have another if available, but it would not be first (or second) choice.
I’m not a fan of the style, and if 312 or the IPA or any of the seasonals is on tap/on sale I’ll choose that. But if not, its still a solid ale: pretty hoppy without much sweetness.
12 ounce bottle.  Pours a light amber with a nice off-white head.  Aroma of hops, malt and fruit.  Tastes of citrus and hops balanced well with malt.  Nice pleasant brew.

Bottle. Pours a thin white head with very poor retention. Dull brown body. Rather ugly and boring. Aroma is f aromatic hops and a good amount of biscuity malt. Balanced. You can’t mistake this taste for Goose Island. Good fresh hoppy bitterness. Crisp dry bitter finish.

At the bar at Wolfgang Puck’s, layover at O’Hare. Goodness knows how many pints I’ve had of this brew over the years. Decent rendition of the style, which was probably more impressive back in the day but for which I still have a fondness. If Fat Tire were better it might be something like this beer.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a hazy light amber with an off-white head.  Aroma is very much of honey and caramel with a bit of tea.  Flavor is toasty malts with honey and caramel, a bit of toffee, and again that touch of tea.  Not bad at all, but not too exciting either, just a solid beer.
This is another good "go to" beer for me.  Not too overbearing.  Tastes good.  And you can get it outside of Chicagoland.

12oz bottle as an extra in a trade.  Clear bright brilliant copper appearance with a one-finger whitish head that fades to light foam.  The aroma is toasty and caramel malt notes, slight butteriness, and light fruity hop notes.  The flavor has a really good toastiness to it, with caramel and toffee, peach pie and earthiness.  Medium-light bodied but not thin, with average carbonation and a wet (not dry) mouthfeel (hey, it is a liquid, right?).  Overall, this is nice.  It’s like a tastier and lower-ABV version of Bass Pale Ale.  I could see myself drinking a lot of this in a sitting...if I weren’t an incorrigible ticker that is.

Bottle, available pretty much everywhere I go in this awesome city. Burnt-orange amber colour, average golden head. Lightly toasty toffee and fruity hop character, peachy, with earthy nuances. A great session beer.
12 oz. Bottle.  This one actually surprised how refreshing and drinkable it was.  You could taste the hops but it wasn’t over done at all.

Draught at clybourn. Had this right after the special ordinary bitter to see how it competed. Much softer, rounder, and less tannic with less toasty and a little more fruity. Light amber to orange in color with a white head good retention. A bit fruity and earthy in the aroma with moderate hops. The malt is a little cleaner on the toasty side, definitely more sweet pale than darker roast. Rounder body. Nice stuff. Another solid session beer.

Bottle @ home. Nice amber pour, large tanned head.
aroma is very hoppy and malty, touch of sweaty blue cheese.
Flavour is quite malty, only a touch of hops, neither bitter nor sweet.
355 ml bottle. Hazy amber colour, thin white head. Sweet, caramel-malty, citrus-fruity aroma. The flavour is malty, sweetish, with a citrus-fruity, mildly bitter finish.

A good American clone of an English pale ale.  I homebrew and brew a style very similar to this (with a bit more hop character) and never get tired of a good English Pale with an American twist.  A nice amber color with a modest head and mild palate.  The best part of it is the taste, not too powerful but not in the least bit weak - just a nice balanced taste that gets better pint after pint.

not as good as i hoped it would be given the brewers reputation. Very sweet like ice tea with nutrasweet flavoring. the hops give it a nice aroma and flavor, but the malts ruin that and it becomes a chore by the last 1/4 pint to choke back. Not a good session beer like i hoped and im glad that i got one out of a broken 6 pack.
Nice interpretation of an English ale...reminds me of Bass but I prefer this actually. Find it a bit fuller bodied with nice malt up front and balanced bitter finish.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12oz bottle into a pint glass. The label has a brief description and a "bottled on" date but no ABV%.

Appearance: On top of a nice orange amber body sits a good two finger tall eggshell colored foam head. The head hangs on well and makes cool lace patterns on the glass.

Smell: The aroma has a nice sweet maltiness with caramel and a good balance of citrus hops.

Taste/Palate: Up first there is a simple bready maltiness with some mild caramel like sweetness and light toasted grain with faint hints of fruitiness. This is balanced by pleasant citrus and leafy hop bitterness. The medium body has a smooth feel and drinks easily.

Notes: This is just a strait up tasty ale with great drinkability
Pours a hazy copper color with a very thin white head. Aroma of caramel malts and floral hops. Flavor is mostly malts with hints of fruit, caramel & floral hops. Very well balanced and smooth beer.

[Bottle from Beers of Europe] My first beer in the dubiously named "English Pale Ale" style.  Copper with a moderate off-white head.  Lovely piney aroma.  Pine continues into the flavour but is less obvious.  There’s a hint of lemon, and some mineral bitterness that doesn’t really suit the flavours.  Herby in the finish.  A pleasant enough beer, but can’t see anything English about it; it’s American through and through!
Bottle. Amber colour with a white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, caramel, grain and fruit.

On Tap- Served a deep copper color with a nice head that fades slowly to good lacing. Fresh grain with citrus & light malt aroma. Crisp with citrus & bread flavor. A nice bitterness and a mild dry finish. Fairly medium body, quite smooth & light carbonation. Easy drinker. A nice mellow brew to relax with.

355 ml bottle @ Tuomari. Rated @ 16.8.2009.

Pours an amber colour with a small white head. Sweet caramel malts on the nose with aromatic hops, peach and apricot notes. Not that pleasant. Medium sweet taste with a malts and hops in balance. Light bodied, watery texture and soft carbonation.
Pours a nice amber with average head.  Not too much aroma. Flavors are malty, hops are not noticeable.   A very mild beer, but not too bad for style.  I prefer Fullers, though

On tap at Chicago O’Hare. Rich golden color with white head that dissipates quickly. Nice fruity aroma - slightly spicy. Taste is more bitter and malty than the scent would suggest. But the spices sneak out of the mix towards the end of the sip. Mild aftertaste clears quickly.

Rating #398, got two free bottles at Lagersalget @ GJK 
 


Amber-coloured ale with an airy, but lasting head. 
The nose is berries, caramel, malts and flowery hops.
Likewise is the flavor caramel and berries, but also an easy touch of alcohol and a light bitterness in the finish. Aftertaste is mild bitter and has some traces of coffee from the malts, too. Soft, but a bit thin.
It has been a long time since I had a good pale ale, but this was a treat.
Amber colour with light off white head. Aroma is a bit malty Flavour is a little sour with light malts. The beer is well balanced with a decent palate.

Heavy malt, caramel, moderate hoppiness of flowers, earth, wind, and fire. Medium hue, amber in color. Light sweet acidic with moderate bitterness. Very tasty and drinkable the more you drink the better it taste with the hops fading to the back ground and the malt really shining through. This is one of my favourite Pale Ales.
Light, grassy, enticing aroma.  Color is a dark amber, while the head is off-white.  Flavor of medium hops, mild herbs, and mild citrus that accompanies a dry palate.

On tap at local restaurant.  Slightly cloudy orange amber with no head, maybe it had one before it got to me.  Aroma slight hops and malt.  Taste light caramel, malts, not miuch else.  Palate thin.  Alcohol not apparent.  Finish dry and hoppy.

Just OK.

12 oz. bottle. Appearance-copper with medium off white head with medium duration. Aroma- bready and carmamel malt with some hops in the background. Taste- A little more hop character than an English pale ale but the balance is more toward the malt. A fair amount of bitterness at the finish. An easy drinking yet flavorful pale ale.

She poured with gusto in my glass, primping and preening coppery amber feathers while flashing a sleek white collar at me. Quite the attractive vision, if I do say so myself, and her nose is even better. Toffee and treacle sit poised above a platter of sliced red apples, caramel can apply, along with fresh cinnamon sticks. Lemon pith whispers in the back while crunchy melba offers silent support front to back. While her nose is complex in no certain way, she is sumptuously sessionable. My first quaff is sweet and dry at the same time, if such a thing is possible. Caramel and toast stand their ground while a solid undercurrent of hops blossom into grass and grapefruit esters. Red grapes and red plums sport their crisp bitter skins before releasing their succulent juicy meats inside. Delicious. Treacle and toffee are but gentle brushes across my lips before joining the melba for a crispy glazed crunch with each quaff. Quaff and repeat. Like her nose, not overly complex but just right.




There is an almost forgotten art in the construction of a truly delicious session beer, whether she is an ale or a lager variant. All beer is beautiful when, well, beautiful, and they don’t have to be ABV beasts and flavor bombs to still be enjoyable. The Honker’s Ale from Goose Island was the perfect median of both, and I’d welcome her in my fridge as a steady staple any day of the week…if she were available in Florida.

Aroma- hay, bread and a bit of toasted nuts.
Appearance- reddish copper  with a butter head.
Taste- light sour bitterness up front with a hint of toasted malt.
Body- light
Finish- dry
Not overly hopped like most Pale Ales.
Bottle from Trykbar in Copenhagen. Aroma of wheat and hay. Golden amber colour with white head. Sweet flavour of bread and honey.

Pours a light hazy amber color with a quarter-inch cream-colored head which quickly dissipates. Caramel malt, bread, and spicy/piney hops in the nose. Light in body and drinkable. Lightly carbonated with a short finish. Bready malt, lightly sweet in the flavor, but finishes pretty dry. I suppose it’s a solid example of an English Pale Ale. I found it bland.

Aroma is fruity, sweet and malty. Appearance is a hazy orange with a small tan head. Taste of orange peel and other citrus goodness up front. Nice carbonation, not too fizzy. A little watery and boring after a bit with a rough finish, but still a nice epa.
Poured a honey color with almost no head.  Aroma is malty with some fruit.  Taste is malty with some bitterness.  Slightly creamy texture.  Some caramel and cotton candy.  Overall decent.

I had tried this years ago passing through O’Hare, so I was excited to finally see it here in MA. I would rate it an above average domestic Pale Ale. Rather well balanced, unlike many others who hop the crap out of their Pale Ales. Highly drinkable, even if this is not my favorite style.
12 oz bottle from Kwik Star - Pours a clear orange with a white head.  Nice hay aroma with a hint of grass.  Very smooth medium body with a slightly bitter finish.  Very nice beer.

12 oz bottle from Stateline. Poured a mostly clear orange tinged copper body underneath a tightly packed light beige head. Aroma is like an odd breakfast, slightly overdone toast, bad orange marmalade, and a piece of candy whose name escapes me.....basically it was a giant toffee/molasses/caramel lollipop. The body is thinner with average, but what seems strong compared to the body, carbonation. The flavor is of slightly spoiled grains where they are just starting to pick up a little tanginess, fruit notes as well including peach and apricots. Sessionable beer.
Had on draft at Goose Island Brewery, Wrigleyville, Chicago, IL.  Dark amber in color with a thin white head that laces well.  Taste is roasted malts and caramel.  Smooth, Easy finish.

must be getting spoiled by IPA....this is not as tart as I recall it to be....pretty mild....mild citrus hoppy nose; amber, orange color; just a lite bitter / sweet taste; fairly light body; not much of a finish; overall...good but not great...

Appearance: Cloudy Mango/Orangey Amber with a fingers worth of head.

Aroma: Granny Smith Apples

Taste: slight tartness with a sweetness. Granny Smith Apples/Cinnamon.

Palate: Rye-Like mouthfeel that dries out the palate for the next sip. 

Overall: Session. I would if I could, but I have to get this from Chicago friends!

Orangish, Amber with some red highlights around the edges.  Clear.  Had a slight off white head with small tight bubbles.  Decent head retention.  Really hanging around.  The smell was of caramel, bread, biscuit with some underlying hints of butter.  Nice balance on all aromas.  The taste was a bready, biscuit flavor.  Slight bit of bitterness at the end and again picking up the buttery flavors.  Bitterness kind of fades as the beer warms.  The mouthfeel was thin, light, crisp and dry.  I do like this beer.  I think it would be very drinkable during the fall season.  Great all around, solid beer.
Available all over Chicago.  It’s success encouraged other craft brewers in the city.  A good everyday pale ale. Serving: Bottle and tap

Pours an iced tea shade of cloudy brown with a very thin off-white head.  Aroma is hearty bread (rye?) with a strong undertone of burnt sugar.  Flavor is an extremely earthy marriage of yeast and malt, with hops that remind me of Fuggle or Kents and that bit of burnt sugar/caramel sweetness.  Smooth texture, if not a bit sticky sweet at the tail end.  All in all, not bad!

Appearance- This beer poured a nice copper color with a huge white head. Lacing was present throughout.

Smell- Wonderful malt aroma with nice hints of hops and sweet caramel.

Taste- Nice toasted malty flavors with a caramel sweetness similar to the nose. There is also a nice hoppiness which provides a nice citrus taste to it.

Mouthfeel- A medium body with a medium carbonation.

Overall- This beer is great!! It could function as a prefect session beer with the great taste and the fairly low ABV. I could drink a lot of these!! Only problem. We can’t get this down here in Louisiana. Guess it’s time to start bugging the local distributor!
Bottle. Amber colour with huge brown head. Aroma hoppy grass notes. Taste quite hoppy, bitter, sweet malty. A nice session beer.
bottled. pours amber with a small offwhite head. Aromas of caramel and hops. flavors of grass along with it. it is smooth and unassuming. Lacks finish.
120z bottle pours amber with small tan head. Aroma of grapefruit, floral, grassy. Tastes of caramel with nice citrus balance. Very agreeable.

Perfect session ale. Perfect. Packing or lawnmowing beer, maybe not the best in the absolute heat but hey if it’s summer and you don’t have shit to do and you aren’t drinking this, you are making at least one mistake in your day. Awesome caramel malts balance out smooth hops of the citrus vein. Lightly done in every way, this is a light lower alcohol medium bodied gem. No sacrifice on flavor, but perfect drinkability. And I’m sad I just used drinkability to describe a real beer.

Pours with a three finger cream head that fades very slowly to a thin layer leaving a good lace.  Clear amber color.  Medium carbonation and medium bodied.  Light hoppy nose.  Flavor is a balance of hops and caramel. Dry finish.  Bottled on Jan 21, 2010. $1.95 for a 12oz bottle from Colonial Spirits, Acton, MA.
some burnt sugar, malts and lemon on the nose, but very watery and the taste is quite weak. hints of dried fruit on the taste
Bottle@Home. Sweetish, lightly hopped, light malty amber ale. That’s it. Nothing wrong yet uninteresting.

Pours a nice amber color with a white head. Aroma of hops, fruit/citrus and some sweet malts. Taste is malty with a small amount of hops and citrus at the end which gave me a bit of a dry mouthfeel at the end. Body is pretty solid. This beer was okay but not very exciting.

Serves up amber and smells lightly of hops and sweet fruit.  Smooth and solid with a good core of malt and fruit, balanced against some nice citrus and hop dryness. Palate slightly fuller than expected, I like it.

Poured from 12 oz bottle while watching the World Cup.  Aroma is an equal balance of malt and hops, appearance is a bright amber with little head.  Taste is an equal balance of spicy hops and rich malt, slightly bitter aftertaste.  There’s nothing that makes this exceptionally great, but I can say it’s exceptionally good.

Bottle. Pours a dark orange/light brown beer with a big white head. Some lacing on the glass. Loved the aroma that came out of the bottle. Very IPA like aroma with hints of citrus, grapefruit and spices. Taste was really nice. Starts with hints of syrup and some fruits which lead into a bitter finish and aftertaste. Could use some more bitter notes but when the beer warms up a little, you can taste the bitter notes more. Medium bodied. Very nice.
Nice amber pour with a healthy head. Nice light aroma. Good flavor. Decent ale.

20100606 tap at O’Hare.  Medium amber with lasting, sticky beige head. Aroma is boldly malt with lots of grainy bread and some peppery/earthy hops, faint pine. Flavor is English ale yeast-ish, some yes notes, mildly floral. Thin bodied and aggressively carbonated. Average, safe pale that would be hard to distinguish in a lineup with similar beers from other large micros.

Aroma:  Subdued ale yeast fruitiness.  Slightly hazy golden bronze with thin faintly yellow head.  Little retention, minimal lacing.  Mild carbonation.  Flavor follows aroma with a little caramel malt backbone.  Light-to-medium body with pleasant foamy mouthfeel.  Slightly sweet finish, but doesn’t cling.   Pretty good bitters.  Another good "starter beer" to convert your friends.

Pint @ Miller’s Pub & Restaurant. Decent pale ale that reminds me of Sam Adams Boston Ale. Hops are a little too forward, but malt balances it out nicely. Leaves kind of a filmy feeling in my mouth which is not entirely unpleasant.

Pours an amber / orange with a slight off white head. Aroma is nice floral hops with some fruitiness and some sweet malt. Mouth feel is medium, malts are sweet and hops are slightly bitter. I did not get the Pale ale experience on this one but all and all a good drinking beer.
Slightly herbal and spiced aroma. Nice mix of malts and hops. Fairly average, not offensive, however it doesn’t stand out amongst other better pale ales.
Lovely beer. Well-balanced, very drinkable and thirst quenching. One of the best American beers I have sampled.

Very clear light orange color. Thick, pillowy head. Nice lace. 

Sweet malty smell with a touch of bitter hops that provide balance. The malt dominates, but has a decent hop presence. 

Tastes like an English ale; slightly flat. Has a very balanced feel between the pleasant sweetness of the malt and the mild bitter hop counterpoint. Nutty aftertaste, surprisingly. 

Has a thick, creamy feel, but with a flat-ale character. It’s a very good ale. "Well-balanced" is the best description. Excellent; perfect for repeat drinkings.

Goose Island Beer Company--Honker’s Ale--2003 12 oz. Bottle.  5.00% ABV.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Pale Ale.  Nice earthy floral strong hop front.  Hop citrus Pale Ale body with hints of caramel biscuit.  Rich clean mild hot hop end.  Light sediment.  Tasted from bottle.  Also sampled 7/23/2003.(4.25 / 5.0) Rich.  Hoppy.  Sampled 2/26/2003.

Goose Island Brewing Company--Honker’s Ale--1999 12 oz. Bottle.  4.70% ABV.  (3.75 / 5.0)  ESB?  Bright clear light copper red color.  ESB character.  Bright clear light copper red color.  Light floral hop front; rich crusty roasted caramel malt body-hint of fruit and a bit light; Spicy finish.  Sampled 6/20/1999.

Location: This rating is from a draft sampling of this beer I had at a BBQ place on 4/15/10, but I have enjoyed this beer quite a few times recently




Aroma: The nose has fruit, wood, and caramel


Appearance: Pours a slightly unclear amber color


Flavor: Taste is balanced, medium sweet, light-medium bitter


Palate: This one has a medium body and a nice drinkability


Overall Impression: 
This one has become a semi-new go-to session type of beer for me as I have found it is served at quite a few places in NYC that have relatively limited selections.  I like this one, especially considering its availability.

Clear brown pour with a two finger white head that quickly turns in to one. the aroma is floral, grassy hops with a slight hint of caramel-nut malt. A bit on the grainy side. The flavor is much the same: a toasty caramel-toffee malt swirls in with a resinous grassy note. The palate is medium bodied with a velvety mouthfeel, medium effervescence, and a slightly astringent finish. Average, but not outstanding.

amber clear colour with a small off white head that stays a while. delicious hops and a caramel sweet maltiness. almost medium bodied but quite watery, in the end dries the mouth. Very nice. I want more Goose Island beer available in Finland.

lucent copper colored, pretzel malt, pine hops, simple, clean.

nothing all that great, bad, interesting, or unique about it.

Bottle. The smell is light bitter and medical. The medium large white head has a short duration. The body is light brown. The Ale tasted light bitter and medical. The body is light to medium strong, creamy-oily with a lively carbonation.

Almost no aroma... significant, white head.  Mild carbonation, amber/orange color & clear.   Very little taste or flavor... mild sweetness.  Overall, very mild & bland... indiscernable and unmemorable.

Pours amber/light brown with a good, sticky, off-white head that leaves some good lacing. More American pale ale than english bitter, the nose is strong with nutty, toasty malt, and refreshing citrus and piney hops. Flavor not as powerful in the mouth, but smooth, refreshing and well balanced. An easy-drinking, refreshing pale ale.
Smell is very promising, but the overall package is a bit of a disappointment. Tastes good, and goes down fine, but there is something missing. Like a broken promise.

Had this on tap with a big ass bacon cheeseburger at the Blue Moon in Madison - Pours amber with a light bubbly white head. Sweet toffee and light malt on the nose. Not much in the way of hops--maybe some light perfume/fruity hops in the background. Taste is pleasantly sweet and non-offensive, with caramel, a touch of nuttiness, and light hops on the finish. Slightly syrupy with a fairly light body, this would be a great session beer just about any time. I’m impressed.
Rich amber/cider color; Medium body; Aroma of malt, & citrus hops; Flavor of sweet malt, caramel, hops, and citrus; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, a solid ale.
On tap at Battleship Brewhouse.  Pours a clear dark golden color.  Aroma is of malts, hops, and citrus (mainly orange peels).  Taste is pretty much the same.  Has a nice crisp hop finish.
Poured a cloudy amber, with a small head and just a little bit of lacing.  Taste is dry, piney hops. Pretty simple and a little thin, but overall good.

On draft at the Hyatt Regency in Chicago.  Pours a thin, foamy white head with a clear, deep orange/amber body.  Faint grainy, bready malt aroma accompanied by earthy hops.  Flavor starts with toast, then some light caramel and raisin.  More light earthy hops and some light fruit - a touch of pear.  Medium body, average carbonation.  Malt forward with light bitterness.  Lingering malt and a touch of sugar on the tongue.  Overall very good and sessionable, if a touch shallow for a beer of this gravity.

Bottle. Honeyglazed fruit aroma, oranges, melons, citric hops. Amber, fine carbonation, creamy amber head. Sweet malt base, fine citric and earthy hop balance. Mellow mouthfeel, light chewy. berrylike aftertaste. Nice.
Clear amber color, white head; fresh hoppy aroma with some doughy cookie notes; good body for the strength, smooth on the palate; pretty sweet flavor of biscuity malt with low bitterness.

First sip was very dry with not much flavor to it.  As I continued on though a wealth of flavors came out.  Has a definite light sweetness, good malty flavor, light bitterness and and almost nutty flavor.  Great beer, could drink about nine of these in a sitting.
Nice looking slightly above average pale ale. An earthy malt holds off some strong crisp finishing hops. Well balanced almost hitting all the right buttons.

Bottle.

A - Light auburn copper with a full white creamy head with good retention and a bit of lace left.

S - Caramel and bready malt. Some citrus and earthy hops.

T - Nice toasted bread and caramel malt along with some grain taste. A little sweetness from these. A good amount of hops intermingle giving it a citrus (mostly orange but some grapefruit) and earthy/woody kind of flavor. Very slight hint of saltiness. Nice balance.

M - Medium to light body with a good amount of carbonation. Smooth and creamy.

D - Easy to drink with good balanced flavors and smooth and creamy mouthfeel. Good balanced flavors.

Notes: Good mix of English and American flavors in an English style. Solid everyday, session type beer, but not going to amaze you.

33cl bottle, CM- Vantaa. Pours copper color with a thin white head. Aroma is fruityand quite hoppy. Flavour is fruity, citrus and malty. Ends bitter, with some grapefruity aftertaste that was not to my liking. A decent pale ale overall, except the aftertaste.

Pours copper into a pint glass with a thin white head. Honkers has moderate hop aroma, pine and citrus stands out. The flavor is mild, nuttiness up front with hop bitterness to finish. Flavorful and drinkable.

12 oz bottle. I’ve never rated this beer? Holy heck I have never rated this? Oh well. Pours a deep golden with a small white frothy head. Aroma is very sweet, toffee, caramel and sugary malts. Some floral hops are present, but for the most part it is malt dominated. Flavor starts sweet, lightly sugary and a bit fruity and crisply hopped. Lightly bitter, nutty finish. Medium body and a sharper carbonation. A decent little epa, easy drinking.

A clear amber colored beer, with a thick foamy off white head. The aroma of fruits like citrus with orange. There are hops with some wheat. The taste of bitter fruits with sweet finish. The aftertaste is sweet and stays bitter for a while.

Found on tap at Soulth Station in Boston while i sat amoung a bunch of other travellers swilling back coors lite. A nice amber color with a thin head that lasted till the bottom of my glass leaveing a nice laceing. The aroma was a bit orange hops and the flavor was a even maltiness and hop spice. Medium bodied texture. A good standby if I can find it more often.

on tap at the Blind Tiger for a GI event: orange and red pour. some sweet notes in the arouma. over attenuated. Sweet orange, caramel, citrus and pine hops. Dry nice and sessionable. Some flat, yeasty notes as well.
bottle from Bierzwerg. Clear deep golden colour, large white head. Fruity nose. Malty with citrus hops and a touch of tropical fruit. Rather light-bodied and quaffable. Very nice!

(bottle, 35.5cl) Hazy, orange amber colour with a medium-sized off-white foamy head. Sweet cara-malty and slightly nutty aroma with fruity (citrus, grape-fruit) and slightly spicy hops. Sweet-bitter flavour, light bodied with a moderate carbonation. Cara-malty, initially bready and subtle nutty taste with fruity aroma hops; almost dry, sweet-bitter but also a bit slim and short finish. Otherwise an aromatic and likeable Ale. 22.II.10

Bottled 355ml. Ordered from www.bierzwerg.de. 30 IBU. It pours a clear amber beer with a creamy, nicely lasting head. Golding hops, fresh cut grass and caramel in the nose; pleasant and inviting. Reminiscent of a weaker version of Brooklyn east india pale ale. Balance between the caramel malt components and the earthy hops. Medium bodied. Bergamot orange sneaking in. Decent bitterness. Nutty. Average carbonation. Good sticky spotty lace. Dried apricot, almonds, grapefruit and marshmallow in the finish which is reasonably dry.

Bottle from a trade with phaleslu. Pours hazy copper color with tan head. Pale malt aroma with some floral hops. Bready flavor with mild hop bitterness. Medium body with moderate carbonation.  A nice English style pale ale. Thanks Peter.

On tap at Papa Jake’s in Buffalo, NY.  This beer’s been showing up here a lot lately, but not on tap....so I jumped at the chance.  I was, sad to say, thoroughly underwhelmed.  I’ve loved the vast majority of the GI beers I’ve had, and I’ve visited the Clybourn location, but this was just meh.  Not much flavor.  Had some caramel in the smell and taste, a little nutty.  Kinda felt like a half-APA, half-brown ale.  Overall it just wasn’t flavorful enough for me.  Would probably be good for a session, but it didn’t really hold up by itself at dinner.

Weak aroma and head, but decent taste. I’m not a fan of pale ales, but this is probably one of the better ones I’ve had. Appears a nice cloudy golden brown. Has about the right amount of carbonation. Hops are a little strong, even for this style. I don’t recommend more than one or two at a sitting, you might get hopped out. Aside from the hops and malt though, there’s really nothing else to this beer, or it would score higher.
Pours amber into a shaker. Off-white head recededs to hug rim. Caramel aromas. Crisp caramel with lasting mild resin finish.

Good Pale Ale . . .  From 12 oz bottle poured a nice, clear amber with an adequate head.  Aroma featured hops and bitterness (which you’d expect in the style) with some pine and fruitiness.  Well carbonated with a dry, somewhat nutty, feel.  Malt was noticeable but took a back seat to hoppiness (again, in proportion to the style.)  We’re not great fans of the style, but this is among the better Pale Ales we’ve tried.

Sampled at Central New York Brewfest, Syracuse NY. 06FE10.



App.:  Clear amber with a rim of white.
  
Aroma:  Some nice earthy, apricot fruity malts, a little brown sugar and nuttiness.
  
Palate:  Medium body and sharp effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Similar to the nose, add soapy/pine hops; lightly off-dry with some bitterness.



First of the fest, off to a decent start!
Bottle. Golden amber pour with some head. Hoppy presence both in flavor and aroma, easy to drink session ale.
Pours amber with white head, aroma is a bit hoppy with some malt.  Taste up front is a bit of floral sweet hops with some sweet caramel back bone and a bit of a dry and sweet finish.  Not bad.
Bottled at Beertemple, Amsterdam. Clear orange-brown, firm head. Malty nose. Flavor of malts, cardboard. Not the best.

12oz bottle. Pours orangish amber with white head. Aroma is malty with some hops, caramel, and toffee. Flavors of chewy malts, bitter hops, caramel, bread, and a little toffee. Decent balance between malt and hops. Ok.
Great locally brew for an english pale ale. It has a n off white head and toffe nuts.
Crisp, malty aroma...delicious, almost foamy mouth feel. Hops make you want to have another sip. Flavors of citrus and malts matched well with hops. Very drinkable. A very classy session beer.

Pours medium amber, clear, with fine sized bubbles and plenty of lace.

Nose is toasted matchstick, dry wood, and citrusy hops.

Palate throws in grapefruity hops, bread-like malt, and a drying hoppy component that fades well into the finish. Hops are at the beginning and the end, but the middle is a mysterious bready/biscuity scene. Medium bodied.

Finish has more of the toasted matchstick, maybe dry forest twig. (in a good way)

A nice step up from AB or Miller products, but this is an old recipe. GI is producing much more craft brews these days then they had in the past. Give this one to your uncle or dad and move them up a notch in beer drinking.

a nice malty brew from chicago. the honker’s has a nice color and aroma, but ultimately falls a bit short overall. it is still recommended drinking for those with a dislike for hops/a liking of malts.

Copper of color with a off white head. An aroma of bread, malt, raisins, caramel and weak notes of hops. A flavor of caramel, toffee, malt, weak bitter notes from hops and a nice finish with nuts and toffee.

Pours clear red wth a medium bubbly white head.  Aroma is hops and some very subtle yeast.  Tastes very full bodied for an EPA with fruit spices and hops.  Finishes bitter but pleasant and decently long.  Great session beer!
English style meets APA in almost perfection.  Goose Island never disapoints.
Slight hop aroma with some yeasty notes. Feels great on the tongue and the roof of the mouth. Taste is classic to the English style with an American hops flourish.
un poco overrated pero buena.  me gusta el estilo y con el tiempo iba mejorando.  si no fuera por la rusa la mejor del tasting
Poured a nice tan color with a light tan head.  Overpowering nose of hops.  Almost a spicy hop taste that has a slightly bitter finish.  Light carbonation.  Very good beer.

Smells extremely pleasant - hoppy, but not overly so.  Poured a great golden amber white a medium-sized white head.  Taste is excellently smooth - medium bitterness, but very easy to drink and very good.  Overall, it’s an excellent English Pale Ale that could benefit from a bit more hops, but that’s not a dealbreaker by any means.
Honey aroma, very foamy and a dark golden appearance. Interesting experience to drink, medium sweet, medium bitter. medium body, evolution.

Bottled at Vihreä Haltiatar, Jyväskylä. Copper color. Caramelly, nutty and slightly fruity aroma with restrained resiny hops. Malty, toffeish, fruity and nutty flavor with gentle resiny-fruity hops. Low to medium bitterness. Pleasant easy drinking beer, needs more bitterness.

Assaggiata in bottiglia da 33 cl.
Colore oro scuro e una bella schiuma fine e compatta. Piacevole aroma di malto. AL gusto presenta anche note agrumate anche se il malto rimane sempre preponderante. Il finale leggermente amarognolo è breve ma comunque discreto.

[bottle]
Soft banana and celery aroma with some herbal hops. Hazy copper appearance with a white ring. Oxidized caramel and cardboard flavour with notes of tobacco, raisin, and a little hazelnut. Very low bitterness. Medium body, low carbonation, clean finish.

In an imperial pint glass at a hotel in chicago.

Pours a clear, copper color with a full lingering white head that clings to the side of the glass. 

Aroma is nice malts well balanced with notes of suble hops.

Well-rounded full mouthfeel but it it is fleeting.

The beer has great malt flavour that unfortunately does not follow through as long as I hoped, the hops were not very pronounced.
Golden orange, whitish foam.  Aroma is citrusy, pine hops, caramel.  Taste is more hoppy, bitter pine, spicy finish.

A nice beer. Aroma promised good things ahead and the beer delivered. Notes of sweet fruit and hops. Appearance was dark amber with lasting head of generous foam. Taste was caramel, hops, candy, and malt. Some slight butterscotch was apparent and possibly purposely so. Biggest factor was the dry palate and high bitterness. Perhaps too much so. This is a bitter beer. Bitterness was somewhat astringent and harsh. Overall, a good beer but be prepared for bitterness.
Bottle. Pours amber orange with a fluffy white head. The aroma has floral and herbal hops with some crackery malts. The flavor is well balanced, with crisp floral hops and pale malts. Tasty.
35,5cl bottle. Murky orange color with rather little head. Malts, vegetables and hops in the nose. Flavor is malty with a nice hoppy touch to it. Solid brew.

Light amber color with a small head. Aroma and flavor are well balanced. Drinkable leaning towards a bitter finish. Some pilsner aspect with some caramel malts and light bitter hops. Crisp and simple but flavorful.
On draft at MacGregor’s in Henrietta. A very nice mild that we easy to drink with just enough caramel and bread to mark it as a great mild (at least in my book).
Bottle. Slightly cloudy deep golden color, white head. Malty aroma with citric notes. Malty flavor with a reasonable hop balance and some fruity notes. Medium-ligh body, medium-light carbonation.

Pours a hazy ruby/amber with a smallish head, leaves decent lacing... Mild hoppiness over a malty english aroma with a touch of orange citrus... The citrus starts the flavor with a nice hit of malty traditional english flavors following... A touch dry in the finish with a subtle hint of sweetness, very good english pale...

I thoroughly enjoyed this beer. I found it to be very smooth and easy drinking with not as much spice as the description is saying. Session-able and crisp I look forward to trying more of their beers in the future.
Sleightly hazy amber orange with a medium off white head. Aroma of citrus hops and toffee, Smooth medium sweet light bitter flavor with a clean freah finish.

The aroma was not as bold as I expected; subdued, malty and pleasant. A fine looking deep orange and amber beer. The head was fairly minute/thin. Lighter on the palate than expected -- buoyant almost, a bit thin and rather crisp. Flavor is malty, a bit of bread, and a definite citrus lingers. A fine beer but certainly not exceptional.
ambrata buona schiuma piuttosto persitente sentori lupplati piacevoli poi un po di lm,ati leggermente tostati in bocca secca luppolata lievi tostaure una piccola astringenza

Bottle at the Chili’s in O’Hare airport. I finally get to rate the beer I affectionately refer to as Honky Ale. Pours clear amber with a medium tan head. Mostly malty nose that is somewhat grainy and has traces of earthy hops. Pale malt flavor with crisp earthy hops and a sorta thin finish.

Poured from bottle into Tulip.

Burnished amber with small head, and only slight lacing. Overall flat look is expected for style.

Aroma of sweet caramel malts, with slight citrus.

Not nearly as sweet as the smell suggests. The malts are mostly dried out, slightly tea-like. Nice mild bitterness at the end. Overall, it is subdued but flavorful.

Relatively low carbonation with moderate body and fairly dry finish. Nice smoothness overall.

Very nice drinkability, and one of the better American made session beers.

On tap, pours a translucent amber with a decent foamy white head. Not much aroma, but I am in an airport. Malty flavors dominate, with light citrus hops at the end. Reminiscent of a Sam Adams lager. A fine beer for a layover.

It poured a hazy golden liquid with a small dirty white foam. It had a sweet smell of caramell, malt and honey. It had a smiliar taste of caramell, malt, bread , honey and something sweet at the end. It had a decent mouthfeel with some stingyness at the end. Medium thickness, a bit watery with a mild bitterness. Decent beer but nothing special.
(on bottle) Dark orange, white head. Huge fruity nose, peach mostly. Not really any taste and an odd metallic finish, bitter too, shelf killed?
Great beer on tap.  The hops come out very quickly.  The finish is bitter (but not to much to dry out the palate.  It has a nice blend of malts similar to an amber.

pours a dark orange/amber color.  thin white head after a few minutes to settle.  This is not a hoppy beer, but I do get a slight citrus flavor with a strong bitter finish.  I feel like I’m actually rating this higher than I should be.
A very solid beer. Pours an amber color with little bit of a white head. Citrusy aroma. The hops stand out in this beer. A bitter but well balanced finished. Very smooth and drinkable. Great beer!"

Compliments of Doboy (Thanks ED !), poured from 12 oz bottle, a nice clear light coppery hue, forming a large foamy head.  Aroma of light earthy notes with hops, malts, and spices.  Flavour much of the same, as sweet malts dominate and the hops come in to balance out the spring like water.  I’m not a fan of the style, but this is very decent EPA, I like it.
Very nice, solid, English Ale.  Hops are present, but not overpowering.  Solid and lingering malt works well to balance it out.

Goose Island Honker’s Ale is a clear, solid amber ale with a soft, creamy, off white whipped fluff of a head that has outstanding retention and lacing.  The aroma is fruity, wooden, botanical and dank with a hint of sweetness.  It’s medium bodied, smooth and fluffy and the finish is a little gritty.  It’s not sweet or dry with nice balance all around.  There are flavor notes of wood resin, wild flowers and a green bitterness.  This makes for a high quality session ale.

Bottle @ CitiField. This might get a higher rating later when I try it again outside of a plastic cup but this beer has a nice ruby body. The balance is more malt than hop. Not bad, but nothing special.

An interesting little beer. I picked it up at a local store in West Lafayette IN. It turned out to be better than I expected. It has some good carbonation, a little bit of malt backed up with flavors of fruit and bread. It’s cool and refreshing, and the copper color is even inviting. It’s a little lighter than I expected, but that doesn’t detract too much from its overall quality.
Bottle.  Pours a hazy amber with an off white head.  Light citrus and dry biscuit aroma.  Light hoppy taste.  Watery texture with good carbonation.  Drinkable but a little bland tasting to me.

I can’t believe I’ve never rated this before.  The pour is a deep burnished copper colour with a thick off white head… pretty good looking really.  Lovely nose with a soft fruitiness composed of cherry and a touch of berries.  There is a bit of caramelly/bready character on the back.  Soft and chewy with just a bit of herbal/spicy hoppiness.  Fruity and lovely.  Really, quite a surprise how much I like this.

bottle: pint glass: first beer after knee surgery... aaaahhh.  Pours mostly clear orangy copper, leaving a light off white head, maybe 2 fingers.  Nose is even, nothing sticks out too much... taste is the same.  Roasted malts, some hops, some caramel.  A very even balanced beer with no real distinct features.
Pours a cloudy honey/amber color.  Floral aroma with hints of citrus, honey and grass.  Smooth grass/hay hops flavor.  finish is slightly bitter, but well balanced.  Good easy drinking beer.
Bottle at Beer Temple. Nice amber body with medium head. Hoppy nose. Lots of hops in the taste. Caramel and malts too. Quite enjoyable.

Draft pint from Mulligan’s in Cincinnati.  Pours mostly clear amber with an average off-white head.  Mild aroma of malt, hops, grain, caramel, and bread.  Flavor is floral hops, malt, and caramel.  Light/medium body, slightly bitter.  Pretty easy to drink.  Strikes me as just a fine, average EPA.
12oz - Toffee colored liquid under tan head.  Caramel nose with a cereal background.  Caramel front with a waxy flavor on back.  Funky.
Bottle pours clear orange with frothy white two fingered head. Pine and mild caramel aroma. Good bitter with sweet honey back end. Very drinkable but a bit too fizzy.

Pours an amber/orange with a slight off white head.  Aroma is nice floral hops with some fruitiness and some sweet malt.  Mouthfeel is medium,  malts are sweet and hops are slightly bitter.  Well put together, good English pale with Midwest American malt influence.

Pours with a nice head and good lace, the color is a reddish orange. The aroma is floral hops and a little bit of sweetness. The flavor has a nice apple and a good bitter hoppiness well balanced by nice roasty malts. A nice enough little session beer.
355 ml bottle. Light brown body with off-white head. Flavour is malt, caramel ans hops.
Sampled numerous times. Clear copper pour with a small off-white head. Biscuity malts, caramel, and earthy hops abound. Decent stuff in a pinch at a small or local bar.

Bottle.  Pours a rich light brown with a large and vigorous white head.  Light malt and hops along with a little burnt aroma and some grain.  Barely medium body, malty and rather non-descript.  Finishes barely bitter.  Nothing amazing, but quite drinkable, and probably in large numbers.
RBESG Sheffield 2009, day 3, train from Manchester to Sheffield. Bottle. Hazy red amber color. thin off white head. Sweet malty and caramel aroma.Sweet flavor of malt, biscuit and caramel.

It pours a clear amber color with a thin off white head and some streaks along the sides of the glass. The aroma is a bit bland. Hints of malt and floral hops. As you sip on it the you can taste the malted and hops. It is a refreshing english pale ale, with great carbonation and nice balance.
FCBF 09  1st beer of the brewfest.  Nicely balanced.  Hops not overpowering.  Enjoyed it.

Very slightly hazed wood stain, huge, fluff-master head with a dose of freeform lacing. Musty hop nose with sprinkles of toasted grains.  Thin to medium body, just enough hop bitterness to balance the toasty malts. Musty basement rides underneath for some odd reason, but its certainly a perfectly balanced nuetral tasting beer with maybe a slight turn towards some toasty notes.  Its certainly not my style but I don’t find anything to rag on either

This is pretty good but nothing amazing that makes me want to drink it repeatedly. No one aspect of it is notable, which perhaps is a testament to its balance? I like the mouthfeel and it is nicely hopped. Understandably Goose Island’s flagship brew.

On tap at Gino’s East (O’Hare location) alongside the world’s best pizza.  Pours slightly hazy orange-amber with a small off-white head.  Lots of oatmeal raisin cookie in the aroma.  Tastes mostly the same, but with a little more of a citrus/grass hop character.  Medium-bodied, smooth, slightly bitter finish.

aroma of perfectly refined hops and well balanced background of delicious toffee. appearance is a nearly browned amber. flavor is floral hops followed by a lighty bracing bitterness. malt then follows to balance perfectly with its own floral notes, biscuits, fresh baguette and nuts. palate ends a tad wet but it seems to fit perfectly and it is not offensive. what a sessionable beer! after 100s i continue to find nuance.
330 ml bottle. Nice honey coloured body wiht wthie head. Aroma has wet malt, hops and sweet bisquit. Nutty hoppy and butterscotch in the taste. Malty and bitter too. Smooth mouthfeel.

clear honey/orange with a large creamy off-white head.  sweet malty aroma but on the subtle side.  toasty malts with a hint of bittering hop.  mellow and easy to drink with an exceptionally smooth palate.  just not that tasty.

Orange-brown beer with medium blond-beige head. Sweet malts and toffee in the aroma. Flavour is better balanced against sweetness than aroma, and there are some bitterness and so sweet malts are not so "in the top". Easy and nice to drink. This beer based on sweet malts: strong brewing to this style beer-lovers.

RBESG Sheffield 2009, day 3, train from Manchester to Sheffield. Bottle, ABV 4.3%. Hazy amber colour, white head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, bready malts. Flavour is malty, toffee, caramel, light bitter finish. Medium bodied. Enjoyable.

Bottle, Rehills, Newcastle. Initially a sweet elderflower aroma, with a bit of sherbert thrown in. Faintest flavour of sweet malt right at the back of the throat. Beer became more pleasantly bittersweet as it progressed. If brewing an English style bitter was the aim, then it’s a job well done - put me in mind of a Timothy Taylor beer, which is compliment enough.

Bottles last November, so I’m getting to this kind of late. Nice golden, orange color, decent head. Somewhat light in body, perhaps overly fizzy. Nice mellow spicy/grassy hop flavor. FInish isn’t entirely dry. Nice sessions ale.

Bottle at the White Horse, Parsons Green, 5th July 09. Fizzy orange, very tingly on the tongue. Slight cola cube or cough sweet note to the malty aroma. Sugary malt flavour with some bitterness but no real hop flavour of any kind. Too gassy and not flavoursome enough for my liking.

Bottled. Orange amber, firm pale head. Lovely fresh aroma, exotic fruitiness, green apples, citric notes, little biscuit malts. Flavor has strong sweetness, modest fruity hops, hint of grapefruit, honeymelon and slight resin, a tad sugary and coarse finish. Very lush mouthfilling palate. Pretty good, though sweet PA.

(Bottle) Amber and clear. Small, white and fizzy head. Malts, hops and grass in aroma. Medium bodied and dryish palate with quite high carbonation. Malts, caramell, grass, bitterness and lightly sweetness in taste. Malty and lightly bitter aftertaste.
Bottle.Hazy amber colour with small off-white head.Aroma is tosted witt taste of caramel and tobaco.Well balanced and hoppy with crispy finish.
Bottle from The Cave. Amber colour, off-whtie head. Nose of malts, caramel, some hops. Flavour is fairly hoppy and bitter, with some malts. Nice one.
Bottle. Poured amber with an off-white head. Aroma was malty for the most part. Flavor was a nice balance of hops and malts but overall quite basic.

12 oz bottle.  Pours hazy amber with a medium off-white head that fades to a thin rim fairly quickly.  Aroma is of sweet malts, caramel, biscuit, and a little bit of hops.  Flavor is similar with a fairly decent balance between malty sweetness and hop bitterness.  I wouldn’ t mind it having a little more hop bite though.  Overall, it’s fairly enjoyable and a good starting beer for converting people to craft beers.

Pours a hazy dark copper color with a medium, creamy white head. Aroma of light fruits, malts, and earth. Flavor is malty with some citrus and oranges, very light hop bitterness, grassy and earthy notes and grains. Medium carbonation and good, crisp flavor. Quite enjoyable.

brilliant medium brown with solid white head.  moderate carbonation for style.  initial clean hop bitterness followed by a mild hop flavor and a distinct upper crystal character.  some yeasty esters are present before a dry finish for the style.  brew could benefit from more hop flavor, malt sweetness and some toastiness.

Poured a clear tawny with a large, frothy off-white head that left some nice lacing. Aroma of sweet, earthy dry malt and English hops. The flavor is a good mix of sweet and bitter. Has a light to medium mouthfeel and light carbonation. An easy drinker, this is an excellent example of the style.
(bottle). Pours a cloudy amber color. Medium off white head. Balanced hop and malt aroma and flavor. Avg duration. Slick texture. Spare lacing. Soft carbonation.

12 oz. bottle Pours an off white head of good duration, with some lacing, over a clear golden orange (SRM 15) body........nose of mild spice, no pie, no citrus........taste is light, initially slight toffee malt, then mild bitterness which lingered.....mouth feel is medium, cabonation low. Rather quiet and understated even for an English Pale.

A 0.355L bottle from K-Citymarket. Mild fruity/malty nose. Pale fast disappearing head. Slightly hazy orange/yellow colour. Peechy taste at beginning. Slightly sour not very sweet taste. At end average hoppiness. Tealike taste.

12 oz bottle-trade w/jake65-Clear copper color w/a slight head & good lacing. Roasted malt aroma. Had a bitter, burnt hop bite to it which I found kind of off putting. More hops than malt, a lot more than I expect from this style. Mouthfeel was kind of thin. Short, burnt finish. Just OK.

Very nice looking cloudy copper color with an amber tint.  A light khaki colored head leaves nice lacing on the glass.  Light aroma of sweet hops with an undertone of honey.  A mild hop flavor starts and finishes the taste with malts coming through in the middle.  Like hop glazed malts.  Mild grassy flavor, decent amount of spices and a bread flavor underneath.  Finishes grassy and citrusy.  Some carbonation in the palate.  Simple but enjoyable beer.
Pours a hazy dark orange with thin white head. Lots of fruity and bready notes with some hoppage going on in there. Finishes dry.

It is hazy, dark orange with a creamy head. The aroma has notes of malt, fruit and caramel. The flavour has a light sweetness and notes of fruit, citrus (mostly oranges), caramel and malt. The finish is dry, and the beer is uncomplicated and pleasant, it seems very British in the hop choice.

Quite a malty one this. Thee is a hint of hop that helps to keep this from being too sweet. This has a grand little flavour.  I could imagine too many of these getting a little sickly though. Yeah, only the one for me.

Bottle. Amber colour with a medium sized white head. Aroma is malt with fruity hoppy notes. The flavour is also malty with notes of toffee and fruits. Some bitterness and citrus in the finish. Light to medium bodied. Quite good and tasty beer.
Bottle. Clear amber/orange colour with large creamy white mostly lasting head. Hoppy aroma and flavor. Creamy palate.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours an amber-orange color with a pretty good sized white head, decent lacing.  Aroma is sweet, caramel malts, and floral hops with a touch of spiciness.  Flavor is similar, a bit more on the fruity side with a decent citrus hop character and a touch of bitterness.   Mouthfeel is light-to-medium with some good carbonation, a slight bitterness sticks around until the next drink.  Good beer, very sessionable.

Nose of caramel, floral hops.  The appearance is a nice amber color, white head.  The flavor is just like the aroma, a balance of caramel malts and floral hops.  The hops take over on the finish.  Medium mouthfeel.  Decent beer, nothing extraordinary.
Bottle from Wholefoods Kensington, London. Citrus, pine aroma. An amber coloured pour with an off white head. Slightly sweet. Easy to drink but nothing special in my opinion.

355 ml bottle. 4.3%. Finland. 
Amber colour with thin off-white head.
Hops, citrus and toffee/caramel in aroma. Flavour is sweet caramel, fruity tea, hops and malts.
3 pints from tap at peter dillons. Served a couple degrees cooler than room temp. Pours light copper. Softly carbonated. Light orange, hop, and soft spice taste.  Very sessionable and delicious.

Sampled this at teh Goose Island bar in the Chicago airport. Pours out a deep amber color with a small light tan head on it. Aroma is simple of sweet caramel and brown sugar. Taste is more of the same sweet caramel/toffee notes with a hint of hops at the end. To be honest it reminded me somewhat of Sam Adams, I’m sure that won’t sit well with many here on ratebeer, but that’s basically what this boiled down to for me. Not much else to say about this one.
Bottle. Golden- orange colour with an off-white head. Aroma is hop,malt, caramel, fruit. Flavour is malt, hop, caramel. Medium body. A little bit ordinary beer.

Hazy golden amber poer from tap with good dense white head. Malty aroma with some citrus hop detectable. Smooth palate and good taste with lots of malt well balanced with citrus hops.  Citrus in the finish.

Lovely looking Amber Hue, Off white head that is happy to hang around. Aroma is blanced but Malt edges it with Hops taking a backseat. Then Boom the falvour is a maltsplosion in the good way, little bit of bitter hop finish. It’s like a good dog, it’s good.

355ml bottle from Trader Joes Indianapolis.  Pours a dark amber wth a thick head that didn’t last.  Aroma is malty sweetness.  Flavour is the same, with just enough hops to keep it from getting cloying, but not asserting themselves.  Very nice bitter.
Bottle. Lighter amber/orange pour. Light malty aroma with muted hops. Taste was English style pale, medium malts with mild hops. Not real excited about this one
Burnt orange hue, small, lasting head.  Malty bread/biscuit aroma. Smooth palate with similar flavor, sweet at the start, a moderate bitter bite at the finish. Sessionable.

330ml bottle (K CM, Helsinki) - at 4.7% (supermarket strength)

Rich amber, small persistent head. Lovely sweet fruity hoppy aroma. Some more savoury and spicy aromas too, more like UK hops. Gentle carbonation, smooth palate. Caramelly maltiness, and also a fruity sweetness, augmented with a tasty well balanced bitter hoppiness. Some hints of soap occasionally. Fruity and spicy hoppy finish. A touch sticky alas.  However, it’s a good effort from a US brewer at this strength, better than your average UK bitter.

Bottle. Pours an amber pale ale with a white head.  Nice hoppy body with some fresh grapefruit and pine a milder malty caramel in the background and a thin slick body.  Hints of grass.  Simple but fresh its not bad at all.
Pours a golden color with a nice white head.  has a spicy hoppy smell and taste.  A solid beer that goes down smooth.

Pint at the Brick House Tavern, Downers Grove, IL. Served an orange/amber, with a fair, diminishing off white head, negligible lacing, and much too cold as most of their beers. The aroma was light malt and a hint of grain and meal. The flavor added to these a touch of resiny bitterness to keep it interesting. A moment of closure after a regrettable experience with this beer many summers ago. Palate maturity...or better handling?

I ordered this beer while on a business dinner at Ditka’s in Chicago. The beer was fresh but fairly indescript. A clear beer with a medium level of amber hue and a virtually non-existent head, resulting in nearly no lace. 

The aroma was balanced but very light. It was difficult to detect even the faintest malt or hop. 

The taste was nicely balanced with a typical malt to hop transition. It was also unusually astringent. The finish featured light hop, but was mostly lip smacking dryness. 

Honker’s Ale is an enjoyable beer worthy of another pint if the variety is limited.

Bottle. Creamy good mostly lasting head. Dark yellow colour. Moderate malty and heavy hoppy aroma. herbie and flowery. Moderate bitter flavor. Average heavy biter finish. Creamy palate. Excellent brew.

Bottle.  Pours a amber, brown color with a medium white head.  A nice malty ale and a great hop balance.  Aroma is mostly sweet malts, and the taste follows the great malt and hops balance.  A nice drinking beer with a medium palate.

From draft -  orange/amber with medium off-white head.  Citrus hops aroma.  Well balanced beer and flavorful for me.  Malts are evident, but more hoppy than I expected.  It was the best offering of the night at a fundraiser, and enjoyed it much more than all the Bud products that were offered, including "Hophound".  Finishes mildly bitter and IMO a very good session beer.  Cheers!

slightly cloudy orange, medium haed, some lace.  a touch of mild hops in the nose, mildly hoppy flavor, not near prominant enough for a pale ale.  medium body, dry finish.  a mild but popular entry from goose island.   i sampled this at the millenium bar in the randolph street station (they finally opened a bar there!) awaiting a train to take me home.

slightly cloudy amber, small offwhite head.
malty, caramelly and hoppy aroma, a little sourish flowery too.
flavor is dry and hoppy, sweet malty, caramelly. ends slightly bitter.
Bottle. Medium high and lasting creamy off-white head. Hazy orange body. Fruity hoppy aroma. Well balanced malt hops flavor with a nice bitterness, low carbonation and a long aftertaste.

(Bottled) Hazy copper-golden with a small, firm head and some lace. Citrus-nutty-hoppy aroma with mellow fruitiness and some caramely malt. Citrus-hoppy flavor with woody-nutty-aromatic notes. Light to medium body, quite crisp with pretty low but fizzy carbonation. A quality imitation of English Pale Ales, somewhat reminds me of Bitter & Twisted. Anyway, there’s no point in importing this stuff all the way from the US.

Bottle, 12oz. A slightly hazy, golden body with an orange tint. Finger-thick, diminishing, off-white head. Fruity, slightly citrusy, bready nose in the English way. Quite sweet flavor with bread crusts and citrus. A bit low on bitterness. Medium body, and a pleasant level of carbonation. Bready, citrusy finish with some bitterness. A pleasant beer, well suited for a drinking session. Rating: 6-3-6-3-13-3.1. 090412

Bottle. It pours a clear, at least almost clear, pale amber body and a small off-white head. Some lacings occur. The aroma has pale malts and canned tropical fruits, rather sugar-ish. The flavor confirms that impression, it’s rather sugary sweet, with lots of peaches and a nice backbone of bready malts. Medium body, smooth. Some metallic notes in the else quite balanced finish. Overall, a beer probably more suited for autumnal drinking than for the hot spring days we have here right now. 110426
Clear amber color, with small head. Nice hoppy aroma. Hoppy flavor but a bit watery finish
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are rich hops and flowers with some caramel and some fruits.

12 oz. bottle from local(I’m in Michigan, you can get it anywhere) liquor store. I got this because a friend that’s new to craft beer was hanging out, and I thought this would be good for a beginner. anyways, this poured a darkish amber, with medium off white head, and had a very subtle caramel aroma. The flavor has some hopiness, but also some sweetness on the finish. I am starting to love these "session" beers more and more, really because they seem to be on par with flavor, and you can drink 2 or 3 and still not get into too much trouble. In that respect, this beer is almost perfect. Cheers!
Flaske: Rigtig fin session beer. Orange øl uden så megen karbonering, hvilket trækker ned på mundfylden. Ellers diskret humlesmag med mindre bitterhed end hos en normal APA.

Bottle:  Dull copper color with a finger of creamy beige head.  Aroma is rather earthy, malty, and bready.  Tastes completely different than the smell.  Floral, sweet, lager malts, and some dandelion.  I just don’t like the malt in this.  Gets to be more like premium lager than premium bitter...
Unclear amber, small white head. Aroma is dry hoppy and sweet. Fruity and hoppy, mildly malty taste. Not bad if you are looking for something easily quaffable.

Bottle from Bottle Stop in Bramhall. Slight hazy orange colour, thin white head. Not bad but unremarkable. Malts, little hops, touch of spice and a hint of dark fruits to it. Reasonable and certainly one I’d not steer away from. Depends where I am I suppose, decent.
12oz bottle pours a cloudy golden yellow with a light white head.  Herbal aroma with hints of honey.  Medium body with a very light hop bitterness.  Very thirst quenching.  Nice beer.

Copper color with an off white head. Grainy aroma with a hint of hops. Rich malty body with a sweet buy dry flavor. Has the characteristics of a pale ale but the roasted malts give it a nice balance and the taste is still smooth despite the dry finish.

bottle 33 cl. Small thick beige head that mostly diminished. Clear nutty color. Nice toasted malt and light floral note. Over the palade came peach, fruit, nutty and caramel. Medium bodied with an average carbonation and light dty texture. Moderated sweet flavor light bitterness.toasted nutty and peachy finish.

on tap @ clybourn. clear orange pour with small white head. not sure why some say it is weak on hops.,i found it to be heavy on hops for the style. but this is a great beer. one of the top sellers from goose island.
12 oz bottle .   part of a goose island variety pack.  pours copper color.   sweet, caramel, malt forward pale ale.  light carbonation.   a bit of herbal and citrusy hop notes.   not bad.
Part of a variety pack.  Just a good, drinkable beer.  Nice balance, if weak, of hops, sweetness and malt.  Not something I would buy again.

On tap at O’Hare Airport while waiting for flight.  Pours a relatively clear orange-brown color, with a medium white foamy head. Aroma is floral hops, slight sweetness, touch of toasted malts.  Flavor is a mild hop, light bitter, with a crisp, clean, refreshing finish. Extremely pleasant.

Bottle. A cloudy copper color with a two finger offwhite head . Aroma of spicy hops and a nice sweet toasted  malt. Flavor starts slightly sweet and turns to spicy/piny hops with a mild bitterness. A very clean and fresh mouthfeel and finish. light body, light carbonation. A very nice session beer.

Had on tap at O’Hare while on layover.  Slightly hazy orange-brown color with a thick soapy white head.  Slight grassy hop hint, but definitely malt-forward on the aroma.  Wet grain malt taste, mild hop finish.  Decent, but not much more than that.
Hazy orange. Aroma is weak and smells rustic like the inside of my grandparent’s trailer. Taste is all bitter, with a finish of rice. All respect given to the English Bitter style but....bleh!

Evaluated up against the BJCP.org #14A.
Brilliant clear amber to copper colour with a tan head. Moderate spicy hop Aroma with some maltiness.Medium mouthfeel with some nice sparkling carbonation. The flavor is pleasently hoppy with some nice suttle bitterness at the end. There is a somewhat anonymous malt backbone, but it does support the hops of the beer well. There are some toasted caramel compounds in the flavor and aftertaste.
Overall an over averages example of an English Pale Ale. Well brewed and balanced, but lacking a bit in the maltiness.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours slight cloudy orange with a small,dense and white head. Aroma is dry hoppy, a bit like wet wood. Mild fruity and subdued malty flavoured. Dry and malty finish with a minor sweetness.
Botella. Clear golden amber brown colour. Good malty and hoppy aroma. Good filling mouthfeel. Flavour of bitter hops, caramel and toasted malt. tasty pale ale indeed.
Delicious. Coloring is not that impressive but it provides a nice white head with definite wheat flavors that are not too over powering

Draft. Included as part of a sampler at the brewpub. Tried many of the GI offerings over several visits to the brewpub while living in Chicago. I remembered liking pretty much everything but do not remember specifics.
Brown color, small head.  Has a hoppy aroma.  A good medium body beer. Had it on tap and bottle, bottle is always better.
Bottle at home. Cloudy brown - Small white head. Medium malty, light sweetness, toasted, resin, light spicy, peppery, cookies, medium hoppy, light bitterness, light flowery. Pleasant. Thin finish.
Bottle.  Light to medium brown in color with a small whitish head.  Aroma is very hoppy.  Flavor is very hoppy with a little malt.  A little better than your typical pale ale.
Bottle.  Medium brown color, small head.  Roasted, malts, floral hops with very little hop bitterness. Nice balance. Finish is clean and crisp.

Bottle.  Bottled on date:  12/23/08.  Pours a clear amber with a big and creamy tan head.  Biscuity maltiness, whole wheat bread, caramel, and some grapefruity hoppiness in the aroma.  Fairly thin-bodied and creamy.  TONS of biscuity malts and shortbread upfront taste-wise.  Caramel is in there along with hints of rye.  Finishes with just a bit of drying grapefruitiness.  Crisp at the end.

This is a nice session APA style ale. I would gladly drink this one after mowing the yard or standing around in the heat with freinds on a hot summer day. They got this one right for what its supposed to be, a regular production brew for the masses. On days where I want a fuller brew, or more hop, I will go elsewhere.

330 mL. Pours a clear light copper with a nice IPA-like fluffy white head with semi-good lacing. Aroma of an ESB with English malt, slight dry hops, faint caramel, light citrus, and biscuit. Biscuity flavor with a touch of citrus hops and caramel. Clean, bitter finish. Good session beer.
Copper pour into a shaker. Not much of an aroma. Hops and malts for an unimpressive flavor.  Slight hops flavor at the end. A very crips brew.....make a great session beer. Not very memorable though.
Pours a clear copper body with a nearly non-existent head. Pleasant sweet biscuit with a slightly dry finish. Like stated below, very simple and easy drinking.
Bottled. Light amber in color. Sweet aroma with a good balance of maltiness and hops. Very smooth and simple. Malts with a decent hoppy finish. Quite sessionable.

Pours a cloudy, rusty color.  Hops dominate the aroma.  Flavor is a little spicy/sweet with a nice amount of hops.  Refreshing herbal/hoppy finish.  Enjoyed this very much and one that I’ll buy again.  Very good pale ale.
A good session beer...as far as session beers go. Nice, crisp hop flavor...some citrus and pine. Good malt (no particular flavor stands out). Clean finish...won’t get you too drunk.
on tap. a little bit of hops a little bit of toastiness. this is definitely pretty high on my list.

BOTTLE: at Chris & Rob’s (St. Paul, MN) on 1.24.09. Pours a bronze/amber with an off-white head. Aroma is faint - maybe a little malt. Taste was sweet, malt, a little hop bite, and some citrus. Pretty good.

Has a faint bronze-brown pour with a bit of red, a white and off-white medium head, aromas of toasted malt and bread with some sweetness, a bit of caramel, mild malt flavor with bread, and has some hop bitterness, a little less than medium mouth feel, an ok drink.

Appearance:  Good color typicity; slight haze; above average head (moderate to large) with above average retention

Aroma:  Not much there.  Closed.  Subtle malt.  Little citrus.  

Flavor:  Decent balance.  Good style typicity.  Subtle malt, lemon, and other citrus.  Bitterness picks up leading to the dry finish.

Palate:  Medium bodied.  Pleasant feel.  Little carbonation.

Overall:  Enjoyable, drinkable, nothing special.

Tasted and rated twice.

On tap.  Pour was amber color with little carbonation.  Aroma had a little noticable malt, but mostly nonexistent.  Flavor was citrus, hops and had a nice slightly bitter aftertaste.  A good BBQ beer.
12 oz bottle.  Poured a clear amber/gold with a one finger white head.  The aroma was malty with just a hint of citrus.  The flavor was sweet malt, with fruit and a bitter finish.

Draft at Airport  Pours a good amber with an off white head.  Head lasts for a good time and gives okay lacing.  Sweet malt aroma and good flavor.  Very easy drinking and went well with my Chicago hotdog.
Nice ale, pours a light dark body. Fruity notes that gave it a nice sweet taste. overall not to bad.
Aroma is spicy hops with some sweet malt nores coming through. Appearence is amber with good head retention. Flavour is initial sweet malt  with apple/pineapple notes and pleasent bitter finish.

To me this is a perfect rendition of a traditional English pub ale.  Low carbination, smooth and easy to drink in vast quantities.  As a single pint standalone beer it probably doesn’t the legs to be remarkable, but definitely a beer that can be enjoyed under most any circumstances.  Cheers.

May not be giving this one a fair shake. Actually had it at the Monday night Bear-Packer game. Head quickly froze on the sides of the glass. At that temp, no nose or flavor was evident and the mouthfeel was simply....cold. The 5 percent alcohol was not nearly enough to break thru, although I could have used about 10% or more. I will look to try this one again.
Tried this from a frosty bottle at a party, which is not the best way to rate a beer, but I got a sense of it.  A tasty pale ale.

Poured an amber colro with an off white head. Aroma was nice mlaty and biscuty with hints of hops. Flavor was more bitter than most other english PAs ive tried. Nothing great but wouldnt be a bad session beer.

On tap at David’s Place.  Nothing too crazy in the aroma, but nothing too bad either, with caramel, nutty cookie, and a minor citrus hop.  It was served to me with about an inch of pillowy marshmallow-white head, good lacing throughout, 50-50 opacity, and a caramel-orange color.  The taste contains a decent amount of goose island caramel cookie malt nicely balanced with a good citrus-lemon that lingers nicely.  The beer feels a little too light overall, but it also has a certain crispness to it that I seem to enjoy.  It may not be the best or most exciting beer I’ve ever had, but to me, drinking this beer never seems to get old, and I think that says something.

Bottle. Pours an amber color with a little white head. Leaves some lacing on the side of glass. Smells like malts and weak hops. A good pale ale. A mild hop bite in the aftertaste. A decent beer that started it all for a great brewery!

Bottle. Pours with an amber color. Definitely a beer brewed in the traditional
nglish style with strong caramel aroma and flavor. Flavors of toffee and butterscotch with a medium palate.
very nice well balanced cascade hopped ale. Great starter beer for hop heads.
bottle, brewed on 9/18/08, chestnut colored with faint head, aroma of malt and floral herbal, spicy hop flavor with strong malt undertones, finish a caramelly bitter

12oz bottle.  Hazy orange tan color, looks unfiltered to me.  Lots of English malt character, maybe a pinch of amber malt in the aroma, with a pleasant moderate hop balance.  Malty sweet, medium bodied, subtle crisp hop bite.  An all around good session beer.
Pours a nice copper color from the tap with a crisp white head.  Hoppy aroma with balanced malts and mild apricot in the flavor.  Smooth and highly drinkable.

Pours a deep copper with a small dissipating head. Lots of carbonation.
Aroma is of dark nutty bread with some caramalt and fruit from the yeast.
Medium mouthfeel. Stale malt flavor with typical grassy bitterness for the style that trails off. This easy drinking session beer needs more malt assertiveness. Disappointing.

On tap in Liberal, KS.  Hey, I was just happy to find a place that served decent beer.  Orange amber pour with one finger head.  Floral aroma.  The flavor was caramel sweet malts and some sweet fruitiness and floral hop finish.  Smooth mouthfeel.  I was digging it.
Pours a golden/copper hue with a thin white head. Nice malt/hop balance with this one. Good malt backbone with notes of zesty, citrusy hops. Well balanced, solid brew. Worth a try for sure.
Bottle form Uto. Amber with an off white head and a decent lacing. Sweet and malty with hints of honey and citrusy/ginger hops. Well balanced with a nice bitterness in the finish. Quite sessionable.

Bottle.  Pours golden brown, kinda coppery, with very little head.  Smells rich bread grains and citrusy sweet with some floral hops.  Tastes grainy, like a good bread, sweet, citrusy, piney, and a little fruity.  Aftertaste is bitter but smooth and dry.  A very good beer.

From the bottle, it has a nice clear orange color, med carbonation, small head which shrinks quickly.  The beers aroma has a good toasted and floral scents mixed with some nice citrus notes and ends with a light fruity hints.  Flavor has a nice bread taste, with light citrus middle and a sweet fruity ending.  Very good beer.
Bottle. Aroma of toasted malt, young green melon, grassy hops. Flavor follows suit, perhaps getting a touch fruitier with similarly soft, fleshy fruits. Very nice beer.

Bottle, bottled 6/30/08.  Pours a clear orange with a small white head.  Aroma of toast and crackers.  Flavor of buttery toast, nice toasted malt with a touch of light fruits and floral hops.  Very good EPA, not sure why people don’t like it...lots of toast and slight fruitiness.  Yum!

Bottle, thanks LilBeerDoctor! Pours cloudy copper with a thick pale yellow head. A bit of citrus in the nose, not much else. Medium-light body and moderate carbonation. Some nice peachy toffee in the taste after it warms up a bit. Reasonably dry finish.

Draught @ BA’s in NSC - Poured copper with no head, aroma is malt and malt and metal?...flavour is pretty good, not as malty as the nose would suggest, nice grain presence, decent but fleeting bitterness, a fun beer but there are way better pales out there, we’re getting better...
12 ounce bottle purchased at Archer Liquors in Chicago, IL for $12.99/12-pack. Very good.

(10/9/08) Draught sample at the brewpub in Clybourn, Chicago. 4.3% ABV. Clear amber color. Aroma has some malt, caramel notes and some slightly floral hops. Sweetish malty flavor at first with some toastiness, continues hoppy and bitter with a bit of citrus. Medium-bodied.

bottle from wisconsinbeer, thanks! Deep copper pour, barely any head at all.  Aroma is very malty and some sawdust notes(previous entry below me nailed it!).  Flavor is pretty plain, malty and maybe a bit nutty.  Slight hop profile lends itself to the english style.  Not bad, not amazing.
Nice goldish color with a white head. Tastes pretty malty with some nut and caramel flavor. Very drinkable. One of my favorites.

Pours a copper color with a whitish head that goes away fairly quickly. Tastes of malt and some nutty flavorings. Malt to the nose as well.

 I got this beer in a sampler pack and I think I’ll actually buy this one alone.

Pours a tawny cooper color crowned by a whitish mostly dissapating head. Aroma is malt and nuts. Very creamy on the palate. Malt, nuts and barlley stoke the taste buds while the hops help this ale finish wiith dry satisfaction. Great with ham and cheese on sourdough.

On tap. Pours with a clear amber body and a fluffy, off-white head. Some light fruits, malts and light saw dust. Taste is fruity, malty, with honey and a bit of spiced tea. Very subdued, but a great session. Kind of thin, water like on the mouth with decent carbonation.

(Bottle) I find the high reviews of this beer to be a bit puzzling: I was unimpressed.  The hops are very weak, and not particularly interesting.  Malt is generic.  There’s nothing subtle or complex about this beer, and yet, it’s not terribly refreshing either--it comes across as just a tad heavy, without any real redeeming qualities.  While it’s better than most macros, this beer just doesn’t have much going for it, in my opinion.

12oz bottle-pours a rich off white head and hazy gold color.  Aroma is husky medium malt-some caramel, secondary earthy hops (English).  Taste is husky medium malt-some caramel/some sweetness, secondary earthy hops (English).  3.3
This beer is a deep copper color, and has a good bitter hop finish without getting rid of some good malt character.  Very tasty.

mmm....good drinking beer.  This is like....what you drink when you want a straight ahead beer.  Nothing fancy, just good.  It is a very nice rich color, but not too light or dark.  The head is smooth and the carbonation just right.  Goes great with food and doesn’t overpower anything.

Just nice.  Very well done.  I’m digging this hometown brew.  Hooray Chicago beer!
From bottle. Aroma of hops, hint of spice and malt. Copper in colour with a good white head. Flavour was of hops and honey. Well balanced, good bitterness and flavoursome. Pleasant IPA.

From bottle : Pours a very caramel color, with a thin white head, and somewhat hazy.  A sweet citrus hop smell comes from this one.  Taste is very nice a mellow, i was expecting a sharp stinging taste from the aroma.  Very mellow and smooth, with hints of the citrus hops and some malts toward the end.  Medium body and a smooth feel in the mouth.  Aftertaste is of piney hops, and it lingers a little.

Summary: Citrus and pine hops balance well with sweet caramel malts.  Maybe a little too sweet, but well done.  Aroma: Pronounced pine and grapefruit hops.  A little sweet malt slips though. Appearance: Hazy amber-brown.  A finger-thick off-white head dissipates quickly and leaves minimal lace. Flavor: Grapefruit and coniferous hops segue to caramel and toasty, bready malts.  Finishes piney and sweet. Palate: Smooth, somewhat sudsy on the tongue.
A good beer worth having if the IPA isn’t available.  Smooth with lots of flavor.  Not as hoppy as I like, but good balance.
Bottle, 4.3%. Clear amber colour, small stable white head. Very caramelly aroma. Teaish, almost to the point of Swedish snuff. Caramelly flavour, also a bit teaish. Quite flavourful for ABV.
