Pours a copper orange color with no head.  Smells of orange and some citrus from the hops.  Medium body.  Tastes primarily of citrus with a nice leafy hops finish.  Not to bitter, overall very solid.

Pours a dark auburn in color.  Decent inch of head sitting atop.  Smell is mostly hops.  Taste is bitter.  Not a hoppy bitter, just a different bitter.  Lots of malt in this beast.  Medium feel in the mouth and decent.  Not a beer that I’ll revisit.
Very drinkable pale ale. Good balance of hops and malt that finishes with a creamy ending.  Worth trying again.

I’ve never understood why this is their flagship beer. As an American, the IPA is just worlds beyond the Honkers. I’m not saying Honkers is bad, quite the contrary. It’s a nice, sweet and creamy ale that is easily accessible in my area. In fact, now that I think about it, this is definitely the best beer available in most gas stations. Even if your not from Chicago, if you see it, be sure to give it a try.

From the bottle to my imperial pint, this malty sweet English bitter style beer has a bittersweet, mapley malt toastedness that’s skillfully balanced by well integrated grainy, lightly spicy, bitter hop flavors.  The creamy smooth mouthfeel that follows becomes stickly sweet as the beer warms and the hops mellow out.  It’s full on malt presence returns mid-glass with a hint of honey and brown sugar surprising the palate.  Very well-crafted, and an excellent example of a highly quaffable pub bitter, G.I. Honkers Ale finishes with hints of sticky, chewy caramel.

From a draft pout at Charlies Ale House in Munster, IN.  This came an Amber color with off-white head. Smooth and rich mouthfeel. Flavor is well balanced between caramel malts and light floral hops Good slightly bitter finish. Goes down easy Decent brew.
hops & earthiness on nosing. beer looks good in the glass, flavor is nicely balanced between malt & hops, finishes, long & clean

Pours bland amber color with a small off-white head. Aroma of musty, minerally yeasty, malt. Flavor is very malty, and sweet yeasty. Mouthfeel is a bit sour but has a lot of carbonation. Aftertaste is flat, but fizzy mouthfeel remains. It laces the glass well.

Poured from bottle (8/2008).  Aroma of French toast, some hops, a bit of gas.  Medium dark cloudy amber, thin head.  Not overly hopped, the malt and hops both stand out nicely in flavor. Slightly thin, but very drinkable.  Very good English style bitter.
Nice cloudy orange-gold appearance, but not the most pleasing aroma. Flavor is fruit-floral-grass along with the fairly distinctive hops and malt. Strange, but hardly boring.

16 ounce pint on tap at Chicago O’Hare airport.  This rating was found on the back of the receipt from the airport in my carry on bag.  It is from September 13th, 2006 at 1:09pm.  This was during a notorious 4 hour layover at O’Hare----Malty, nutty, caramelly aroma with some buttery diacetyl hints as well.  Some light floral hoppiness is also present.  Quaffable enough.  Transparent copper-amber color with a frothy off-yellowish head.  Nice head retention and lacing for being poured in a clear plastic cup!  Unfortunately, this is overly carbonated and overly cold.  Burnt, toasted, nutty, cereal-like maltiness is present to start.  Turns mildly sweet with a light, floral, spicy hop finish.  Would be more enjoyable if this was initially served at the proper temperature with the correct carbonation.
Bottled. Amber colour, small white head. Aroma is fruits, wood and strong fruityness. Flavour is US hops along with some grassy and mild spicy notes.

Drank this one at the lakehouse in Northern Michigan, which always seems to have a good supply of Goose Island beers. Up in the light, the beer is a dark golden yellow-orange, with the proper haze for the style and a thick white head. The citrus hop aroma is inviting, not overpowering. The flavor, particularly the middle, is medium-bodied and slightly more malt than hopes, and the palate is solid from front to back. Overall, a very balanced and drinkable pale ale. I think I’ll have another!

Luss, Scotland.
Bottled. 250708.
Amber - white head. Aroma of caramel and bread. Flavor hoppy with a little bitterness.

There was just nothing to this beer. The smell was very light, almost nonexistent. The flavor was very bland and lasted only a short second. Absolutely no aftertaste. I was extremely disapointed by this brew.
Bottle bought in Chicago. Aroma is sweet toasty notes and caramel. The taste is a smooth and crisp malt with a touch of hops and some bitterness. A very nice EPA, smooth and a crisp hop bite.
Clear amber with medium white head. Sweet fruity aroma with caramel and hoppy notes. Sweet flavor with pine,caramel,hops and grapefruit notes. Ends bitter.

drank at Old Chicago, Omaha-NE. Copper body with medium foamy, aroma is roasted malty and some sweet and fruit notes, Flavor is sweet, but some bitterness could be percepted. Mouthfeel has some balanced bitterness and swetness.
Bottle. Pours orange with a small head. Aroma is sweet and fruity. Flavour also sweet and fruity and a bit grainy.
Clear amber, nice long lasting head, strong notes of hops, grapefruit, spices, flower, some caramalt. Mainly bitter and bitter finish.

Body is dark yellowish brown with very little head. The aroma is sweet like a mixture of honey, flowers, lemon and orange. The flavor is fairly sweet as well, but kind of watery tasting without a whole lot of carbonation (might just be the tap) . There is a malty flavor with a bit of orange and lemon. Not much hops.

courtesy of Toni Flükiger - slightly hazy amber-orange colour, solid and firm pale beige head; aroma of cream and herbs; low carbonation, very smooth mouthfeel, low bitterness; creamy flowery finish - gentle and inoffensive

12oz. bottle at Table Rock. Pours a copper color with slight haze and a thin mostly diminishing white head that left light lacing. Aroma and flavor of roasted malt and spicy hops. Light body, not too watery texture, lively carbonation, and excellent light bitter and dry mouthfeel. A slightly above average beer, but for 6.99 a sixer in Branson, MO. this was gold.

Touch of biscuit and yeast in the aroma.  Pours a caramel colored amber, with a thin, quickly fading head.  Touch of sweetness balanced out by clean, crisp hops.  A fantastic session brew, and a good introduction beer.
On Draft at Pizzeria UNO in Chicago.  Pours amber with white head - good lacing.  Nose is caramel with mild hops.  Taste is caramel with a touch hop bitterness and mild floral hops.

Nothing spectacular, but quite good.  Pours a dark gold with a thick off white head.  Sweet malty caramel and a bit of grass evident in the light aroma.  Medium-bodied and very smooth.  The malty sweetness is present up front with notes of caramel.  Finsishes clean but with just a touch of hoppy bitterness.  An easy drinking, tasty brew.

Appearance: Light brown, a bit of head, not longlasting.
Aroma: Malty, fruity.
Taste: Malty, a bit fruity, pretty smooth.
Info: 355ml bottle, 26/10-2005, 40/300
It’s aight.  Along with Sam Adams Boston Lager as just an incredibly drinkable brew.  Nothing too complex or exciting, but tasty and yummy.  Yummy factor is a plus.

Had this while between flights at Chicago Midway.  Pours a coppery amber supporting a small but surprisingly dense light tan head.  Initial aroma of fresh cut grass with hints of citrus zest, toast and maybe a little toffee.  Flavor is pretty straightforward and conservatively hopped with caramel, a touch of milk chocolate and some vanilla bouncing around every now and then.  Fairly thin texture but not watery and moderately dry, slightly bitter finish.  Not a bad brew for killing some time in an airport but with establishments like the Map Room in town, I’m surprised at the generally weak selection of beers at this airport.
Golden-amber with white, sticking head.  Orange-citrus, floral, and mild caramel aroma notes.  Citrus, mild caramel, grapefruit, and mild biscuit flavour notes.  Medium bitter finish.

Bottle. Copper with a thin white head.  Citrus and caramel aroma with slight spice.  Sweet and floral up front that leads to a malty bready finish.  My first trip to the windy city and overall it’s a good beer.

Golden yellow to amber with a thin white head. Aroma of mild citrus, caramel and grassy hops.  Malted body has a mild bitter finish and not a whole lot of flavor with mild caramel preceding a citrus hop finish.

Color of an old penny.  Hard to judge the head because it was served with a clear plastic cup to pour the bottle into.  That being said, it made a small, rapidly dissipating head and left a little lacing on the plastic cup.  Malty nose with a slight fruitiness.  Nice balance of simple malts and hops in the flavor with a bitter hop finish.  Had I not known the type, and been asked to guess, I’d have guessed ESB, and a pretty good one at that.

Copper appearance with a full, quickly dissipating light beige head that leaves little lacing behind. Aroma is sweet caramel malts with some honey presence.  Nice sweet malty flavor with a hearty nutty/bread palate. Nice balance.

On tap. Poured a medium amber with a two inch yellow head. First smell was sweet and malty. Mouthful was fairly thin, and seemed almost a bit watered down. Decent enough lager(thats how it tasted to me, as I didn’t read it described as a pale ale) with mellow hop in the front and malty  kind of sweet finish. Had some wheat qualities to it.
Bottled. Tasting @ Kolding Bryglaug. Aroma is floral, grauny and has honey in it. Clear, golden-copper coloured with a thin, white head. Taste is sweet, floral with some fruitiness. Okay.
>Golden with a small white head. Aroma has citrus, apricot, and pilsner malt. Thin and grainy, sweetish flavour.

Very nice aroma poured out of the bottle on this one, flowers and spices from the hops.  Looks to be bottle conditioned so that is a plus!  Quality session brew, and quite a good clone of a british ale for an american brewery ;)
On Tap,  Decent beer.  Excellent flavor for an English pale ale.  I will add more to the decription once I get a hold of an actual bottle of the stuff.
Bottle @ thewolf-and-his-flock-of-sheep tasting session. Aroma of hop, bit floral. Bitter and bit grainy taste.

On Tap at a White Sox Game.  Excellently refreshing considering I thought I was going to settle for regular cheap beer at not a cheap price.  actually this  beer was free thanks to the gentleman in front of me who said he worked for goose Island and bought my girlfriend and I beers.  nice combination of fruits
Bottle@Thewolf,tasting. Pours clear copper/amber with a small white head. Aroma has bread/caramel & hops. Mouthfeel is soft & ok. Hardly no bitterness & rather boring!

Pours a light copper with a medium off white head that fades fast. Medium malt aroma, caramel, biscuit, light toffee fruit (that fades with the head) and pepper hop aroma.
Well balanced malt flavour and dry fruity hop finish

Pours a clear amber colour with a small tan head.  Decent lacing, noticeably nutty character but generous on the hops. Mouthfeel is firm and astringent. Aroma is of caramel, nuts and grass. Finishes dry.

Bottle @ thewolfs pre-festival tasting, Kolding.
[thank you, Chris_o]
Pours clear copper with a fine, creamy film head. Aroma is softly hoppy, but not much else. Okay mouthfeel. Flavour is also softly hoppy, okay sweet malty, but only low bitterness. Very dull.

[i] [b] Bottle picked up from Westholm, Londis, Goring-on-Thames, Oxon consumed this evening 17-05-08 [/i] [/b] Mid amber thin white head, some soapy hops. Refreshing beer, I agree with the commercial description this is quite english in style, reasonably well balanced bitter/sweet flavours, light fruitiness, just wish it had bit more panache.

12 oz. bottle. slightly spicy aroma. pours adarkish cloudy orange. a little bitter but not much. kinda like a very light weight IPA. light on the palate but overall a very drinkable beer. nothing to really distinguish it though.

Medium, lightly roasted, malt aroma. Copper color with a reluctant beige head. Medium bodied with mild, near creamy carbonation. Starts with light, fruity sweetness. Quickly followed by a very decent amount of hop. Flavor tends to go a bit watery, but it recovers. Finish has hints of sweet fruit, some peppery spice notes, and a good amount of bitter. Finishes dry. Seems more APA than EPA, but it’s very enjoyable.

Draft from the Goose Island Brewery beer stand in terminal 2 @ O’Hare. Orange in the class with a frothy off-white head that lasted and left light lacing. Sweet & spicy aroma with a hint of citrus. The flavor seemed to have an orange citrus mixed with some malts. Sweet up front with a light bitter ending. Medium body and smooth carbonation. (Rating from 14 Mar 08)
12oz bottle spicy grassy aroma, a very interesting flavor thats deferent than most ales
Bottle. Pours a light amber with a good amount of head. As far as pale ales go, it’s fairly average, with some notable malt and hops coming through in aroma and taste. A decent beer but very average.

Bottle, Beers of Europe. Muddy orange amber colour, thin whiteish head. Sweetish mandarin aroma. Some fruit and hops in the flavour, but at 4.3% lacking any real clout. Vaguely above average I ’spose.
12 oz bottle from acknud! Nose of grassy hops, grain, and an off note; clear copper with a big beige head; flavor has caramel, some light hop bitterness, and a bit of peppery spices.

Pours a reddish golden color with a nice inch of head at the top. 

Smells primarily of hops with some light underlying notes of citrus.

The hops, while still present, are a bit more mellow in the mouth; the notes of citrus are a bit more prominant on the tongue than the nose.

A bit watery in the mouth, but a smooth drink. Definately worth multiple purchases.

Serving type: bottle

(Bottle, Monk’s Café, Stockholm, 14 April 2008) Dark amber colour with frothy, beige head. Malty nose with notes of dried fruit, hops and rosehip cream. Malty taste with dark fruit, grain, rose-hips, nuts (almond) and a balanced bitterness in a toasty finish. Well balanced, very much in the English direction.

Pours caramel like body with frothy head.  Looks quite nice.  However, the aroma is a little more sad.  Smells of pine hops, but not necessarily good,  The flavor is easy, but it’s not interesting.  It’s carbonated well.  Overall, there’s nothing bad about this beer, but there’s nothing interesting with this beer.  I’m just bored.
Hmmm pretty boring. Little bit of vomit in the aroma. Fairly sweet. The hops in the flavor are pretty decent. Vomit is in the taste too.
Draught at The Cheesecake Factory, Skokie, Illinois. Served way too cold but once it warmed up, it was a fine beer. It had a nice spicy and grassy aroma with a flavour of orange rind and hops.
Bottle.dark amber with a medium head,aroma of light sweet malt,taste is sweet malty and hoppy with a dry fin.

Orange-gold pour with a 1 finger, white head.  Aroma is doughy, earthy, grassy with notes of orange and pine.  Lots of chewy malt flavor with some notes of toast, slight caramel, and a grassy hop finish.  Medium thin body, lots of carbonation and a dry finish.
Pours a cloudy burnt gold/amber with a thin layer of head. Aroma is very earthy and hints of grain. Flavor is hops, undertones of caramel and floral. Body is light  with a fair amount of carbonation.

pours a slightly hazy amber, thin white head.  A slightly grassy aroma.  A nice hint of caramel and malt up front; quite a bit of hops in the finish, but there’s a bit of cardboard quality to it.  Starts good, finishes a bit unpleasant.
Bottled. My former local brew is amber in colour with a floral aroma and a sweet flavour balanced by citrus hops including hints of orange. Pretty good.
35,5cl bottle @ home. Dark amber colour, little white lace.very malty nose with a bit of hop. Bit bitter and really not much else, sorry.

Bottled at Monks Café, Stockholm. Pours out in a clear pale amber colour with a low creamy white foam. Fruity and caramely aroma of mandarin, floral hops and grass. Medium-bodied. Caramel, straw, raspberry jam, flowers and mild orange-peels in the flavour. Rather clean mouth feel. Medium bitter finish of red berries, resin and wet grass. Pretty nice one.
Pours a nice brown with off white head.  Smells of roasted coffee beans, and tastes delicious.  Some caramel, but mostly hops with a pleasantly bitter aftertaste.
Easy to drink, not exactly a risky beer.  Not as hoppy as a true pale, but still has some bite.  Living in the Chi I will obviously drink more, but I wont be going out of my way for it.
Draught in Chicago.  Amber colored with a white film on top and some lacing.  Almost no aroma.  The flavor was caramel and sweet hops.  Decent.
Draft.  Pours amber in color with white head.  Has a malty begining and a nicely balanced but hoppy finish.

ehh. thats the review and the sentiment.  not much to write here.  its true that its well balanced and a good introduction to the apa which can kill newcomers with overt hoppiness but it just doesnt do much for me.

Pours a translucent amber with a thin white head.  Mild aroma, with just a little bit of hops.  The flavor is well balanced with just a little bit of hops and malt.  It has a little bitterness to it.  Goose Island’s basic brew, they have much better stuff.

Bottle. Poured a slightly cloudy rich amber with a nice off-white head that would leave a fair amount of lacing. The aroma was a nicely balanced malt and hops sensation, if a bit underpowered. A good easy flavor just barely sweet upfront with a light bitter finish that lingers gently. It is smooth with a barely perceptible tingle in the mouth. Overall it is a nice balanced beer, easy to drink,

Pours a nice amber with a thick white head. Smooth malt aroma with a touch of hops. Taste is malty with a nice splash of hops. Very tasty version of an english pale, but has a burst of west coast hops.

Great Chicago classic. Nice amber color, white head. The aroma is sweet malt and hops. Taste is caramel well-balanced with some hops, delicious. My only gripe is I wish it had a little more carbonation. If your girlfriend drags you out to some bar, and they have Honker’s Ale, well, you can’t go wrong.
On tap at Patton Ally Pub. Pretty solid English pub ale. I was expecting a little more hopiness to the beer, but it was dominated by the sweet malt flavor. Not a bad beer.

A golden ambler color with a thin white head. The nose is hoppy, hints of yeast and malt. The taste is hoppy with a fresh balance of yeast and malt. The finish is clean and quick a very good ale from Goose Island
Poured amber gold with a thin whitish head. Balanced hops and malts.  surprisingly good.
on tap.  Amber with a thin white head.  Light hop aroma with sweet malts.  Flavor is muldly hoppy with caramel malt and bread.  Slightly bitter,  easy drinking.

Bottle from mixer pack from West Lakeview Liquors, Chicago.  Clear amber with medium off-white head, nice lacing  Aroma is very fresh soft malt and spicy hops.  Caramel flavor with slight pine and noble hops, very nice.  Medium to full body and creamy.  Very fresh tasting but not the most interesting beers in the world.
This a a decent ESB.  It has a pleasant aroma and a dcent hop bite to it.  It pours brown and doesnt have an overpwering aroma, but it is there nonetheless.
An average ESB for the common man.  You can find this at O’Hare at Chili’s, FOX Sports bar/grill.  A better alternative than the BMC options.  Nothing great, but decent.
pours amber, orange, with a off white head witharomas of malts and hops with a taste of the same
This if a very good beer, and is very popular in Chicago.  I had it on tap and from a bottle and it is always good.
first i taste nothing not bad but bam lite pale ale then some dry hops maby some spices. smell is light i drank it out of a bottle so i did not see color. over all good.A++
amber/brown in color and easy to drink.  goose island makes good beer - great hop/malt combination.

bottle poured a medium amber in color with good initial carbonation leaving a one finger head of white froth on the surface. aroma has sharp hops, peach sweetness, caramel malt, and a little must in a nice way. mouth feel is medium light but very smooth. flavor has less hops than the aroma led on, good malt balance, slides across the tongue really easy and finishes on the dry side with hops and reminds me of a frothy unsweetened iced tea. really nice drinker (i keep coming back to this) my second from this brewery and both have been good so far.
good coper color.  nice head that dissipates slowly.   Flavors of  bread, malt with a decent hit of hops.  Not as hoppy as i like, but a good hop flavor.  great easy to drink hoppy ale.

Bottle. Copper color with good white head and nice lacing on glass. Very nice aroma of malt, hops and biscuit. Flavor of biscuit, malt and a good bit of hop bitterness. Good mouthfeel. I thought this was an excellent beer. Loved the hoppiness.
Decent ale with medium to low hoppiness.  Poured medium dark golden with white head.  Light citrus in aroma.  Overal decent, ok, beer.  Probably won’t buy again.

Good for what it is, Honker’s Ale is a pleasing choice for when I’m really not sure what to drink: Head back to what got me in to craft beer and have something nice and simple with just a little character. A light spicy hop mixes with some bread and funk  to create a subtle aroma. The taste was a nice, smooth malt tone with notes of light fruit, biscuit, yeast and soft carbonation. Good session beer.

Aroma was faint and kind of had the dull citrus if english hops, and a bit of malt on the end the had a sour character.  the beer poured a dark gold heading towards amber, with a head the stayed on top and laced nicely.  Flavor was a dry maltiness with dull earthy citrus hops, with a slight english yeast character.  medium light palate very easy to drink.  Overall and alright beer, but it lacked real character, nothing jumped out about it and told me that I needed to have another one, it was just rather dull.
nothing really special to say about this. Drinkable but doesn’t stand out as anything fantastic

Poured a dark orange color with decent white head that stayed a while and left good lacing.  Has a nice spicy hop aroma to it.  Flavor is a nice blend of hop spicyness and maltiness.  Mouthfeel is a velvety pleasantness.  I really enjoyed this beer and would have again.  Drinkability is high.

Washed copper color with thick cream colored head.  Aroma is slightly acidic with a bit of spice. Very nice smell.  Taste is very clean.  Distinct presence of hops but not overpowering.  Hops stick around for the finish.  Not at all a bad beer.
Typical ale with nothing special. Aroma is borderline lager. Flavor is good with a little bittering in the finish.
Quite malty aroma. This is pretty nice. Malty with a solid aftertaste, mostly of a light hop and grassiness. Decent.

this is an earthy brew indeed. bright and mildly hoppy this english style ale is velvety and nicely sweet with a decent malt backbone. hop aroma somewhat piney and well recessed this is the type of brew to sit back with and perhaps follow up with a honkers ipa.

12 oz bottle.  Golden copper and clear with decent creamy off white head.  Aromas of citrus.  Orange and tangerine.  Some mango.    Flavors were more malty but still domiated by hops.  Not as fruity though.  Some earthiness, and toches of grass.  Not bad for a style I’m not a big fan of.

Bottle. Unclear medium amber color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, wheat, moderate to heavy hoppy, orange / grapefruit, light yeasty. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (281207)
A decent beer.  Had some maltyness and very little hops.  Smooth, not too special, but didn’t suck.
Its a good beer.  I had a couple for the holidays.  It is more malty than hoppy, but the hops character balances the taste.  Smooth, crisp, and delicious cold.

Bottle @ Microbar, november 07. Clear, light copper color with a medium, creamy, white head. Caramel, cereal arome with some toffee notes. Caramel, toffee flavor with some nutty notes and an almond finnish. Medium palate, a lot of chewy malts going on but a bit troubled and without harmony. Rather short aftertaste. A nice, dark, malty pale ale.
Pours a golden amber color with a thick frothy head.  Aroma is slightly hoppy, little bit of citrus fruit, and grain.  Light caramel taste with a slight bitter finish.  Drinkable brew.

Pale golden pour; lazy white ring on the rim.  Watery honey and maple syrup aroma with light biscuits and sweetcorn.  Lots of tepid wheat grass and green tea bitterness in the somewhat timid flavor; some light, zesty lemon notes and wet foliage layering an earthy mulch underneath.  Apples, pears, and other easy to ignore fruit flavors lend a bit of liveliness here and there.  Sparkly, light bodied and very gracious on the palate; laid back and comfortable.  Muted sweetbread, biscuity yeasts and soft dirty hops in a fairly lasting finish; pleasant.  Cold and highly carbonated it’s nice, but not especially fulfilling; cask treatment at room temperature might coax out the lovely british character that seems to rest somewhere in the background here and allow it to really shine.

Bottle at home ... amber ... very bright hop little spice ... right after the flying dog pale ale this one isnt hitting the mark ... agin its too fizzy ... lots of hop fruit up frount but a bit rough. the balance just isnt right....

Pours copper 2 finger head, aroma is of hopsand something I cant fully describe...notiiceable, almost white wine like (sileage, if you have ever smeeled the fermented grain that cows eat, you know what I mean, not reallt bad but not the most apetising). Flavor is ..... well balanced, inoffensive but not terribly good. Somewhat sour, too little hops and too much sour malt for my taste in An English Pale. Somehow still very drinkable.  I really like Goose Island and I really like this beer, but there is something about it that keeps me from buyin it more often even though it is the most available goose Island variety in my area,

Dark amber pour, no bubbles, with a large sudsy white head.  Very clean faint aroma of hops with a hint of sour malt.   Very sweet malt in good balance with the hops, slightly buttery. Some bitter in the finish.  The body is very watery...has a little pop to it the in the very smooth crisp carbonation.  No stickiness at all.  This is one very drinkable pale, a lite version.

Not a huge fan of this beer. It is somewhat malty, somewhat hoppy, somewhat not good for some reason.  Its blend is ok, the complexity lacks, and the flavors are muddled.  I didn’t find this refreshing but didn’t find it terrible either.  There are much better from goose island

Poured from a bottle for Thanksgiving dinner. Pours a nice lighter bronze color with a soapy head that dissipates. Smellls of malts and hops. A nice malty taste that fades into a good hoppy finish. Nothing super special about this beer, but I really enjoy it. One of my favorite session beers and the beer that put me on the path to beer exploration.
on tap at gio’s pub.  hazy, organe color with a nice white head.  a little caramel taste, but not overly complex.  drinkable, good beer.

Bottle. Light caramel smell, moderate pine and herbs for the hops and a light earth note. Head is frothy white the has fair lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is hazy orange/tan. Flavor starts lightly acidic and a little sour, then finishes lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is dry, light to medium and has a lively carbonation. A little bland in taste, but a nice claen, dry finish makes this beer.
Hazy bronze colour with thin white head. Mild hop tatse but finish with slight metalic mouthfeel.

This is a tasty, satisfying, solid ale.  It is amber with a thin offi-white head that dissipates steadily.  The aroma is malty grain, yeasty dough, and a hint of sawdust and pine.  The taste has both malt and hops noticeable, with some sweetness and bitterness, a somewhat bitter finish before a nice grain aftertaste.  The flavours improve and rellow blend together nicely after the first couple tastes and it’s great to drink over time.  Ultimately, it’s a solid, smooth, tasty, easily drinkable beer with a solid ale character.  The taste is similar to a good English bitter but with a slightly less rich/complex malt character and slightly more hop character.
10-19-07 bottle.  Malty, doughy metal aroma.  Deep amber color with decent head.  Very carbonated.  Medicinal metallic finish which coats the tongue.  Drinkable but not my favorite.

Draft – Dark amber with a creamy white head. Aromas were of soft toasted caramel malt with faint notes of citrus and chocolate.  Light citric hops bitterness balances over lesser notes of toasted chocolate.  Light bodied, medium carbonation, soft malty finish.  Drinkable, but just not a whole lot going on here...

bottle.....appearance: cinammon brown with a thin white head....aroma:  light on the citrus hop while also having a mild malt contingent....taste: clean citrus hops, light on the bitter scale w/ a crisp clean finish.  needs a bit more flavor overall but very sessionable.
Consumed a few BFB’s of this at Gin Ricks. A nice, mildly hoppy pale ale, very drinkable. Smooth, lightly bitter, good stuff.
Golden amber pour.  Small white head.  Aroma and taste of toasted caramel malts.  Medium citrus hops finish.

12 oz bottle pours an amber with a tall white head.  Toasted malts, caramel, and toffee in the nose.  Similar flavors with a touch of nuts, grapefruit citrus, and pine.  Sessionable.  A nice example of an English Pale Ale as Goose Island has done with many of their early balanced English styles.
Simple, easy to drink weak ale.  Not a huge amount of flavor besides hints of carmel and a hint of bitter in the finish.
This went down VERY fast!! It s aroma was fantastic and tasted much better than I had thought it would. Smooth and crisp. A lingering after taste was quit pleasant.

Bottle sampled. Pours a dark copper color with a beigh head. Aroma of toasted malts, caramel, and english hops. Flavor is lightly sweet and very smooth with caramel malts and some citrus with a light bitter hop finish.

Nice copper color with excellent clarity. Notes of caramel malt.The hops in this seem really low. The only thing English about this beer is that it tastes old and oxidized even though the best before date is neary 5 months away.

Everything about this is subtle but nice. Aroma shows the characteristic malt, but is so subdued you have to stick your nose in it. Lightly hopped and crisp, this goes down nicely as a session should.

Bottle at Delirium Café, Gothenburg. Amber red color with white head. Sweet aroma of toffee, caramel, butter, spices and light citrus. The taste is sweet with notes of toffee, fudge, caramel, butter, fruits, and light roasted malt. Light bitterness. Smooth and highly drinkable.
Not bad, good session beer.  Easy to drink, a little bit bitter on the finish.  Crisp, hints of malt/caramel.  Not too much hops.  Standard.

Very lightly hazed amber pour with a light off white head that provided nice lacing.  Smell is sticky toffee like malt at first, then some metal, and light hops only at times.  Taste was a bright lemony, sticky caramel like malt.  Not overly heavy with malt, but not very hopped either.  Some nice light finishing bitterness, a hint of metal, a touch of fresh citrus to it.  Pretty good, considering I don’t generally like the English Pale Ales.  Best of the style I’ve had, and I could drink this again.
Pours a light orange golden amber with a medium beige head.  Aroma of faint floral hops and funky caramel nuts.   Taste is faintly floral hoppy with hints of caramel and nuts.  Average.
I was surprised with the color, A nice ale with a hint of fruit. The flavor not to overpowering. I was surprised overall and will buy a 12 pack again.

A decent EPA. Aroma of slight hops and some caramel but it’s hard to pick out. Pour was a nice amber with barely a head. Taste was dry and lightly carbonated. Mostly malt in the beginning with a nice bit of grassy hops in the aftertaste. The flavor was short lived and light. Not terrible, but this isn’t the Goose’s best beer.
Not one of my favorite of the goose island beers but still good. amber red with a good smooth taste and a bitter ending. Go Cubbies.

12oz bottle - Poured a amber red color with medium white head.  Aroma is floral hop. A nice malt and hop taste a a medium mouthfeel. Nice lacing on glass as I drank. Overall a really good beer with smooth flavor with nice hop flavored aftertatse. My first Goose Island and will not be my last.
Kind of a mellow pale ale.  Halfway between an English and American pale ale.  Nice all around.

Bottle.  Pours cloudy golden amber with a thin white head.  Aroma is fruity, maybe some orange coming through and some spices.  Taste is well balanced between the malt and hops, seems to be a little malty for me, again I get an orange Kool Aid taste.  Little bitterness, medium body.  Went well with pizza.

Had this beer on 6/23/2000.  Aroma is a dry, roasted malt scent.  Color is a golden brown with good carbonation and head.  Taste malty, slightly sour and bitter.  Starting with light body that goes down crisp.  Finish is a lightly roasted malt flavor followed by a light hop flavor and good bitterness.  It’s smooth, fruity and just plan good.

12oz bottle.  Pours dark amber with a nice white head.  Aroma is malty, sweet, honey, pretty balanced.  Taste is sweet, malty, caramel, slightly bitter. Medium bodied.  This really hit the spot for some reason.  Not the best beer or even one of my favorite styles but I found this to be really surprising.  Well made.  Good stuff.

355 ml (12 fl oz) bottle, bought at Peckham’s, Glasgow. ABV is 5.0%. Amber colour, large to moderate head with an orange hue. Nice sweetish aroma of malts and plenty of fruity hops, hints of molasses. The flavour is surprisingly short, some fruity hops but a moderate bitterness, biscuity notes.

I ordered this from the tap at a restaurant in Kenosha WI.  Pours a darkish color.  Not sure what beer the commercial description is aiming for, but it’s not this one.  No aroma, barely any flavor -- almost all malt.  Not sure I’d try it again.

I was dubious when told this was the most popular beer at the popular Chicago restaurant I was visiting. But this is a pleasant surprise. I can’t comment on the color, as this was served in a bottle. Nice spicy and fruity hops aroma, gentle carbonation, slightly yeasty. Sits medium on the palate with a slight, gentle, tinny hop taste. Dry malt adds to sweetness. There is taste of orange peel. Finishes with slight bitterness that quickly leaves.
I like this beer its very pleasant to drink.  it has an amber color, a fruity hops smell, not much head, and a sweet taste
Yellow amber color, decent head.  Malty and hoppy with a short finish.  Kind of boring

Poured from the bottle into a pint glass.  Produced a clear ale with an amber-orange body with no head (perhaps because of my pour and the cold temperature of the beer.)  The aroma was a clean, crisp hops.  First taste provided medium to heavy bitterness which lingered throughout the tasting.  The  overall body of the ale was clean, medium bodied with a bitter, metallic aftertaste which diminished quickly.   The "rich malt middle" provided in the commercial description was not evident, though I have found that a pale ale’s malt notes develop as it reaches room temperature.

Date: 11/07/1997

Mode: Firkin

Source: Brewfest, Real Ale Festival



dark amber, pleasant floral hop aroma, sweet malt flavor, nice hop flavor, (styrian goldings single hop varietal)

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Date: 09/07/2002

Mode: bottle

Score: iii



amber, thin white head, sweet malt with pleasant fresh hop aroma, dry malt flavor, nice low bitterness leading to a bitter finish

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Date: 04/29/2005

Words: Charlie’s Ale House

Words: Munster



boaring, but in context it was after the the 3F dark lord release



Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20

Rating: 3.6/5.0
Score: ***/4

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

I’m not a huge fan of APAs, but this one is OK in my book.  It doesn’t have the overwhelming, brutal, hoppy bitterness characteristic of the type, but it isn’t timid either.  Well balanced and suitable for long evenings chatting with friends.

Bottle: Poured a cloudy dark beige color ale with a medium foamy head with good retention and some good lacing. Aroma of dry malt with some English hops. Taste is also dominated by some malt presence with a dry finish from what I believe are English hops. Body was quite full with some good carbonation. A bit too dry for my liking but very enjoyable nonetheless.

12oz bootle wife got for me in Wi. Aroma of sweet malt and spice. Dark golden body with off white head. Flavor has a spicey dryness but along with that you get a tolerable sweet juciy malt mix. Also some lemon citric acid in there as well. Complex beer but a decent one.

When I pop the lid, I thought yeasty, but there is some choco aroma in there someplace.  It pours looking like a dunkel weizen, light brownish and cloudy. Taste certainly has hop preservative in there. I also get a hint of chocolate passing thru to the taste. Hey this is not APA, it’s EPA! This is right there with other English Pale ales, on par with 	Ottos Mt. Nittany Pale Ale, 	Great Divide Denver Pale Ale and 	Spanish Peaks Black Dog Ale.
English hops and malt in the nose, golden body, small white head. Maybe EKG and Fuggles: herbal, grassy hops with a bit of fruitiness. Mild body, refreshing, nicely balanced, under-rated here.
This beer gets max appearance because they have cool beer taps.  If you’re in Chicagoland then you must have this beer
On tap. Strong notes of spice (nutmeg, ginger), actually reminded me of Vernor’s soda. Slightly grassy and hoppy as well, providing balance. Thin, but left nice lacing. Great stuff!
On tap at the Clarke Street Ale House.  Amber in colour and hazy with a thin white head.  Sweet taste with a hint of caramel, spices, nutmeg.  Complex and quite nice.

Nice looking clear orange color with a foamy white head.  Predominantly malty aroma with just a hint of flowery hops discernible.  Hops also take a back seat in the flavor.  I was hoping for a bit more bitterness.
Hazy orange with off white head.  Hops, fruit and spice.  Solid drinkabe beer.

Draft at O’Hare. Copper with a small lasting head. Aroma of peppery toasted pecans. Taste is the same, with a nice caramel aftertaste. Palate is light-medium, slightly dry, and astringent with a lot of tongue tingle.

12 oz bottle.  Moderate aroma of citrus hopps and cereal malts.  Average sized frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing head that left a better than fair lacing.  Body is normally clear with a medium brown-amber hue.  Flavor starts lightly bitter/sweet and ends moderately bitter with a short finish.  Palate is light and watery with soft carbonation.  Not bad but overall it was below average.
Bottle. Amber coloured with a slight off-white head. This didn’t make much of an impression. A slightly fruity aroma followed by a sweet malt flavour and some hops on the finish. Ok.
You get the deep amber pour with a decent sized head.  Then we see the notes of hops and spice which roll into a deeper citrus and spice palate.  It also drinks with nice complexity.

Tap @ Peculier Pub, NYC.  Pours an amber color with a small white head.  Aroma is hops and malt.  Taste is roughly the same, though this definitely has a higher malt characteristic than a classic pale ale.  Solid, if unspectacular, beer.
A nice ale. More malt flavor than some i have had. Plenty of bitterness but not overpowering. She picked this up to surprise me so I had to drink it. Not my thing but not a bad beer.

Poured an amber / copper color with a medium, whitish head.  Aromas of hops and citrus.  Taste was strong on the hops with a slight citrusy background taste.  Aftertaste was a little bitter, but not too much.  An overall average beer, widely accessible and non abrasive.
amber color, tan head. pleasant malt taste throughout, with fruit, spice and hop notes. very drinkable, great with food. better than expected, and cheap(!)
An attractive brown/amber colour with a small head. Pleasant hops, light fruitiness with some caramel and peach. Ok

A Mes rate: 
Bottle from Whole Foods. Wasn’t gonna drink this but Rudiger opened it "accidentally" after we had been on a bender so it got a rate. Amber colour with a faint white head. Sweetish with toffee and some slight orangey notes. Slight wheaty malt. Run of the mill.
Bottle. A superb beer. Lovely bright brown colour. Full of flavour,  this is goes down extremely smooth.

Bottle. Poured light and creamy with very little head and little lacing. Could smell some fruit blends along with malts. Medium body that went down smooth with a good amount of hops. Complimented this beer with some pizza which worked out well. This is nothing fancy, but a very drinkable beer.
Amber with good, foamy beige head / Light to medium body with good balance and finish / Flavors of toasted malt, orange peel, lemon, and candied caramel flavors / A fine example of the style.

On tap at Coco Bolos in Overland Park. Given a choice between BMC, Dos Equis XX Amber and Honkers, the choice was easy. This is a clear amber/orange beer with a creamy, off-white head. The nose is sweet caramel malts with no discernible hop presence. The mouthfeel is light to medium-bodied, soft and dry at the finish with a faint hop bitterness. This is a malt-forward pale ale with a caramel front and a lightly bitter hop finish. Overall, it makes for a nice session beer.

Bottle.  Yeasty aroma with light aromatic hops and a tasty bit of chocolate and toffee.  Orange-copper, clear pour with a soapy beige head.  Crisp taste with biscuit and cracker taking the lead, lightly bitter with English hops and slight fruitiness.  Clean medium body and more of the same into the notably dry afterparty.  Pleasant and refreshing quaffer, something of an ESB crossed with an American amber.

On tap at Clybourn pub, Chicago.  Actually tastes almost like an ESB to me-- maybe not quite bitter enough.  I think this beer has a nice flavor-- but nothing spectacular.  Probably a good conversion beer-- like Sam Adams, etc.

Tap @ Navy Pier Beer Garden, Chicago, IL: Big Foamy whitish head, lasting.  Bitter hoppy aroma, somewhat malty, but weakish. Sweet taste, not overly hoppy or malty.  Decent taste. Kind of an appley taste.

Mondial de la bière 07. Couleur orangée-cuivrée pâle, très légèrement voilée, mousse qui reste bien. Arôme houblonné, d’agrumes, et fruité. Goût doux de houblons et de grains, bon équilibre entre les deux. Un peu mince, carbonatation moyenne. Correcte.

This has a most unusual scent to it.  Their is a certain sour wheat smell that I can’t seem to cut through.  Looks good, pours a dark orange color with a quickly diminishing white head.  Some mild hop flavors are present along with a dry Alka-Seltzer like quality to it.  Wouldn’t recommend, even though I love most of the Goose Islands I’ve had.

This is a terrific beer. Nearly perfect, really. It is a malt ninja in an era of H-bombs. Hop heads (me included), take heed of how a well balanced, subdued, old-school ESB is made! Yes, I am aware that it is listed under "English Pale Ale"--It is an ESB through and through! A perfect blend of malts, yeast and hop characters, with smoky and bready malts taking centre stage. From the great honey and biscuits nose to the apricot and peat notes in the mouth, to the great and prolonged finish; this beer is superb. Worth moving to Chicago for.
Robe blonde dorée surmontée d’une mousse blanche qui persiste. Arômes de houblon aromatique et d’agrumes. Saveurs de houblon aromatique et de céréales.
Strong, fruity aroma that reminded me of Brooklyn Ale (which wasn’t necessarily a good thing).  Good initial flavor with dry finish.

Chicago Trip Friday 17:30. On tap at O’Hare. Just off the plane. Bronze with a light head. Served a little too cold. Didn’t get a strong aroma, drinking as we walked to baggage claim and out to the rent-a-car shuttle. Very hoppy beer. Medicinal hop flavour with lots of woody notes. Mouth drying finish. No malt sweetness. Like the hops but somewhat unbalanced.

12 oz bottle.  Good head and lacing.  Adequate bitterness, although the flavor / body didn’t last very long- kind of dies at the end, and even tasted a very slight hint of sweetness / ’soapiness’ in the finish which I wasn’t expecting.  I like this beer, but it’s not in the same league as Young’s Special London or even Anchor Steam Liberty.

Dark amber beer with a little white head. Bitter fruit aroma is detectable but not too strong. Flavor is front-loaded with citrusy hop tang before rolling into a finish that is perhaps too clean. Refreshing though.
On tap at Giovanni’s in Rockford.  A dark "red" with no head.  Plenty of body and a well bananced ale.  It had a very suttle coffee flavor.  I would have this one again.

Rated 6/9/06:  Amazing beer from Goose Island, to date they have yet to let me down. Pours a dirty copper color with a medium thick off-white head, ample lacing and good carbonation. The aroma is outstanding containing a slightly mellow blend of flowery hops and lots of malt. The aroma reminds me of a low key IPA. As I sip on a few of these I’m amazed at the awesome flavor. The hop characteristic is near perfect. They are very present but not overdone. Strong blend of malts keep me intrigued. The balance is perfect. Full mouthfeel with a great finish and pleasant aftertaste. Fantastic beer, I can’t say enough about this one.

355 ml bottle. Deeply murky orange pour swimming with bits. Rich, cakey, reach-out-and-touch-it florally hoppy aroma with a chewy malt background. Flavour plenty more of the same, awash with flowery orange hoppiness. Heavy but refreshing. Thickly bodied hop fruitiness far outdrinking its ABV. If only this was truly representative of a typical English pint.

On tap.  Poured a nice pale amber color with a decent two-finger white head that receded slowly.  The aroma was malt and spice with maybe a bit of floral hops thrown in.  The flavor was an above average malt backbone with some good spices spinning around it and a somewhat dry, hoppy finish.  Very drinkable.  A great session style beer.
On tap.  Pours a deep amber color with small white head.  Aromas of sweet malts.  Medium body with tastes of light hops.  Very smooth with a nice, light bitter finish.  Not bad.

12 oz bottle, Wolfgang Puck’s, O’Hare Airport.  Crystal copper color, white hed, nice lacing.  Aroma of crystal malts and spicy hops.  Big malty flavor, hops not over the top but well done.  If available to me locally, I would make this my house ale.
12oz bottle-An amber body withh a nice white head. Aroma of malt and hops. Taste of malt followed by some hops and then a big malty finish. A decent drinkable everyday brew.

Draught @ Flying Saucer Little Rock 5-2-07.  Clear golden copper.  Faint sour aroma, some hops.  Flavor is slightly sour, with a nice nutty finish.  Not as fruity as some English PA’s but a good beer nonetheless.
Fairly faint aroma but the hops come out on the palate.  Malty finish.  Cloudy light red appearance.

Pours a translucent golden amber with a medium creamy lacing white head.  Aroma of caramel, floral, mix of citrus and Cheerios.  Flavor of cereal grains, lightly sweet, some hop flavor, citrus notes and hints of coffee.
Medium bodied english ale, orangy caramel in color. Not my favorite style, for no particular reason. Just seems kind of boring. Highly drinkable but just average all around.
Never had anything by this company and I was impressed.  Great looking hazy orange brown.  Great head.  Malty hoppy palate and aroma, nothing unique, but well done, like a good home brew.

Bottle at Blue Smoke, 2th st., NYC (great rib joint). Heavy dose of caramel malts with some dryness in the palate and floral qualities but nothing else more to me. If this is an average beer, I do have to sample what the rest of this brewery has to offer! It seems well crafted.
medium body, carmels, hopy, some malts and nutty, good everyday brew. readily avalible in my area. so its a go to beer for me. not spectacular but a reliable friend

Pours a brownish amber color with an off-white head.  Aroma is of floral hops, toasted malts, caramel, and some yeast.  Flavor is pretty well balanced with the hops and toasted malts, but it seems a touch watery and doesn’t have much of an after taste.  Wasn’t too impressed with this brew.
Pours reddish w/white hoppy head.  Not to bitter, not too bad, not too exciting either.

Very nice sweet malt wafts off the rim of the glass.  Honey colored with a decent white head that dies quickly.  Not a lot of frothiness on the palate, but not flat either.  Taste is malted caramel with out a bitter ending.  A basic red drinking ale.  Easy on the palate, not as good as goose Island’s IPA although.

It pours a small white head, and appears kind of a slightly cloudy copper color.  The nose is very hoppy and nice.  The flavor is well-balanced, though more to the hops side but in a very pleasant, not overbearing way.

12oz bottle acquired in trade with kramer17801 (thanks!). Bottle labeled BB 031007. Poured a medium and slightly hazy orange color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of caramel and some citrus. Tastes of toasted malts, caramel, and some citrus. Drinkable but kinda boring.

Draft at Mother Hubbards. Went here a couple of times after work at midnight. I was glad they were open until 4am! Came out coppery amber. Nose is hoppy and lightly floral. Nose reminded me of a pale ale, but more towards American now that I’m seeing this as an English style. Taste is hoppy, floral, dry malts, and light nutty notes. Body is medium and has average carbonation. Finishes with more floral notes, soft citrusy hops and malts notes. Subtle spices as well. Not bad.

I’ve had this beer before a few times...never got around to rating it though.  Well, a buddy of mine brings it over, so I thought I’d give it a rating.  
I used to think this was a very solid beer.  However, I really wasn’t that impressed this time around.  Malt heavy, and very few hops to speak of.  Slightly let down after almost raving about this beer when I first tried it.
On tap @ Bar Louie’s in Flint.  Hard to detect much of an aroma... a little hops, but not much else.  Flavor was of malt and hops.   It was OK... nothing special.

A copper pour with small head.  Similar to a an APA.  Hoppy aroma with some caramel malt and citrus.  Watered down flavors of citrus, malt, caramel, and hops.  Just another average offering from goose island.

Poured a clear copper color into pint glass. Little to no lacing. Taste is predominantly carmel malts with hints of citrus and spice. Undernotes of overroasted malts are slightly out of character. Very crisp and clean. Not my favorite, but fine enough.
Good Bottle beer now being served on tap at a few of my favorite bars locally.  Interesting flavor and refreshing taste.  I’ll have to get down to the brewery sometime and try it fresh.
cloudy orange with large white head..aroma of light floral hops and minimal malt....finishes slightly acrid and bitter...flavor is somewhat similar, crisp and refreshing. Grassy finish. ..
Couldnt even tell that this was a pale ale.  The hop presence was almost non existent.  Below average for me.

12 oz bottle from a Variety pack.  Beer pours to a amber color with a minimum head.  Small hop nose with some malt aroma. Taste is of malt and very smooth with a bit of a bitter hop finish.  A Goose Island standard that has always drank well
Got a 6 pack of this for my Birthday last year. My friend from Indiana said this was her favorite regional beer, now I see why.
Draft.  I thought this was a below average pale ale, as the hop presence was not there.  The malt flavor was nice and drinkable, but the beer needed some hop balance.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a pint glass, cloudy orange with almost no head. (This was an aggressive pour, wondering if the bottle was a bit flat.) The aroma was dominated by roasted malt. The flavor was a nice balance of roasted malt and hops. Very smooth, little bitterness. Nothing stands out too much, but a smooth drinakable session beer.
A nice Tasty Easy drinking beer  that does,nt fill you up!!!      I almost always have a 12pack of Honker,s ale sitting next to the milk and eggs.

Good Session Beer....I’m on number 6 right now....’hicup’  Pours burnt orange colored with a nice head that fades quickly.  Aroma is not offensive and not very strong.  Tastes like most pale ales.  It’s a staple that Chicago can be proud of!

So my layover is at Chicago O’Hare and I have two and a half hours to kill. I walked all over every concourse to find a restraurant and bar that had something I’ve never seen or had. After about 40 minutes of walking I went by a Chilis and I noticed people sitting with beer bottles with this red label on it, I had never recognized that and thought it would be a local micro brew.  So I got a bottle and poured it into a pint glass... Burnt orange tone with a small white head.  Sweet, mildly malty and hoppy aroma.  Highly carbonated palate with flavors of hops, berries, caramel and a nice malt balance with a light nutty background.  Label describes this as a perfect blend of hops and malts and I’d say I’d almost agree with that.

Bottle.  Pour is reddish with a nice two finger dirty white head.  Aroma is malt and spice, with a background of hops.  Taste is just as advertised, with nice full malt taste and a hop bitterness highlighted by spices.  Overall a very drinkable beer.

Tap.  The beer pours to a rich reddish amber body with a nice creamy off-white head.  The aroma was hoppy but mostly just balanced for the masses.  The flavor was malty but had a nice light hop kick that was apparent after many sips.  It started to grow on me.  The palate was subtly bitter and has an average mouthfeel.
On tap @ Giordano’s on Rush!  Pours a nice amber with a thin head.  A muted aroma of hops and some spice.  A very drinkable session PA, nothing super special, but solid.
Had this at a fish fry and I don’t know if it was the fish or the beer, but they both were great.  Nice Pale Ale with an amber color and very smooth finish.

Great amber color, almost no head and what little of it is is gone in seconds. Has a very spicy carbonated taste to it but goes down smooth. Light hoppyness with a good bitter character like an esb. An above average beer.

Solid pale ale.  I first got hooked on beer via pale ale and drank Sierra Nevada for years.  This beer is comparable to that one.  Very drinkable, but not too special.  Lacking a bit in hops.  Great mouth-feel, though...and nice balance with malt.
Didn’t care much for this beer. There was just nothing special about it. Lacking in both flavor and aroma. Not bad, just not great.

Big thanks to footballguy TD32 for this midwest brew.

Pours a clear amber color that forms into a medium sized head that faded preetty quick. Smell is the smell of a bitter, pretty good. NOt a bad taste, but pretty light IMO for an English Bitter. A solid drinker though, just nothing special.
Got some malt and slight hops in the aroma.Pours alight to medium copper with a medium off white head.Sweet malt stood out in the flavor.Thin mouthfeel with a sweet finish.
33 cl bottle, Minneapolis. Hazy pale amber colour, malty aroma. Some malt and hops flavour, but lighter than I expected. Still decent but thought it’d be a bit more full flavoured.

Pours a hazy reddish brown with a big white head.  Aroma is malty, with some spicy hop flavor coming through.  Taste is malty, but very accented by the hops.  Overall a good easy drinker, but not the best from Goose Island.
drank this with spicy gumbo and it was the perfect easy to drink ale to wash it down with.  I’d drink it again
Drank this at some bar in chicago late into a night of drinking.  I remember this to be a refreshing beer that had an enjoyable flavor.  I would order it again and recommend it to others.
Purchased a six pack of bottles. Pours amber red. Light palate, yet quite flavorful. Very drinkable beer, will buy again.
On draft, at the United Center... Beautiful amber color, with nice crisp malt taste, very clean and easy to drink.
pours amber with white head. hop forward aroma brings big earthy and leathery notes. flavors continues to be rather hoppy, leathery with a light malt body. tasty brew.
Pours a nice reddish color with a good golden head. Aroma is tangy but mild. Flavor is sweet with a tiny bit of grassy hops, nothing too great.

Dark golden pour with minimal head and some yeast remnants floating around. Tastes was hard to pinpoint: sort of sweet and fruity with a crisp tingle left on your tongue. Too sweet for my taste but the crisp, spicy flavor is somewhat unique.

This pale ale is one of the only local brews near me, at first i thought it was a very simple beer and not bitter enough for a pale, but it has now grown on me since it is one of the only micro taps i can find

Jan. 23, 2007; 12 oz. bottle. This was the only serviceable beer I could find at Chicago’s O’Hare Int’l whle passing through there recently, and I was somewhat surprised to see it turn up on a shelf here in Upstate NY today.  Amber color, nice balance with a tasty, candyish malt profile and some slightly spicy & fruity hops.  The brewers were really on to something here, but stumbled a bit with the lightness & watery finish.
draft.  copper hue with white head, the aroma is of mild malt and the flavor is not very distinctive.  so so beer.

Bottle.  Clear and copper pour, decent frothy head.  Looks like a nice beer.  Aroma is light, some grassy hops and a little malt, not much else.  Not much too it in the mouth, a bit of hops, a bit of malt, a bit of water.  Actually, it’s pretty refreshing ... probably would make a good lawnmower beer, not so much a middle of the winter beer.

Single bottle purchased in Fayetteville, AR.

Pours a clear copper, a frothy and persistent but thin tan head. Some fine lacing in the glass. Smells of sweet citrus and herbal hops. Certainly not the traditional hop varieties to make and English style bitter! Some fruity pale malt aromas too.

Taste is lightly sweet pale malt with balancing faint herbal hops. Light in the mouth but nicely balanced and tasty. Not much more going on. A nicely balanced American-style bitter. Would be a nice session beer and is a decent drinker. If it was local, would be a regular.
Bottle. Poured a golden color with a redish hint and very carbonated. Aroma of bittering hops is very present. Taste of Clove and citrus and hops is there.

Bottle from Sean, thanks ass bandit.  Pours out a light brown to reddish color with a little head on it.  Smell is light hoppiness with some grassy notes.  Taste is smooth and refreshing with some sweet notes.  Has a little bit of a bitter flavor with some spicies.  Not really outstanding, more just a mediocre ale, but it would be about the perfect session beer.  Thanks Sean.

Bottled(355ml). -No sign of ABV on the label. Pours a dark amber coloured with a small but persistent white head. The aroma is sweet malty and hoppy with fruity and spicy notes. Subdued caramel notes in the background. Mild bitter finish.

I’ve had this beer before on several occasions, and think it is decent and well-balanced.  However, there is nothing really outstanding I can say about it.  Altogether, a pleasant but not memorable beer.

It poured a copper read color and is slightly hazy.  Head formation was pretty decent.

Aroma was very malty.  

Taste-wise, although this beer is categorized as a bitter here, I was under the impression from previous tries that it was an IPA.  It is not very hoppy for an IPA, but the hop and malt is well balanced...so I would say this is way insufficiently hopped to be an IPA, but rather hoppy for a bitter.

Drinkability and mouthfeel were decent but not outstanding.

Served on tap at The Gathering. Clear dark amber with a respectable white head.  Aroma was pleasing but difficult to characterize in this environment. Medium-light bodied, mild bitterness, dominated by a pleasant hop flavor.  Drinkable session-oriented APA, one of the best in a sketchy selection.

clear orange with a nice lasting white head. faint toasted orange aroma. spicy hops balance to the sweet nutty toffee flavor.  slightly bitter nutty toffee finish. a bit thin and fizzy. decent drinkable beer.

Bottle, Cellar Bar, St Andrews. Very vigourous bubbles, a little sediment supported in the glass. Thin off-white head. Aroma is fizzy fruit and hops, some malt there too. Mouthful is little coating due to the bottle-conditioned nature, but sweet, some bitternesss. Smooth. Alright, but a little too carbonated.
Slight above average session beer.  Nothing incredibly special and nothing really negative going on here either.  Mild hop presence mild malt presence.

Bottle.   Pours a dark amber color with a smallish white head.   Aroma is light, citrus, bread, malt.   Flavor is citrus, toasted malt, biscuit.   Palate is medium-light, medium carbonation, mild bitter finish.   Not bad.
A pretty average beer for Goose Island.  Pours amber with a white head.  Citrus and malts.  A good alternate beer to go out and drink with, but nothing that is completely remarkable.  Decent.

Bottle. I drank this all of the time when I lived in Chicago, because you could always find this at BMC bars. I come to find that I have not rated it! Pours a translucent amber with an off white head. Aroma of toffee and citrus. Very light mouthfeel. Flavor of caramel, toasted malt, and orange. Transitions to a spicy hop finish, with some lingering strong tea flavors.   Nice hop profile for a pale ale, but maybe just a tad on the watery side. This is sort of a british/ american hybrid pale ale.. A good session beer.

It’s dark copper/brown. Very pretty, like the color of clay only much darker. The aroma has something floralesque to it. I don’t know if you would use the terminology floral but it is kinda. I like the smell personally.  It’s definitely got some mild hop bitterness.  It’s got a laid back flavor and a lightly bubbly mouthfeel. It’s not watery but at the same time it’s not jaggermeister.
Amber color with a little head that lasts several minutes.  Not much aroma.  Nice flavor.  Mildly hoppy with a little malt.  Slightly bitter aftertaste; just a hint of metal.  Very good.
Cloudy orange color. Small to medium head that leaves just a bit of lace. Aroma was wheat like-cloves, bitter perfume. Taste was bitter to start, with sweet finish. Medium body. Balanced aftertaste.
(Tap) Pours amber with a good-sized beige head. Aroma of floral hops, and some smooth malts. A nice hoppy, yet balanced flavor with a medium  mouthfeel. This is good all-around beer.

12 oz. bottle left wrapped up next to my truck by one of my co-workers today.  According to the date on the bottle, this bad boy is a little over a year old.  Gonna give it a shot anyways.  Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a one finger thick off white head.  Very light lacing.  Has a nice fruity aroma.  Flavor is light toasted malt and esters.  Light to medium body.  Not bad for a beer that is a year past its prime.  Gonna have to find out who left me the beers at work.

Slightly floral hoppy aroma.  Flavor is kind of subdued hops up front with a decent malt backbone, but nothing really jumps out.  Slightly dry and also metallic finish.  Seems like their flagship beer is a bit dulled down in order to suit the masses, but this would be an excellent session beer.

Hazy, copper color, with a tiny head and minimal lace. Inviting, clean citrus aroma. Flavor is dominated by mild citrus hops, but there is a definite malt presence, as well. A sublte bitterness in the finish. Kind of dry, with nice carbonation. Quite refreshing.
smooth crisp, distinct in a good way, honker’s ale is a chicago classic.  Makes beers like miller light seem like tiolet watter.  Not the best beer i ever had, but a danm good one
12oz bottle. Clear amber color with white head.  Aroma and taste of malt and hops. Little watery taste.
12 oz bottle at Kyle’s "This Is Not A Beer Tasting" beer tasting. Clear amber with no head. Sweet malty caramel nose with a mild spicy hop influence. Flavor follows suit.

Bottle at The Rake in Borough (London), a hazy amber witha foamy white head. A beautifully strong floral hop aroma with stone fruits. Very hoppy palate and a berry fruitiness. Smooth all the way through with a light bitter touch on the finish. Delicious.

A dark amber coloured beer with a weak white head. A strong floral hop nose, some sweet malt aroma, but also slightly perfumed. A bitter taste, dry floral hop, slightly zesty, then a bitter malty flavour into the finish. (Bottle - The Beers of Europe, Setchey, Norfolk).
It’s OK but not really for my taste. A little too citric and bitter. Seems quite carbonated

Wispy orange citrus and light grain aroma. Orange-copper pour, with a creamy ring of ivory. Flavor is a sweet, crisp malt with a wafting edge of light toast, earthy grains and nice goat cheese over faint cream. I really appreciate the balance of up-front fruity hop character, with the more rustic deep roughly-hewn grain character in the middle. A nice long minerally crisp hop finish, maybe edging a little American? Smacks on fresh hop cone resin. Worked nicely on draft with my Ploughman’s Platter.

pours a honey color with an ok sized white head that does not last to long and has a light body. lttle lacing small hop nose small pine and a small orange grapefruit as well. a small pine hop grapefruit taste not over powering little bit watered down i would say. small dry hop after taste not bad an above average session ale.

This one was just okay with me. I’ve been exposed to a few Goose Island products and have enjoyed each of them. This too was a decent beer, but I have to say that most ESB’s I’ve had are just...okay. Aroma is definitely malty with a bit of citric hops playing in the back. Appearance is a deep copper color with a nice head. Medium-bodied on the palate. A strong malt presence on the palate with just a nice hop character to let you know it’s an ESB. Nothing too over the top here either way. A decent beer.

12oz - BB 112206 - Aroma of stale citrus hops blended with a maltiness that is actuall inviting.  Pours transparent light brown with a medium head and good lacing.  Flavor is bland with no hops, all malt and a touch of lemon.  Palate is clean and soapy.  Nothing special here but drinkable.

Weak-looking as it pours, nice darkish head, good lacing.

Spicy in a very drinkable fashion.Hops smooth.  A pretty good effort and one I’ll try again.
not a bad beer good taste nice hops i think lil spice and bitterness overall a fine brew keep up the good woerk in CHI town
Pours orange, was very hoppy..notes of citrus.  The flavor is more spicy and ends bitter with a smooth finish.  Goes nice with the Buffalo Burger as advertised.

Bottle. Pours a clear amber-orange with an average size mostly-lasting white head. Pleasant U.K. hops aroma with some toasty malt backing it up. Flavour: Easy to drink C-hops and malt blend, lightly spicy and with a nice bitter finish. Medium bodied. A decent version of the style.
brewtopia 10/21/06.  Aroma is caramel malts and some spicy hops.  Taste is caramel malt, bread, with a lightly hoppy finish.

Bottle: Copper coloured, small and quite stable foamy layer, slightly hazy with clumps (of yeast?); spicy hoppy nose with some bready, almost nutty aromas and some malt in the background; stronger, dry bitter flavour, light bodied; tart fruitiness, hop resins in the lingering dry bitter finish. Very good stuff !

12 oz bottle: Aroma is medium hopped with a yeasty scent to it, Appearence is a clear copper color with a medium sized white head that lasts for quite a while.  Nice spicey taste with a hop backing, nice bitterness to the taste, and some twang which I can not distingusish.  Palate is somewhat watery, bitter, and quite carbonated.  Overall, It’s a decent beer.

Bottle poured an amber/copper color with a white head. Floral hops dominate the aroma.  Taste is also of floral hops and a little malt.  This beer is very simple, straight-forward ale and a good one at that. Easily accessible in Missouri.

On tap at the Goose Island kiosk at Chicago O’Hare Airport. Poured cloudy, coppery brown with a tan, lacy head. Nose is malt and yeast with a slight floral note. The nose is malty with a nice hoppy finish. Nicely balanced. Cost an arm and a leg at the airport, though.

Draught from The Pub poured into shaker - Pours amber with a tint of red with a 1 finger white head; Sweet malt, hops, a little spice to the nose; Floral and pine hops, some malt on the initial taste; Not bitter at all; A clean, hoppy, piney backtaste; A very refresing beerthat I enjoyed. The carbonation was a bit heavy to start with, but I think that may have been the lines at the bar. It did die down eventually. Good stuff!

Pours a nice white head, light orange.  Medium and soft moutheel. lagerish ale. Tad of lace left.Smarty hopped, acidic bite and overcarbonated.Bit of yeast and malt and hops in the aroma, bit of C hop.. Drying aftertaste.
Good pale ale, but too little hop taste compared to their IPA. Part of variety pack.
A wonderfully fresh and hoppy brew.  Very drinkable, just perfectly simple.  I like it a lot.  It isn’t overly impressive, but it just works.

12oz bottle.  Hazy, deep bronze hue.  Nice thick ring of bone white head.  Spotty large bubbled head.  Nutty graham cracker nose.  Medium bodied.  Great light malt character.  Nutty and sweet.  Dry finish with bitter hop flavors.
Amber color with little head.  Had on draft in downtown Chicago.  Good flavor with some malty bitter flavor.  Good beer and a great choice if you’re in Chicago.
Good drinkable beer.  Slightly sweet smooth flavor.  Good carbonation.  All purpose beer for any occation, gos well with food or on a Sunday afternoon.

Bottle: The sweet malti aromas are salivating though the tasting experience was mediocre.  Don’t get me wrong, I like this beer and would buy it again... it is a nice English bitter style, but comparatively to other great beers, this one lacks complexity.  The aroma and taste are great but the beer could use some extra body, perhaps another fermentation to take it to the next level.  Again, it’s a good beer with the potential to be great with minor adjustments, one that I recommend.
Hazy golden amber ale with a thick creamy white head. Light caramel malt with floral hops. In mouth, a crisp maltwith floral piney hops, rather short, but good. Trade with Piscator. Thanks Kris.
Draft- Thai Place.  LIght hop nose.  Good amber color and light tan head.  Hopy flavor with a slight maltiness to it.  Fruit flavors in the middle.  Not bad.
poured a nice amber hue with a white head which had good retention.  Sweet malty aroma with some hops. Smooth crisp malty flavor wiht a mildly bitter hop finish.

Rating this from memory after drinking several while in Chicago recently. Thought it a nice and decent APA with an alright amount of hoppiness and fruit flavours. Pretty standard, but when somebody plunks down a bottle of this and a bottle of Old Style on the table....well, the choice should be fairly obvious.
Bottle. Tawny brown body with a lasting foamy head. Caramel, low-medium hops, dried apple chips, light nutmeg, some canned corn juice, very good fruit flavors that are kept in check very well.

Ho hum not much here.  Poured an amber color okay head and okay lacing.  Aroma was of light fruits.  Flavor was the same with a little malts to there.  some malts very very thin to me.  just an average beer.

Bottle. Clear amber with a thin white head, quickly diminishing.  Aroma of caramel malts with some hops.  Flavor of caramel malt with some ale esters and a slight hop background.  Malt and hops are basically balanced, but only because neither really stands out.  A bit thin on the palate.  Another run of the mill APA which leaves no real impression.

Bottle.  Fresh berry malt aroma.  Medium amber color with small head.  Lightly sweet malt flavor with light hops finish.  An easy drinking beer - a bit light on the hops for the style but still very good.
On tap at Curraghs:  Amber in color, minimal head.  Had nice flavor but was lacking hops.  Definetly better ales out there, but overall it was an okay beer

12 oz bottle. Beautiful transmitted orange color; has a cloudy/murky reflected color.  Initial reaction = not as good as Bass but better than Redhook; put it just under S.Nevada.  Actually well balanced.  Excellent aroma, decent lacing.  Medium to high on the conditioning bite/sting.  APA for sure; trying to copy the Brits using indiginous materials...Got a strange buzz from this beer, and I detect the piney-ness which is in their IPA (someone mentioned that this is the Chinook hop).  Tastes like thier IPA w/ less hops.

Goose Island is the closest I drink to commercial beer. Honkers is a mainstay when you’re in basic bars in Chicago. it’s "ok." Basic pale ale. Nothing special. Hardly hoppy. You buy it when it’s the only real beer on the menu.

(bottle - 12 oz) Had a few of these at O’Hare International Airport in Chicago. Nice amber color with a tiny amount of white foam. Aroma was nice and hoppy with a hint of some bitterness and some sweet malts. Flavor wasn’t as hoppy as I was expecting, but it was still nice. Nice and smooth hop flavor at the beginning with a medium body and a slightly bitter and not too overpowering hoppy finish. A bit watery but not too bad.
Decent apa. Sort of like Anchor’s Libery Ale but not quite as vibrant. Little on thin side.

Re-rate, Jan ’08, bottle at the Midway airport: Much more impressive experience (for the style) than my first. Fully lace yielding head/appearance. Nicely hopped up earthy resinous presence, all supporting toffee, caramel, even nutty and slightly fruity base beer. Refreshing preparation for the flight home. Two thumbs up withinthe ESB family of beers! Bumping the numbers up a bit. Original rating: Snorefest here, as most bitters tend to put me to sleep. Pour was amber colored with an ok initial head, decent lacing. Aroma was fruity. Flavor was fruity with some balancing hops and rich matiness underneath. Couldn’t make out the fruit flavors, almost seemed somewhat berry-like. Mouthfeel was fairly heavy for a bitter or ESB. An odd bitter aftertaste was left in the mouth. Beers like this require a tap pour to get a real sense of the work - a luxury which wasn’t afforded me.
A clean, but roundly hoppy ale. no question this is well balanced.  This is a great gateway beer, as it is widely available in even the worst bars in  Chicago.

A nice pale ale, one that I found to be quite similar to say, Sierra Nevada (although not quite as good). Hazy  orange color with almost no head, it goes down easy but doesn’t sacrifice the nice bitter taste. Bought at Stimmel’s Market, Bowling Green, OH
clear amber body with no head.caramel and nuts make up the aroma.flavor is much of the same with a small hop finish.

Bottle. Pours a foggy copper body with a small creamy white head. The aroma is somewhat nutty with vague maltiness and generally lacking in substantive hop profile. Watery palate with some faint spicy hops and lots of bread. Not really what I’m going for when it comes to APA’s - I almost found this to be more of a Brown or something to that effect. 

Purchased at World Market in Ann Arbor during the month of July in 2006.

Best when consumed by 120306.  Pours a Clear copper orange with a small fading yellow white head.  Aroma is of lightly citrusy, earthy, and spicy hops.  Light caramel and biscuity malts.  Flavor is more malty than hoppy, a bit thin on the palate.  Moderate carbonation, no lacing.  Listed as an APA and labeled as a bitter, I think this is more like a bitter myself--it just has the English taste to it.  Not bad, but not Goose Island’s best, either.

Decent but basic, and probably not something I would pick up again.  Very much on the malty side, but does has a light bit of floral hoppiness, but comes across as almost perfumey.  Light, but well balanced.
[Bottle] Amber coloured with a fine head. Peculiar aroma of fresh wet snuff and hops. Fruity apricot flavour, hoppy bitterness. A bit thin maybe.
Pours a hazy orange with a small head. Pretty nice lacing. Aroma is of mild citrus and floral notes. The flavor seems to have a little of everything. Malt, hops, citrus.... Very very nice ale.

Pours clear medium dark orange with a moderate sized white head that gives nice lacing.  Aromas is very balanced with semi-sweet malt and perfumey / floral hops.  Medium bodied with fairly fizzy carbonation.  Starts lightly sweet malt with spicy hops.  The spicy hops become more dominant in the finish.  Sharp and crisp beer, nicely done.

Bottled.
Deep honey golden, small white head. Bready malty aroma. Bready, hoppy, lingering aftertaste. Very standard APA - balanced and drinkable one anyhow.
A copper appearance.  Nothing distinctive about the aroma.  A nice mixture of malt and hops with a floral finish.  Very drinkable and affordable.
Decent, somewhat light and just a bit under-hopped (for m y taste) APA.  Widely available in chicago area.  Good all-round ale.

bottle - Pours amber with a moderate head.  Some lightly roasted malts and the hops make for a nice aroma.  The flavor is well balanced with a dry, hoppy finish and the palate is medium bodied.  It’s not bad at all.  It’s a good session brew, though be aware that the flavor is a bit different for the classification of American pale ale.  I thought it tasted much more like an ESB than a typical APA.
Bottled. Deep golden, malty nose and finish. Medium head. Clean and easy drinking.

Heavy malt, caramel, and milk shocolate, moderate hoppiness of flowers and pine, oak, toffee, honey, syrup, and alcohol.  Head was small, off white mostly diminishing with fair lacing.  Medium hue, amber in color.  Light sweet and acidic with moderate bitterness.  Very tasty and drinkable the more you drink the better it taste with the hops fading to the back ground and the malt really shining through.  Overall a very excellent Pale Ale.

On tap 7/15 @ "The Second City" comedy theater in Chicago. Pours amber in color with a thin off-white head that diminishes rather quickly. 
Aroma has hints of a floral hops with some spices. Flavor is sweet and malty with a mild bitter finish. I found this well balanced and easy drinking since I had several pints during the comedy revue.

Pours a nice amber color with medium head and a little bit of lacing. A mix of flowery hops and caramel malt in the aroma. The malt flavor comes out when I take a drink.  Easy drinking, nice on the palate.
Damn smooth pale ale. Orange in color. I drank these while fishing on the boat. damn tastey, but I was mostly concentrating on catching walleye.
Bottled. Dark golden in colour with a medium sized white head. Very nice aroma. Both malty and hoppy and notes of flowers. Well balanced sweetness and good mouthfeel.
