(bottle) This had an interesting and complex nose that I really liked -- a little vinegar, a little butterscotch, some kind of tart fruit jam thing going on.  The color of weak tea, 2 cm of upholstery-foam head.  Endearing goose on the label, even though we all know that the only thing that geese are fit for is roasting, when you're out of turkey. But, I'm biased ever since that swan attack incident as a 4-year old -- but I digress... Dry, starched ale. Fruitier, brown sugar-ier and sweeter as it warms.  Initially finishes weakly roasty or coffee-ish, after which the hops speak up. CO2 leaves too quickly. I was a little disappointed in this one after the fine Summertime Kolsch. Good, but not outstanding, session beer.

Amber with orange shine, cold haze; slight orange head, lacey. Nose yields caramel and colour malts, and fine hops. Malty underbuild with hoppy surroundings in the taste. Surprising for an American, this tastes very British. Including the mouthfeel and aftertaste, both rather empty  - just the hopbitterness, and a little oiliness linger on. It starts off proudly American, then turns out to be prominent British, and finally fails to deliver both goods. Ay. Expected better from this much-vaunted ale. I don't know if it's for export, but my label states 5.0% ABV.

Light amber body with a quickly diminshing white off white head.  The aroma is of English hops, not American; lightly malty with some hints of caramel and fruitiness.  The flavor starts malty but quickly switches to hop flavor with a little bit of roastiness, but that's only a back ground flavor.  Caramel malts and a light fruitiness add to this fine session beer.  Very well balance, but definitely toward hop flavor and light lingering bitterness are very pleasant and not harsh or astringent.  Although I was expecting a fuller mouthfeel, it seems a little light and is moderately carbonated.  I rather enjoyed this session beer from Goose Island since I find that to my palate there is a grainy astringency to some of their other offerings, but this one is well made and very drinkable.
malt in aroma with hint of hops. very smooth and malty just enoughj hops to break up the maltiness but not to add anthing special to this beer,
light malty nose, copper hue with a small white head, malty, some pineapple tones, oily texture, reasonable stuff
Brown color,off white head, lace all the way, perfumy aroma. Very bitter, perfumy taste. Bitter aftertaste. Too bitter for me.
Golden brown. Diminishing head leaves a few spots of lace. Smells good--fruity, hoppy, floral. A bit watery on the palate though. Just a hint of malt sweetness with a bitter finish.
Copper in color with adequate head and lacing. Roasted caramel aroma with a hint of fruiteness. Lightly hopped with a spicy clean finish.
This is better than I was expecting.  I heard it compared to Anchor Liberty Ale, but this is not as bitterly hoppy.  good malt balance.

I had two from the same six pack over two days and the most memorable thing about either was how different they were from each other.  First was like a Chiswick Bitter from Fullers ... thin, second run, not much mouth feel, not much malt.  The second one was better, so let's use the rating from that one, escept that I down graded the overall impression rating number because of how bad the first one was.  Good mouth feel and appearance — cloudy reddish brown with good thin lacing.  Taste of malt and bitter hops, followed by floral hops.  Good lingering bitter finish.  The first one I would have to describe as thin, watery, lifeless in the mouth and on the tongue.

Attractive hop aroma, with a hint of fresh-brewed tea.  Broadly fruity flavor (grape) and more tea.  Slightly limp, lacks a certain richness and depth on the tongue.  Golden/amber/red color, clinging head, lingering rounded bitterness. (on tap, Goose Island, Clybourn, Chicago)

A refreshing beverage, perfect for warm temperatures (although...come to think about it...it was in the 30s outside when I drank this).  I'm not sure about the pale ale description however.  Flavor is smooth and modestly hoppy with a pleasant citrusy, spicy character evident as the ale enters the throat.  In this respect, Honkers Ale reminds me of a sort of "Oberon lite." This is my favorite beer in Goose Island's lineup.

Great aroma, clear amber color.  Good flavor not too hoppy.Clean finish.  Flavor is not overpowering, but everything doesn't have to be stout.

I like it!
Initally sweet, finishes dry and a little spicy. Has a nice hops prescence. Not bad for Goose Islands flagship brew. Better on tap, but good in the bottle.
Beautiful color, great smell and aroma, but the taste is a little soury for my taste.

Malty, straw and gain nose.  Slightly cloudy rich copper appearance with off white foamy head.  Flavour is initially malty but predominantly hoppy with strawberry hints.  Dry lasting after taste with a slight bitterness.  Another good beer from Goose Island
Decent color, nice amber with a good head.  Nice full hoppy aroma.  Hoppy and dry with a good hop finish.  A bit watery.

Nice amber color with a respectable head. Nice lace. A bit of hops and malt up front, a bit bitter in back that lingers. Very drinkable and yet very unremarkable. More hops would make this a better brew.

Great colour, and a fantastic smell. The flavour was great at first, but quickly faded away. Not a bad beer, but not my favourite APA. A great beer to have real quickly between Terminals 1 & 2 at Chicago O'Hare (ORD).

Do I rate by flavor or by style?  I suppose by flavor, with comments on the style.  This had a rich British Isles taste, I suppose coming from the malts and hops, with a bit of a peaty character thrown in there.  I happen to like this flavor profile, but APA it most definitely is not.
Inviting dark amber color, diminishing head.  Dry spicy aromas and flavors, English malt character.  Finish is less dry, with a little caramel sweetness.
Nice pour: spicy invitedness in aroma, a little short on the head, beautiful amber color; taste is appropriately malty with carmel undertones. reason for re rate becomes peppery with warming.

July 2019 355ml brown bottle, no residue, part of a Goose Flight Pack bought at Lidl. Some crystal malt. Well, too much crystal malt in relation to the other malts, so a little dry and tannic. Not my thing. Watery. A lot of these Goose Island beers lack body. This feels more like a lager than  an ale. Brewed slowly at a low temperature for stability? Possibly. That, and in a closed fermenter using throwaway yeast. This feels like a very commercially oriented beer. Brewed for the money rather than the character. It's drinkable, but not hugely enjoyable. [2.2]

Feb 2003  Thin body with a good dusting of hops. Nice malt tang. A pleasant, drinkable beer, but nothing special. Nice bottle, but a bit small. [2.4]
Good, but not great. This seems to be Goose Island's standard bearer, though there are stronger beers from that brewery, especially some seasonal ones.
Not to bad on tap.  A little to much malt for an APA but I can live with it.  This is not as good as Great Lakes Burning River.
Nice, reminds me of a hefewiezen. Nice color, a full but light palate.......

Sampled on draught.  Malty, lightly fruity aroma with a hint of caramel.  Light to medium amber color, slightly hazy, with a small but creamy head.  Flavor is uncomplicated, with a bit of lightly fruity, caramel malt and a gentle hop bitterness.  Finish is mostly hoppy and smooth.  Light to medium body.  Palate is a bit on the thin side.  A definite session beer.
copper color with small head, floral hop and malt aroma, well balanced, and a bit thin, but still a good session type beer
[rerate needed] Nice rich color, good hoppy flavor.  Not as strong as most pale ales, but has a nice texture in my mouth.
At O''hare in Chicago. Hoppy aroma and flavor. Thin non lasting head. A nice beer to pass the time away when at O''hare.

Nice stuff.  Much maltier and heavier than your average pale ale.  Dark amber color, with little head dissipating to nothing as you drink.  Has a worty nose to it, like it hasn''t been fermented yet.  I like that smell.  I''m guessing they used a low alpha cascade variety, with pale malts and a bit of caramel malt.  That''s some beer geekspeak right there.  Suck it down, cousin, it''s good.

Has that damn perm or "barber shop" hops smell to it. Anyone know what kind of hops these are? Very light, even for an APA. Not as much malt presence as I like, even in an APA. This is OK. Funny, I""ve heard two people rave about this to me; I feel a bit let down.
Watery and somehow good. Flavorful, light head. Not your average APA, thank goodness. One of the best of the style I"ve tried.

light amber color, with a thinish, quickly dissipating head. Bitter aroma, with hoppy notes, and a slight unpleasant metalic odor. Very thin, watery palate. Flavor is rather bitter throughout, but not in a particularly good way. Nothing much else in the flavor to speak of. This bottle is a little old, so maybe it''s gone bad, but I don''t think this beer is much to speak of at all.
not a bad apa, but not a great one either. the more they make the lighter in flavor this seems to have gotten over the last 5 years. try their ipa for a real winner.
A little cloudy in appearance. The head was ok. Tastes both fruity and a little hoppy. Yes, I can taste the yeast coming through.
From the bottle. Nicely balanced ale--neither hops nor malt overwhelms the other.

This beer must have been nitrogenated. Light amber body with a nitrogenated looking cream head. Playful, light, fruity hoppiness in the nose with a creamy, fruity hopped body. A merger between an APA and a cream ale. Eh.
Good, malty APA.  Needs more hop or different style?  I think their malts keep this beer from being average.  Needs stronger head--- they should import a yeast?

I don''t really think ''small batch'' when I think Goose Island. This is the flagship beer, rightfully so probably. Kind of thin mouthfeel, fair head, light amber color, roasty malts that are set aside by floral hops. It tastes like it smells, for the most part. Appropriately carbonated. A great session beer. When it''s truly fresh on tap, it''s practically unbeatable.

Bottled.  Light-medium amber, little head.  Nse has caramel, somewhat roast, some fruity hoppiness.  Flavor is reasonably hoppy, but that''s about it; very little sweetness, and rather dry and lacking in malt.  Fizzy on the end, but a decent long finish.
Much better on tap than in bottles, this is a bottle review.  It just doesn''t seem to have anything exciting going on.  Certainly a very calm (boring) version of an ESB.
Mmmm, light and soapy with a metallic edge.  Not a good beer................

Fairly fast diminishing creamy head.  A fairly hoppy aroma with a malty undertone.  A copper, amber color.  Very smooth drinking.  Like the aroma the flavor is hoppy underscored by malt.  A little bit of a smokey undertone as well.

The aroma is slightly malty. Notes of toffee and caramel.
This crystal clear, deep amber beer has a small, white head. Mostly diminishing with excellent lacing.
The flavor is perfectly balanced with bursts of caramel and butterscotch.
Medium-length, dry finish with fresh cut fescue at the far end.

Good malt and hops cobination leaves this sweet, spicy and toasted.    Well balanced for an American pale, in which the style tends to be over-hopped.  Light citrus and yeast taste.  Not exceptional, but a good brew.

I need to try again for sure. Had what seemed like an old one at the airpotr in Chicago. people need to be moer proud of the local brew, especially when the other chioce is millebucoors. This might not be great, but is a good, well brewed beer.

Bottle conditioned? Amber bronze, good lasting head and moderate condition with very little yeast apparent in the bottle. Bready aromas with hints of caramel and some assertive American hops. Plenty of hop flavour but with a slight soapiness, and a soft finish with a delicate hop bitterness tickling the tongue. I walked into one of my local stores expecting a shelf full of already rated beers and was surprised to find this along with the IPA. Can we have some more American beers in the UK please.
Don''t think mine travelled well.Hazy amber brown,lasting head. Sour hop nose.Bitter flavor with long finish. Lacking in malt?no balance
Good pale ale, although other brews offered (which I forget already) were more adventuresome. Easy brewpub to find even if you're not local.
Not a bad beer, but they make a few better ones at their brewery.  It has a better nose than taste, but it''s nose is pretty good.
medium body,somewhat malty, bitter, an average Pale Ale.....................
Something about this beer just isn't right. Bad aftertaste and totally different flavor from what I like in an ale. Nothing compared to the Hex Nut Ale.

Rich amber color, slightly cloudy. Nice fruity aroma. Mellow flavor, mildly sweet with a little hoppiness. Hint of citrus? Pretty good overall, but something's missing here that would make it top notch.... I don't know what. For $5 a 6 pack? Hell yeah!

rerate-ya know, this beer is nothing special, but makes a good session ale when at chicago bars with this on tap-this has a very unique finish, something that i cant describe-more english than american PA.
rerate again-i have altered and messed with this rating so many times.  all in all, this beer is a pretty decent session ale.  the beer pours light amber with a soapy off-white head.  toasty/carmel/malty aroma with a touch of citrus and light yeast.  the flavors here are pretty good-decent malts, but not much of a hop presence.  the beer suffers from a tea-like palate, but i didnt bring the palate score down due to easy drinking abilities.

A very good pale ale. The first few tastes are quite citrusy, and then it levels off and the beer acquires more of a malty flavor. A very good experience overall! Up there with Sierra Nevada, but I would not go so far as to say it is just as good or better.
These guys have a hard time making a bad brew there all well done nice flavor slightly malty with a definate hop presence.the finish is a little bitter but nothing that can''t be handled.Well done
fairly malty ale with somewhat of a nutty flavor...walnut comes to mind. not a pronounced hop flavor...pretty enjoyable beer.

A pretty standard pale ale.  Some bottles are clearly better than others and when fresh on draft, this beer is great.  Citrusy and crisp.  Could use a little more hops and malt.  Hit or miss - sometimes tastes liek iced tea.
Has nice red tint color, Not overpowering on the hops,I sure it would be better on tap.  Was expceting a little more hop to come out.

Nothing really stands out. No real aroma to speak of, little head. Dark reddish amber. My first sips tasted good; slightly fruity, refreshing. First beer of the night. After those first few sips it got boring. The further down the pint I got, the thinner and more tired I became of it. Very mild in all aspects, I guess a stepping stone beer.

This was my personal session ale before Three Floyds Alpha King came to town!  On tap it is a different, cleaner, hoppier ale. The bottle just gives a slight sour taste instead of the fresher bitter bite given by it's tapped version.. On tap, the balance of sweet malts and Citrusy hops is so much more evident. Still, I like their special brewpub cask conditioned stuff and seasonals over the honkers.
The first time I had this I thought it had nice body.  The second time it lacked hop bite and flavor.  A decent beer, but could use more IBU.
Not overly impressed, but far from the worst on the planet.  It's cold and drinkable, that's about it.

Medium brown color, small head. Roasted, nutty malts, floral hops with very little hop bitterness. Nice balance. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is crisp and clean. Aftertaste is malty, no bitterness. The malts shine through on this beer.
Not great, and not bad.  Definitely middle of the road but slightly better than the average bear, I mean beer.  But it IS number 400!
A light, watery amber color with a nose of cooking wort, this ale gets better as you drink it, but still does not excite me much.   The long bitter finish is nice, it keeps lingering on.
Amber colour with a medium sized head.  A lightly hoppy flavour, with a bitter dry finish.
Turned my stomach. Kind of a moldy, sour flavor. The first drain pour I've had in ages. If this is one of Chicago's best beers, I'm really glad I don't live in Chicago.

Big rocky head fades down to nothing atop an amber colored brew. Smells mildly malty and slightly of cardboard. Sweet malty flavor pretty much runs throughout this brew. Tastes a little old. Even if it wasn't old, this tastes like a good beer that was watered down.
Medium caramel color. Not much head but a decent "lace" for what head there was. Creamy. Good hops and a bit of a fruity finish. Not bad...not bad at all.
I thought this was a good all around ale.  First time I drank this i was at work.  Smooth with a good taste.  Would rather have a PBR.

Re-Rate 08/22/02: Clear copper in color, the head and lace are adequate. Nose is malt sweet, as is the front, top is light, the finish has a mild hop presence, the carbonation is light to moderate, somewhat dry, and a decent "Session Beer". Ranks #766 on my current 1000 beer master list.
A somewhat hearty Midwestern ale. It's honey-colored with a fine sweet finish. Good with Chicago pizza and hot dogs. High on carbonation, though.

I liked this stuff a lot actually.  I had it on tap.  Very pretty looking brew.  It had a pleasantly sweet/fruity malt nose.  Tastey, slightly bitter hops rounded this beer out well.  Rerate: one of my favorite college hangouts just put this on tap and I am pumped!  Great pitcher beer!

My old rating was 3.0, but I’ve been drinking this a lot on tap lately and I just really like it as a summer beer, so I’m upping the rating a bit as I drink it at Ray’s.  nice.  deep golden color.  Medium thick malts, not too sweet.  Nice citrusy hops for balance and finish.  substantial enough to stand above macros and some micros too.
The malt overpowers the hops, making for a sweeter ale.  Aroma is too fruity.  I wouldn't want more than one.
The first Goose Island beer I tried, and its a very good one.  Noticably more hops and malt than the blonde ale, as well as an attractive appearance.

Unimpressive clear reddish amber color. Fizzy.  This had a spicy, very carbonated nose, which then led into a bit of a stale, heavy hop taste.  Beer is very unbalanced and ends with a touch on the lighter side, with some fruity notes.  Did they forget the malt? 5/2/4/2/8

No they did not forget the malt.  Wow, old ratings are pretty funny.  While I wont go out of my way to drink this, if it’s a macro-oriented bar, I will happily drink this and enjoy it.  Light in hop flavor, fairly dry.  Not going to knock your socks off, but certainly drinkable and clean.
This isn't one of my favorite Goose Island brews. Honestly, the Honker's Ale tastes a bit like it has geese in it.

Golden-amber color with a medium, creamy head.  Strong taste of hops, but little else to enjoy.  As someone from the Chicago-area, I'm partial to this brew in comparison to the American standards and pils that the city usually drinks.  A no thrills ale that is good to drink.

I liked it alot but there is only so much you can do with an ale.  After a while you really got to know your stuff to make major judgements on different types of ales.  I...well I just drink the stuff. I can't tell you the strain of hops used.

It makes me very sad to say that Goose Island is the *only* craft brewer in North American who's products uniformly disappoint me.  The family resemblance from one Goose Island  product to another is very consistent - like Bell's of Kalamazoo, but nowhere near as good.  First sip - you know it's from Goose Island.  More's the pity, because that family resemblance I can only describe as
"malt with floor mop squeezin's added to it".  It tastes *musty!*  I've actually tried the Honker's Ale several times - no dice.  I really wanted to find something to love in Goose Island - I consider the American craft brewers to be "beer Messiahs" - but it consistently comes in dead last across my tongue.  Try Bell's Amber or Sam Adams Boston Ale, and see if you really think this is better.

Another beer I had at a gathering. I found the beer to be quite a nice beer that would do well if your trying to get your friends to break from the Bud/Miller brigade. I haven't tried some of the other Goose Island beers, but if this is any indication, they would be worth a try

I was in Chicago so I had to sample the local "flavor".  Pretty good stuff.  You have t0get it at Oven Grinder's in town with a Pizza Pot Pie.  On the beer, nice hop aroma and zing.  Dark amber in color... nice stuff.
Nice aroma with an attractive amber coloring.  Satisfyiing flavor with a spicy bite from beginning to end.  A tasty pale ale - a decent choice if you're in that type of mood.

Clear bright copper color, small white head, sweet light malt aroma, kind of nutty. Light malt flavors, some hops noticable in the finish, clean. This pale ale is very light in body and on the tongue, a little watery, otherwise has some good light flavor, maybe a good sesssion beer.
Good malt and a nice hint of spice.  Good on a hot afternoon in moderate quantities.
Nice malts... hops were there too, but not as much as i would have expected.  Sort of reminded me of Killian's with more hops.  Pretty good.
This was a decent offering from Goose Island.  Not horrible by any means, but leaves a little to be desired.  Nice finish, but starts a bit weak.
Good balance. I liked the sweetness and citrusy hop flavors and aromas, balanced by nice maltiness.  Cascade hops and something else I cant put my finger on...a good, relaxing beer.
A good ale. Reminded me a little od Sam Adams, only not as strong of a pecan lager taste.  Overall, very good.
(bottle)Dark straw colored, ok head with light nose of hops and malt. Above average APA with excellent balance. A good session  beer.
pretty dark and malty for a "pale" ale.  pretty good, but could be hoppier.
Very light pale.  Not very hoppy.  A light malty aroma.  Not very impressed with this offering. The label says that it is an English Bitter, the balance seems more appropriate to that style of brew.

I meant to have this stuff on a recent trip to Chicago but failed.  Had a sample from a friend's pint the other night.  Let's see...light fruity hops, very smooth and clean.  Well-balanced, nice smell.  This would be a good all-purpose beer to have a 6 of in the fridge.
I don't know if it was b/c I had just gotten done from a long night of moving or what- but I drank this one down really fast - it was smooth and very refreshing.

This one was a little disappointing to me because it was not too heavy in the hops department. I don't know if that is a regional thing (west coast APAs seem to have more bite) but this is still a well rounded and smooth offering from Goose Island.

Had one of these on draft to start the night off right yesterday at the Old Bag of Nails Pub in Upper Arlington.  This brew pours a sparkling orange amber.  The average creamy white head is mostly diminishing with good lacing.  The faint flowery grapefruit nose never really comes alive as the brew warms.  The spicy warm flavor is very good with a sweet grapefruit start and an average nutty bitter finish that has notes of raisin;  balanced with moderate complexity.  The smooth light soft body is a tad watery, but has good bite, and a very clean finish.  Not the best APA I've had, but very good all the same.
all i have to say is WOW, wonderful aroma, beautiful amber color, perfect balance of carbonation, sweetness and hops.
This is a very crisp, clean tasting ale.  It has a nice, fruity flavor balance with a good hoppy bitterness.  It is good to see this good beer getting wider distribution.
A very good pale ale, one of the best out there. It's that sweet lake michigan water that made milwaukee famous, except it's chicago.

A nice dark goldenrod color; head was average; Malty nose. A very nice session beer that had the citrus notes that I find in Boulder Singletrack and the malty notes that I find in St Arnold Amber. Three or four of these would go down nicely without much thought.
Overall, pretty easy to drink. But I think it could use a bit more hops character. Being from the Chicago area, I think Goose Island's products are a bit overrated in general.
Fruity and a little bit of malt. I pick up some smoke in the finish. I like Bell's and 3Floyds much better though.

I live in Chi-town for 5 years and if you ever happen to land in the windy city have yourself a chicago style deep dish slice a pizza on Sheffield near the Vic and one of these. Best local brew I ever had.
A fruity, toffeish medium bodied pale ale with well balanced bitterness. A nice easy drinking ale.

Hey, I'm a diehard Chicagoan and from the Northside to boot, so I have to stick with the best local beer around.  This is definitely an icon and it didn't hurt that I used to live across the street from the brewery.
A decent ale with a unique flavor.  A nice smoky finish and an over all decent beer.
An interesting pale ale.  Good combination of malt and hops, but the flavor is unique.  A bitter, sweet, and spicy taste is not for everyone.
Pretty good, pretty bland though.  I had a few at Miller's Pub in Chicago last week.....so I have good memories of it.

Tingly, with an evident mouthfeel. Rich & malty, finishing with some hoppy bitterness & some lingering sweetness. Good, but seems slightly unbalanced. I detected a "hollow-musty" off-flavor that I wasn't fond of. I'm sure it's better on tap.
Not too bad at all.Nice to have a Chicago brewed beer on my trip to Chicago.

Pretty good -- a staple on my own Chicago trips, to.  Nice color and balance, though I remember it being better in the Windy City -- location always helps a beer, plus I usually had it on tap.  Still, always a solid choice, though the IPA is definitely better.

Draught @ Goose Island Clybourne:  A favorite when I go to Chicago! They also have a cask conditioned version that is even better!  Dark golden color with some white head.  Mild hop nose with sweetness too.
I didn't particularly care for this at all.  The flavor is very bitter and "malty".  For a pale ale, I'll go look to many other brands before I drink this again.
I would take no other beer inside the continental United States over this one.  What can I say, the Windy City never lets you down
A very good ale.  I do not like many of the other beers i have tried from this brewery, but this was was very good on tap with some pizza.  Pretty nice head and a good, fruity taste to it.
A pretty decent pale ale.  Nice caramel sweetness, balanced by a decent hop character.  Very decent.
An above average ale.  A few samples have been a bit yeasty/cloudy. Nothing particulary wrong or right with it.  A fine all around session beer, but nothing in need of a critical tasting.
A good Pale Ale.  I am not a fan of this style, but I find this beer very drinkable.
I enjoy on tap when I am close to Chicago, but don't go out of my way to drink it at other times.

Nice hop aroma rises from the glass before the first sip.  Color is a mild reddish tint with shades of gold.  The head on my sample faded quickly, but left a nice lace pattern in the pint glass.  Mild flavors of both malt and hops hit the end of the tongue but then the flavor fades as fast as the head.  Some hops in the after taste but I was left wondering why there’s been so much fuss about this beer.  There’s just nothing really special about it, though it’s not a bad beer by any means.  This might make a nice training beer for those wanting to explore the very beginning edges of the craft beer movement.

Solid.  Middle of the road, for a 
microbrew. .............................
It seems Goose Island beers fall a little short, as compared to say, New Holland Brewing. Finishes with a grapefruit-like citrus hop flavor.

Have to re-up this beer.  Its previous 3.0 rating was clearly left-field.  A re-sampling of it (bottle, 45-50 deg F) revealed a nicely caramelly ale with a bit of spicy and earthy hops around the edges, a balanced hoppy finish.  Nice amber color.
This brewery's other products set a tough standard to match.  This one falls a little short.  Clean finish, and moderate hops, but more mass-produced in character.
Nice APA.  Light slightly hazy amber.  Nose a bit malty.  Flavor starts with good maltiness, mildly nutty with some caramel, then a citric hoppy bite to it.  Very nice, creamy and fully.  Nice stuff.
Smooth and consistent, never had a bad one..................................
A descent ale. Probably the best thing ive had from the goose island brewery. A little too bitter but otherwise an ok beer.
Another in the kinder, gentler pale category................................

I've had this bottled and on tap, and either way it's an ultra-dependable beer. I can't think of anything bad to say about it. Solidly recommendable even to the relatively unadventurous. Your grandmother would enjoy Honker's Ale.
Overall a decent pale. Nice aroma and flavor with a marshmallow like maltiness and nice spicy hop bite from the Goldings. A good session brew that I'd gladly have another of.
I thought that this was a good Ale.  I must thank Got Stout? for this one...
I must go along with Gusler on this, but it is still a fine beer. Really good with a hearty meal.
Some very well-balanced micro straight outta the Windy herself..............
This is always the first beer I drink when I get to Chicago.  A nice full bodied beer with a pleasant aftertaste.
Light pale amber hue, good carbonation and head formation. Malty aroma. Sweet malt, slightly biscuity palate, decent bitterness in the finish.

One of Goose Island's many fine selections.
Nice smooth flavor and plenty of hops round out
this ale.
Good Chicago beer with a strong taste.  Good to have with a meal on a cold night.
A little on the bitter side, but can still be fairly refreshing.............
Overall good.  A beer snob's chugging beer.  Best enjoyed during lunch hours.
Good stuff.  Not as flavorful as other ales, but it a nice standard in its category.
Good quaffer with fruity/hoppy notes........................................
A damn fine ale (had this on tap).  Good body, smooth initial taste, slight hoppy aftertaste, perfect finish.
